column10: I am a longtime ME fan and find the original trilogy to be solid gold with good and ever improving game play, good story telling, and well developed characters.  No matter how old the game may be I keep coming back to it.

While I wouldn’t say that [i]Mass Effect[/i] is near the greatest RPGs in recent history, it deserves recognition for combining traditional RPG elements such as extensive worldbuilding and dialogue with Action mechanics such as fast combat and a tight story. It’s a synergy that works amazingly together, and the amount of content up for grabs here is insane; 3 massive games with a large assortment of DLC, there's 80-100 hours of content if you do everything, and provides enough combat and dialogue variety to be well worth a replay.

If you’re already familiar with the trilogy, be aware, there's nothing revolutionary here. The first game has received a number of tweaks to reduce some of the clunkier mechanics, as well as both a graphical and UI overhaul, but it really stops there, with the ethier games feeling near identical to their original counterparts. The smaller tweaks to the series are certainly appreciable, but for a definitive full priced re-release, it certainly feels like more effort could’ve been put in.

[h1]Mass Effect[/h1]
[i]Mass Effect[/i] is such a great introduction to the world itself. I don’t see many sci-fi worlds with this level of depth, an assortment of fantastical technology and alien races makes the world feel very genuine, existing outside of the player's involvement. You see this come to a full head in the Citadel, [i]Mass Effect’s[/i] main hub populated by every alien race, richly detailed with stories to find, brilliant to explore from an outsider perspective.

Exploration is far more prominent here than the rest of the series, but everywhere you can visit feels so barren. There are tons of side-quests that lead to repetitive planets, consisting of basic terrain and the same three interiors repeated. Even the main quest worlds are rather dull, consisting of a handful of uninteresting human colonies, Virmire being the only location I remember fondly. [i]Mass Effect[/i] is willing to throw a lot of objectives at the player, but almost everything that takes you outside of the citadel feels uninteresting, and fails to capitalise on the wonderous world they’ve built here.

The shooting that carries you through the game is fairly decent. A few essential changes have been made from the original, such as guns no longer being locked behind class, which stops some classes from feeling too limited. Each class’ combination of weapons and powers give the player a huge variety of options, complimented by your squadmates, but a lack of the refined shooting and advanced powers makes [i]Mass Effect[/i]’s combat a far cry from the quality of its sequels.

The first game excels as an introduction to the universe and is a good mechanical lead-in to the future titles, but unfortunately by itself, it's a rather clunky and flawed RPG.

[h1]Mass Effect 2[/h1]
This is where [i]Mass Effect[/i] found itself, there are huge improvements in every area, which leads to my favourite game in the trilogy. 

The plot is such an unusual offshoot from the first game, feeling more like a heist movie, as you spend the entire game gathering up twelve squadmates and earning their loyalty to pull off an impossible job. There are only a small handful of missions directly related to the core threat, but they do an impressive build up to an absolutely amazing finale.

This storyline setup is really fun. [i]Mass Effect 2[/i] undeniably feels more character driven with so much of your time dedicated to squadmates, which has always been where the writing shines brightest for me. The variety of your companions and their personalities is fantastic, providing great variety in whose interactions you want to see in each mission. 

However this story feels so disconnected from its predecessor, that it can suffer in its questionable relevance. Shepard is justifiably distant from the first game here, but it does feel as though too many of your previous actions simply don’t matter here. Likewise, your big mission in this game has minimal impact on the sequel, resulting in this title feeling mildly irrelevant despite its amazing storytelling.

Despite the smaller story, [i]Mass Effect 2[/i] does a great job expanding the universe introduced from the first game. Far away from the idealistic society portrayed in the original, the world here mainly consists of the shadier yet beautiful locations, hubs like Omega and Illium feel so distinct from the Citadel, representing the darker societies that inhabit them. There's a much greater variety in aliens to meet, locations to explore and enemies to fight; every aspect of the game is enhanced by the expanded worldbuilding.

Perhaps 2’s greatest strength is in its gameplay improvements. Exploration has been cut down to avoid repetitive empty space, and the class system is fantastic now. Each archetype has its own identity, from the movement based Vanguard to the utilitarian Sentinel, distinct powers and focuses for each class makes combat way more fun as you lean into your specialization. The mechanics in play are ultimately simple for an RPG but extremely effective at making every shootout enjoyable.

[h1]Mass Effect 3[/h1]
The climatic and divisive finale to the trilogy aims to be the biggest title yet, and while there are a few major missteps, overall it's a fairly strong conclusion to the series.


The oncoming threats set up in the first two titles are brought to a head here, leading this title to have a strong “end of days” motif. Everywhere you visit shows the importance of your quest with every race and location you’ve grown to know and love cast into disarray by the reapers. The amount of choices and continued character relations from previous games returning here is insane, all contributing to a united effort, and while these choices were never the most diverse or interesting, it's amazing to see how many of them are acknowledged in this climactic finale.

There's not a huge amount of combat changes, but what is here is deeply appreciable. Changes to movement make combat generally feel smoother and a few ability additions help flesh out your character, you can keep your level from the previous game here and continue that feeling of climbing in power which is great. It does feel as though it's wearing thin, you get into an insane amount of gunfights in this title. I’d recommend taking a break between each game. 3's lack of major innovations can make the combat feel very stale if you play it all back to back.

Both the gameplay and the story heavily prioritise an action tone in this title. I don’t think this really did the series justice, [i]Mass Effect[/i] already had a great balance of Action and RPG in the prior titles, but here we start suffering from the abundance of dated mechanics such as turrets and chase sections. Combined with the finales' insistence to resolve every single contentious point in the entire galaxy, [i]Mass Effect 3[/i] can’t help but feel artificial far too often.

Despite its improvements, [i]Mass Effect 3[/i] will always live in infamy for its writing. It’s still good, most of the time, but it can feel as though key moments in the plot haven’t been thought out nearly enough, such as Shepard’s relationship with Cerberus, or the notoriously awful Kai Leng. The ending in particular, can feel rather lackluster and fails to represent the trilogy. The plot still feels enthralling for most of the run, especially with the enormous improvements to the Paragon/Renegade system no longer locking you down a strict path and instead focusing on a genuine character, but there are enough problems to still blemish the overall story.

[h1]8/10[/h1] 
[i]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/i] is an important note for the evolution of RPGs, and this collection is now the ultimate way to play it. I’d highly recommend picking up the collection in order to experience one of the best sci-fi worlds we’ve seen in a video game.

[Mass Effect 1]
Ok, I can see why this was really popular and got a bunch of sequels. There's an epic space opera storyline, and you get to decide the fate of the galaxy by shooting stuff with a gun.

I was honestly kind of disappointed by the gameplay - for all the RPG trappings, it was super shallow and linear. It played a lot like a visual novel with dull shooting sequences between the chapters - it reminds me a bit of Control in that respect, but there's no Ashtray Maze. For all the conversation options, I feel like most of them didn't make any difference. 

There was a skill tree, but I don't feel like it made any difference. I maxed out my intimidate skill, but it enabled an extra conversation option maybe once, early on. Similarly, I maxed out electronics and decryption, but the only time it made checks (that I'm aware of) was to tell me to use my electronics skill to salvage a downed satellite, and then tell me my (very high) electronics skill was too low.

It was pretty satisfying to save the galaxy, but I wish I'd had more fun along the way.

[Mass Effect 2]
This was a much better game than Mass Effect.

My skill tree gave me actual usable abilities instead of intangible attributes whose effects I couldn't see, I got a wide spectrum of secondary characters to work with (or not (Zaeed)), and the majority of the side quests revolved around the interesting secondary characters instead of being "go to this planet and shoot some dudes for some credits".

The missions are still largely oriented around shooting dudes from behind rows of boxes, but they did change it up on a number of occasions, and the addition of the abilities added an extra dimension to the box-shooting, at least.

The story was even more epic, if possible, and I felt like Shepard had more agency to affect its path.

I'm genuinely looking forward to Mass Effect 3.

[Mass Effect 3]
Mass Effect 3 was certainly a game. It started out feeling very epic in scope, and the ending was very strong (if a little oorah), but I felt like the middle was a wide sea of meh.

You're supposed to be recruiting factions and gathering resources for the war effort, but almost all of the missions feel very generic and samey. The teammate options are also pruned way down from ME2.

Overall, I don't regret playing it, and I really enjoyed the conclusions of a few of the storylines, but in the latter half I was just slogging through to resolve the story and get my 100GB back.

[Overall]
Mass Effect Legendary is a very good game (Mass Effect 2) with a dull prologue (Mass Effect 1) and an overly drawn-out conclusion (Mass Effect 3). I enjoyed most of my time with it, but I probably won't buy Andromeda.

To say I love and cherish Mass Effect as a series would be a drastic understatement. At time of review, you'd see I have 100% completed the achievements across about 200 hours of gameplay. This is but a fraction of the actual time I've spent with this trilogy, with my playthroughs of each game well into the 20-count across my original Xbox 360 copies, my PC copies on Origin, and here on the Legendary Edition. I've basically mapped each game to the back of my mind, and know each and every corner of them. Mass Effect is one of my favourite series of all time. No questions, no doubts, and the Legendary Collection is, far and beyond, the best way to experience the original trilogy.

Starting with Mass Effect 1, this is where the Legendary changes are the strongest. I've always had a bit of a special appreciation for the original ME1's gameplay, given I had played through it about eight times before ME2 was even released. But it has aged pretty poorly, and my recommendation to play the trilogy always came with the caveat of "please tolerate ME1's gameplay and don't just go into ME2 with Genesis". Legendary Edition not only drastically polishes the game up, but it gently overhauls the gameplay to be more in line with the other two. Cover shooting is much more responsive, training requirements are mostly abolished so all of the weapons you carry are actually usable rather than just what your class specializes in, AI is a bit more responsive and less buggy, targeting with powers is a bit more consistent, weapon equips now have different properties to give them different playstyles... there are a lot of changes, and it does still play like ME1. But it is unquestionably the best way to play ME1, and I can now happily recommend it without caveats.

Mass Effect 2 feels the least touched, which is simultaneously a good thing and a bad thing. ME2 was caught in a visually awkward period between reusing a lot of ME1 assets with minimal improvements to the textures and models, and leaning into a more distinct visual style that would be further cemented by ME3. So while ME2 Legendary has been given visual improvements across the board, it now feels the most noticeably weak visually. Additionally, if you were a fan of ME2's gameplay, it's basically unchanged aside from dispersing DLC weapons into the game's shops. But, personally, I've always felt ME2 was a little flat in terms of its gameplay. It doesn't quite reach the levels of insanity that ME1 gunfights can reach in the later levels, and doesn't have the distinct flow and strength of ME3's gunfights. ME2 could've used a few improvements, but leaving it alone makes the most sense given its enormously venerated social status. I know my quibbles with the game are entirely my own, contrarian that I am.

Mass Effect 3 remains my favourite of the trilogy, and the only thing missing from it here in Legendary Edition is the multiplayer. It's still a genuine shame that it wasn't able to make the jump in a more accessible format, but ME3 stands pretty proudly on its own. Even if you're not a fan of the endings ([i]I am, and always have been[/i]), the gameplay, writing, and visual quality all the way through is all aces. Every time I do a trilogy run, getting to ME3 gets me fired up because it's time to have the most fun with the best missions and the best gunplay.

If you haven't tried the trilogy before, this is me telling you it's time. Even at full price, it's absolutely worth the cost of entry. Three of the most incredible modern RPGs, polished up to near-perfection, ready for you to experience them either once again or for the very first time.

[h3]Introduction[/h3]

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a remastered collection of the original Mass Effect trilogy, one of the most acclaimed sci-fi RPG series of all time. The Legendary Edition features enhanced textures, animations, graphics, and performance, as well as various bug fixes and quality-of-life improvements. It also includes all the DLC content for the three games, except for the Pinnacle Station DLC for Mass Effect 1, which was lost due to corrupted source code. The DLC weapons and outfits are no longer available from the start, but are distributed throughout the game or sold in stores, making the progression more balanced and rewarding.

[h3]Like[/h3]

Mass Effect Legendary Edition delivers the best sci-fi story in game form yet, with an amazing cast and characters that are brought to life by the stellar voice acting. The gameplay is improved with some quality of life options, such as unified controls, faster elevators, and better inventory management. The graphics upgrade is also noticeable, especially on ME1, which looks much more polished and detailed. The choices made in the game do feel like they matter, as they affect the outcome of the story and the relationships with the crew. All of this epicness is packaged into one single “game”, which is a delight for fans and newcomers alike. Moreover, the Legendary Edition fixes some of the major bugs that plagued the original game, the achievement/trophy unlocking issues, and the pre-rendered cutscene darkness. These fixes make the game more enjoyable and immersive, without compromising the original vision of the developers.alike.

[h3]Dislike[/h3]

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is not without its flaws, however. I encountered multiple bugs during my playthrough, some of which were game-breaking. I had to restart the game twice in ME1 and three times in ME2 due to crashes. I also experienced some in-game glitches, mainly collision issues, such as enemies getting stuck behind objects and preventing me from progressing. The animation, although improved, still felt stiff and weird at times, especially during conversations. I was disappointed to see that some of the bugs from the original game were not fixed, such as the camera tracking and collision issue that I could replicate in this version. The exclusion of one DLC, Pinnacle Station, also made me feel like this was not the complete edition of the trilogy. Lastly, the game required me to install the EA app, which I found unnecessary and annoying, especially after having trouble with it in the past with Dragon Age on Steam.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a must-have for fans of the original trilogy, as well as for newcomers who want to experience one of the best sci-fi RPGs of all time. The game offers a captivating story, memorable characters, and meaningful choices, all enhanced by the improved graphics, gameplay, and performance. However, the game is not flawless, and suffers from some bugs, glitches, and crashes that can ruin the immersion and enjoyment. The game also requires the EA app, which can be annoying for some players. Despite these drawbacks, I still recommend this game to anyone who loves sci-fi, action, and adventure. As somebody who has never played the originals, here's my short take:

ME1: Best "pure RPG" of the three, great introduction to the world and characters. Combat definitely shows its age as enemies are just numb bulletsponges. You can almost feel like it's KOTOR with shooting mechanics... almost. 8/10

ME2: Best character development, IMHO worst combat of the three, it's a bit more fluid than 1, but relies even more on sponginess of the enemies, which makes later encounters just tedious - not hard, just tedious. Things take annoying amount of time to kill and game relies way too much on throwing a lot of shit at you from all directions. Story overall felt like it didn't move that much in the grander scheme though, ME2 definitely felt more focused on smaller stories and world building - however that only becomes apparent once you're playing ME3. 8/10

ME3: Had a bit much on it's plate in terms of story and tying up loose ends due to ME2 not doing any of it really, but overall executed it fairly well I'd say - at least coming into it with extended ending of the Legendary Edition + after finishing the DLC stories first. Easily the most enjoyable gameplay and combat out of the three - however it lacked in bossfights - there wasn't much of an attempt at anything mechanically interesting. Soo... a bit of a hot take, but I'd give it a 9/10 purely because gameplay was just so much more fun than previous 2, and the rest of it was almost just as good. If I am doing a replay in the future, this is the one I am looking forward to most.

Overall a great trilogy, I can absolutely see Netflix ruining it with their adaptation in the future.

The advertised ultrawide support has not only been generally underwhelming, it tried to autodetect resolution on launch, failed, then somehow crashed my computer and broke my NVIDIA surround. 
So now I have been fixing my system today instead of gaming.
How about a display configuration utility in the fucking launcher instead you absolute fucking ass monkeys?

Uninstalled, requested refund, swore a lot. Then remembered I only paid $5 and I actually *would* like to play these again, so I cancel the refund and re-download the 110GB. 

It does run in ultrawide 5840x1080 now after fixing my displays and getting NVIDIA Surround setup proper again. Antialiasing is bugged through all 3 games and has to be turned off, but whatever, the usual EA jank... 

I'm having fun ...mostly. These are pretty good games still ...mostly.

For a remaster of one of their fan favorites, the execution here is pretty lazy and typical what you expect from EA. There's graphics bugs left unfixed, stuttering framerates while driving around planets, bugs left in that have been there since these games were originally released ... 

And then there's their abomination of a useless launcher getting rammed down my throat.. -_-

On the positive side, I will say it's cool playing the ME3 DLC I ignored when I first played it, since after buying all 3 games being asked to fork out for an actual prothean character (you know, the race central during the ENTIRE STORY of the trilogy) just ticked me off. Which made me completely ignore the other DLC content. And some of that is actually pretty good.

Retaking Omega with Aria and the whole Citadel/Shore leave story. Those were good fun and full of funny writing. That's actually the kind of DLC I don't mind - actual content that adds gameplay. 
If you didn't play the trilogy already though, it's hard to know which are the DLC and they often break the flow of the story. Eg. there's an enemy which has a kinda dramatic reveal in the storyline, but if you play the DLC first, they just casually get thrown at you.

I really recommend turning up the difficulty to make the most of the battles, because otherwise the actual action sequences in the game, are painfully short and it turns into neverending fetch quests and dialogue. Especially ME3.

This is not even close to an RPG. It's a decently designed stat 3rd person shooter with an occupying story, well written dialogues and great voice acting. Some of the characters - unforgettable. Of course it's fun, but it's nowhere near an RPG game. But who doesn't love action shooters with stories?

The entire franchise was a masterpiece, from top to bottom, even though I must admit, I [b]despised[/b] Mass Effect 2's planet scanning, as I like to 100% a game before I go into the next one, so you would imagine how many hours I put only into scanning every planet for the last drop of element zero or platinum. But man, I got so deep into the storyline, that it's one of the [b]FEW[/b] games in which I'm so sad that it ended, and I wish I had another 115 hours to spend again to go through the entire trillogy and experience the game again.

[h1]Mass Effect 1 - the buggy simulator[/h1]
In the first hours, I was getting adapted to the combat system, the ,as you would call it, right side pannel of abilities and team management. 
Infiltrator perk / class seemed like the most fitting one for my character (who I tried to make him look as close as possible as me), so I went with it.
The first few missions went really well, but I regret that I didn't chose the Insanity difficulty, since it [b]at least[/b] gives a good meaning of a challenge, especially for an infiltrator.
Near the end of the game, you pretty much [b]one shot or two shot[/b] almost every single enemy you encounter with the sniper rifle, needless to say on the last boss.


[h3]The one thing I disliked a little bit in ME: 1[/h3]
The MAKO or "Buggy" part of the game seemed interesting, but after you nail down the movement and the [b]four or five[/b] combat encounters, you're pretty much stuck going from planet to planet to get the debris or explore the question marks. 
That's it, the rest of the game was fantastic to me, except of course the casual crash or stuttering.

[h1] Mass Effect 2 - the scanning hell[/h1]
The first noticeable change in this next game was that the power ups weren't on the right side anymore, but at the bottom.
This took some adapting, even though it was fast, but visually it was better. The combat system was better, movement was better and it felt like a direct upgrade of the first game.

[h3] What I [b]hated[/b] about ME:2[/h3]
The scanning. My God the scanning was hell of a task to fully 100% this entire game.
That's it.

[h1] Mass Effect 3 - the emotional rollercoaster[/h1]
This game is where shit hits the fan, movement between covers, [b]hopping[/b] over the cover which I adored a lot, weapons were meh except the harpoon cannon which is extremely OP. The characters and the dialogue feel more alive, with many choices, and I liked the DLC integration too, both in ME2 and ME3.
The ending really struck me though, even if I watched it very long ago when the game dropped, it felt geniune and raw this time I played it, and I loved it.

Mass Effect stands alone. There isn't any other series I can think of that ties each iteration into each other in such a way as to make the player invested to such a degree. There are plenty of games with a great story, and characters. There are games with fantastic sequels, that have important choices. But none take those choices and pull them through each game to such a degree. 

The choices aren't going to take the story on some wildly different courses, no. But when you get to the third game and see two background characters have a happy ending and this can only happen because of a choice you made in a side quest early on in the first game it sells the "illusion" that your choices do actually have an impact. Ultimately that's what matters, the illusion, and Mass Effect sells a convincing illusion.

Brilliant trilogy. Very good games but extremely easy to abuse and trivialise. The story gets worse with every instalment but gameplay get way better especially ME3. ME1 is still the best one of the series and ME3 is second best.

-ME1: Very good story and dialogues, best of the series because they have a massive repertoire of decisions that can be made. Very basic third person shooter with a basic cover system which is basically useless if you ask me. The AI is quite dreadful and easily exploitable because most enemies run very slowly. Quests and missions are quite dull but there are good sequences and foundations to really enjoy your progression through the game.

What makes this game incredibly good is the management of your squad and your abilities via combat pause. Not many games use this kind of system and it really works in this game because, there are a lot of abilities and choices to make in which doing it in real time would be extremely difficult. It is impressive the world they have created and everything you can explore.

-ME2: This is probably the worst of the series because, it does a 180 on the story and it forces you to use the cover system. The cover system is not terrible but it changes the gameplay dynamics drastically compared to ME1, where I believe it did not need to. The story is also pretty bad from beginning to end. It is very unfortunate that they went the route they did but, it is very unique and it did spice things up.

Compared to ME1, ME2 is a lot more linear and has less decisive dialogues, making it an easy paragon or renegade choice. Also there are so many new squad mates that it gets too much following the side stories. The amount of work to get these stories working is insane compared to the payout. They also added ammo to weapons in ME2 which completely destroys the fast pace and smoothness that ME1 had with infinite ammo. Worst part of all of it is the dismantling on the talent tree. How can you remove the intricate system of ME1 and replace it with the awful system of ME2? Disgraceful.

It does improve a bit with the missions and settings. While ME1 is just huge maps of nothing with a few objectives, ME2 is more cohesive and has more dynamic levels, shorter and does not waste your time as much. It is still a good game but it tries to do a lot without it being worthwhile.

-ME3: The best gameplay of the series. Quick, very slick, easy to manoeuvre and excellent gun play for a third person shooter.  Completely improves everything ME2 fails to do, including the talent tree which is more fleshed out and has more decisions for the player. 

The story unfortunately does not make much sense after ME2 as it tries to course correct and follow what ME1 story was trying to do. It also does "member berries" here and there which is alright but, to be honest it does not really work in many of the situations. The whole story is very deficient. Dialogue options are very linear with once in a while choice for renegade or paragon. I prefer this way because it means less effort on quantity and quality of dialogues and more improvements in gameplay.

Otherwise, the AI is way better than the previous game, excellent maps and levels, cover system is great, powers in cover actually work properly, weapon diversity is fantastic, Weapon mods customisation is a welcome addition. ME3 does a lot right and almost no faults.

-ME3: CItadel DLC: This is horrendous. If you ever want to see what "woke" writing looks like, play the Citadel DLC. The worst writing I have seen in a while and bastardise the entire art that is Mass Effect. It literally takes a dump on the whole game, that is how bad this DLC is. I would say avoid like the plague. 

Also, it was with the Citadel DLC that I discovered the use and abuse of powers, especifically "Adrenaline shot". Once I found out how broken it is to get 200% power recharge and spam powers, this game became absurdly trivial and very unfun. I basically played the entire game as a typical shooter, some sort of hardmode and the last 15 hours ended up being unkillable while abusing powers. Being able to do this ruins the fun of the game.

The mass effect trilogy is a very interesting study in game design. Mass Effect 1 had a compelling sci-fi story with incredible and well written characters and a fleshed out world, which came attached to a third person shooter that outdated even for 2007 when ME1 released. 

Mass Effect 2 scaled back the story to almost solely being about Shepard and their companions while adding on to the existing setting with more lore and locations. It also refining the gunplay and rpg mechanics to be a fun shooter that even merits replayability to see how different classes engage with combat. 

Mass Effect 3 expands the scope of the game to the entire galaxy, rather than the sections of it the player was confined to for the first 2 games. However the story attached to the expanded play area was just okay, and clearly underdeveloped. However, it does have by far the best third person shooter gameplay of the 3 entries. Each game seems tailored for a different type of player so it can be jarring going from to the next.

that being said, I recommend the trilogy in it's entirety just to be able to experience a trilogy of games with the same player made protagonist, which is still a rare feat among rpg game series with multiple entries. The Mass Effect trilogy is a gripping space opera and one of the defining rpg series of the last decade and playing through it for the first time is an incredible experience.

There's 2 ways to review properly this game. One if you never played this series, or only played the first 1 or 2 games, but never finished the series. And the other, if you already have played the whole series. 

[b]You have played the whole series [/b]
This game is a [i]should[/i] have, not essential for you, only if you missed some DLC's or you catch a nice discount. This edition have some quality of life improvements, graphics enhancements and a "linear" progression between the 3 games. I put the linear between quotes because you can play all the series with the same character, but the character progression have some differences between games. Plot related, maybe. The improvements in this legendary edition maybe couldn't justify at all, the extra money if you already have the series.

[b] You never played, or finished the Mass Effect trilogy [/b]
Short answer: amazing series (9/10). If you like RPG's, action RPG's, is a [b]must[/b] have.

[b]Main story[/b] - You create a character, you have a spaceship, some bad dudes appear, you must kill the bad dudes so you can restore order. This was a over simplification of the plot, but the main story is basically a space opera. In my opinion, the main story is the main shortcoming of the series. Lacks consistency, complexity and engagement. Altough the main story lacks content, is very well crafted across the 3 games, emphasizing the dramatic [i]crescendo[/i] until the very end.

[b]Side quests[/b] - Here, this gem starts to shine. There's some amazing side quests, some from DLC, which really worth playing. There's this thing about Mass Effect, the story is quite bland, but all the lore complexity allows a rich side questing content. In this aspect, Mass Effect is really good.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - Top notch. The gameplay is action-oriented, with tactical choices and commands to your squad. The controls are simple are while you give instructions the action is frozen, so you can think and act while in combat. When not fighting, you navigate your spaceship in solar systems, wander through cities and settlements, go shopping, talk here and there. While talking, you can chose the flow of the conversation, by reacting or asking about specific topics. 

[b]Graphics[/b] - I really liked the graphics of this edition. This is a very subjective topic, so I will just leave my personal opinion. I played the original game for Xbox 360 and played the 2 for PC. I noticed a higher graphical quality in this edition, even playing at full HD resolution.  The graphical effects seem abundant and well placed and the animations very sharp. 

[b]Sound and Music[/b] - Since we aren't in 1992 anymore, and a Soundblaster compatible card isn't a requirement to enjoy good sound quality, yes, the sound quality is acceptable. Well, the sound effects are appropriate and the voice actors made a terrific job. The music is very good. Each game have a unique music piece, while playing you'll start identifying them. Overall the music is a blend of orchestral cinematic music, synth and space ambient. Some pieces are trully unforgettable. Tip: there's some videos in Youtube of x-hours of mass effect space exploration music, it's nice soundtrack while working or studying :)

Overall is a must have for RPG fans, truly a masterpiece. I think it was one of the last games to be a testament to Bioware quality. Where passion and commitment are clearly poured in this series.

I recently embarked on an unforgettable journey through the Mass Effect Trilogy, and I am absolutely thrilled to share my overwhelmingly positive experience with fellow gamers and sci-fi enthusiasts. BioWare's masterpiece has left an indelible mark on my gaming soul, and here's why

First and foremost, the narrative brilliance of the Mass Effect Trilogy is unparalleled. The depth of the story, the intricacies of the characters, and the sheer scope of the galactic adventure kept me hooked from the very beginning. The way the trilogy seamlessly weaves together an epic tale of interstellar conflict, moral choices, and personal relationships is a testament to the studio's storytelling prowess

The character development throughout the trilogy is nothing short of extraordinary. From Commander Shepard, the charismatic and customizable protagonist, to the diverse and memorable squad members, each character contributes to the richness of the narrative. Witnessing their growth, facing moral dilemmas, and forming deep connections with them made the journey feel incredibly personal

The world-building in Mass Effect is simply breathtaking. The meticulously crafted planets, the varied alien species, and the attention to detail in every corner of the galaxy create a sense of immersion that is second to none. Whether I was exploring the bustling streets of the Citadel or navigating the hazardous terrain of an uncharted planet, the level of detail and creativity in the game world was consistently impressive

The gameplay mechanics are both engaging and dynamic. The combination of intense third-person shooter action, strategic decision-making, and RPG elements offered a perfect blend that kept the gameplay experience fresh and exciting throughout the trilogy. The combat scenarios were thrilling, the exploration was rewarding, and the sense of agency in shaping the narrative added an extra layer of depth to the overall experience

The Mass Effect Trilogy's musical score deserves special mention, perfectly complemented the emotional highs and lows of the story. The sweeping orchestral pieces and haunting melodies enhanced the atmosphere, making every moment feel epic and memorable

In conclusion, the Mass Effect Trilogy is not just a collection of games; it's an emotional and immersive odyssey that will stay with me for years to come. BioWare has created a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of gaming, delivering an unparalleled storytelling experience in the vastness of space
If you haven't embarked on this intergalactic adventure yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the Mass Effect, it's a journey you won't soon forget

Best Sci-fi franchise in gaming history and it's not even close. Few games make me genuinely care for its characters the way Mass Effect does. The story is good, although HEAVILY inspired by Babylon 5 and it has its flaws, but it's the characters and the way they're written and performed, that make these games something truly special. Every one of them has a deep, believable backstory and diverse personalities that make them all unique and feel like real people. Like any good sci-fi, there's dozens (if not hundreds) of hours of lore here filled to the brim with interesting alien species, intergalactic politics and plenty of mystery to keep you hooked. The soundtrack is also excellent at setting the tone of the games and it has some iconic tracks. It's hard to stay objective about a trilogy this influential, but the games do have a couple shortcomings, mainly due to their age. If you regularly play older games than you're probably fine, but otherwise the gameplay can be a bit clunky and it takes some getting used to. Ultimately, I would massively recommend Mass Effect Legendary Edition to anyone who is looking for a new universe to get lost in or just wants to experience a true classic.

[h1]Mass Effect 1 - 9/10[/h1] 
- Story is set within galaxy in the year 2183 where interstellar travel is possible through the use of mass transit devices called Mass Relays, a technology believed to have been built by an extinct alien race known as the Protheans. The government body known as the Citadel Council controls a large percentage of the galaxy and is responsible for maintaining law and order among races of the galactic community. The protagonist of the game is Commander Shepard of special forces program and a candidate to become the first human Spectre, agents given unlimited authority by the Citadel Council to protect the galaxy, they are above the law and answer only to the Council. As Spectre you are given spaceship and crew under your command. What follows is a really interesting journey about seeking knowledge, trying to find ways to beat your enemy, but there may not even be the way, so maybe you need to prepare for your doom. Whole game is very mystical, and at the end of the game you are left with a lot of questions, but with a very good core concepts which leave you desiring for more. Overall really amazing story.
- Characters are very loveable, through the journey you can acquire up to 6 squadmates, meaning that you can choose whether you want to hire some of them. Every mission you choose 2 squadmates, you can level up their stats, change their weapons, talk with them on your ship outside of mission, have romances, bond friendships and so on. 
- Choices are great. Every dialogue you have a lot of options to choose from, and some decisions that you have to make are really interesting and globally important. You also have paragon and renegade meters which are basically good and evil scales, and based on percentage of your paragon/renegade meters you will have options to do/say good/bad deeds through the game, however sometimes renegade may actually be good, so it's all up to you. Choices also "affect" other 2 games.
- Gameplay is a classical third-person shooter gameplay mixed with option to pause the game so you can activate powers, order your squad etc. There are few weapon classes to choose from, you can change weapons all the time, buy at shops, upgrade, sell stuff etc. What makes weapons in this game great is the fact that you have endless ammo based on advanced technology and all you have to worry about is overheating. Aside from combat you also have Mako which is a space car that you use while exploring uncharted planets. You can talk with NPCs on your missions, just like in most RPGs.
- Aside from main missions there is also a lot of side content and most of side stuff is exploring uncharted planets, searching for minerals, visiting strange facilities, fighting various enemies etc. 
- Around 35 h to 100% complete the game

[h1]Mass Effect 2 - 5/10[/h1] 
- I hate the story of this game, I literally hate it. In first 10 minutes of the game some ship attacks you and all your crew flees except you, and you literally die by falling from space to the planet surface. You are completelly dead, but somehow evil organization from the first game, that wasn't even important before decides to spend billions of credits trying to revive you, and after 2 years you are alive again. WTF. My interest in the game dies already at this point, I hated it after this. And it doesn't get better at all. So like I already said in first game you are seeking the knowledge, trying to find ways to prepare for your doom or to somehow beat your enemies, and it's logical that you will continue doing that. Nope, writers of Mass Effect 2 decided to completelly ignore events of the first game and focus on new enemy that kinda has connection to the enemy of the first game, but whole concept is so stupid that it hurts. Whole game feels like a big filler. You can acquire up to 12 squadmates and you can do loyal mission for each of them. Cerberus, an evil organization that revived you is so unnecessary and stupid that it ruined not just this game, but third game too. Illusive Man who is owner of this organization is a guy with diamonds instead of eyes, dude smokes 24/7 and drinks whiskey and somehow knows everything while having unlimited money. This organization used to do experiments on people and now you are forced to side with them cause story wants so. One of the squad members from the first game who was researching old ruins in the first game is now number 1 information trader. That makes no sense at all. Right before final mission FOR NO REASON whole squad decides to leave the ship, you just click on map and they go and leave whole crew unarmed in critical moments. This just happens so plot can progress, I won't spoil how. 
- Dialogue is cringe af, especially in the beginning. There is one moment when you randomly approach alien holding gun and he tells you "do you have a problem with me", and then Shepard takes out his gun and says something like: "Look at the size of this gun, you don't want to mess with me" LOL. 
- Last boss is so lame, but last mission overall is good, it's a suicide mission and your squadmates can actually die permanently. In every mission you go and shoot gangs, you rarely stop to talk with NPCs to find out more, it's not a RPG anymore, it's a shooter. New characters are okay. Around 45 h to 100% complete it.
- One of the rare good things about this game is gameplay, it's really really fun, best in the triology imo, if we ignore the fact that they replaced infinite ammo with thermal clips, so now you have bullets instead of advanced alien technology... 

[h1]Mass Effect 3 - 6/10[/h1] 
- Gameplay is okay. Dialogue has less options than before. Takes around 45-50 h to 100% complete it.
- Story is terrible again, but at least it got some old conflicts resolved. Instead of fighting real enemy from the first game, you are mostly fighting [spoiler]Cerberus[/spoiler] cause they are space Nazis now, killing everyone for no real reason and have their own Bruce Lee. Yes there is a stupid explanation, but it doesn't fit this game, it's unnecessary and stupid. I dislike Cerberus so much that after 100% completing ME1 and ME2 this time I couldn't bother to play ME3 again. ME1 clearly stated that we don't have a chance against the enemy fighting with guns, yet whole game we are trying to acquire war assets and instead of using them since we spent our time doing so, they don't matter. I mean they do, but in illogical sense. [spoiler]At the end you have a choice to press one of 3 buttons, and decide destiny of the whole galaxy, so all your war assets (armies, weapons, people etc.) only matter in a way that they let you press correct button. That's like having 3 colored cookies (blue, red, yellow) and being able to eat blue one if you eat alone, but if you bring your whole family you can eat any of them, makes no sense.[/spoiler] Only great things about this story are 2 conflicts resolved and also Leviathan DLC which is now a side mission. 

[i]Note: This explains how I rate games in my reviews. https://imgur.com/s7VB3Vj[/i]

[h1]Verdict:[/h1] I hate to say this, but even though ME1 is an amazing game, ME2 and ME3 are just series of dissappointments with some good moments, so I would recommend playing the first game, but not the other 2.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition encapsulates the awe-inspiring trilogy of Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2, and Mass Effect 3 in a remastered collection that elevates the series to new heights. The core of its brilliance lies in its exceptional combat, masterful storytelling, and unforgettable characters, all of which are seamlessly intertwined with player choices that echo throughout the entire saga. 

Mass Effect introduces players to a captivating galaxy teeming with lore and richly developed characters. While the original version had its quirks, the remastered edition polishes these imperfections, delivering a visually stunning experience that aligns it more closely with its successors.

Mass Effect 2 stands out as a pinnacle of the series, flawlessly amplifying its predecessor's strengths. With tighter combat mechanics, intricate storytelling, and pulse-pounding missions, it earns its place among the top games of all time. The depth of character development is unparalleled, with favorites like Miranda Lawson, Garrus, and Thane standing out amidst an exceptional ensemble. The DLCs further enrich the experience, introducing captivating new characters and missions.

Mass Effect 3 thrusts players into a breathtaking conflict as the Reapers descend upon the galaxy, culminating in a riveting battle for survival. While the game drew criticism for its controversial ending, subsequent updates provided additional closure, assuaging concerns and enhancing the overall narrative. The DLCs offer valuable extensions to the story, providing further resolution and moments of camaraderie with beloved allies.

I'm judging the game as a complete trilogy.
The fact that the story overall somewhat forms a coherent narrative on top of the morality/choice and combat/gameplay mechanics is astounding.
The games on their own are quite weak; the first is nice and perhaps the most replayable (in my opinion) but lacks companion interactions and player relationships, yet ironically is the most role-play like game of the three.
The second seem to be the weakest, because now that there are better companion interactions, the gameplay is completely overhauled in favor of modern-day gunplay; which can be jarring if you continue into the second game immediately after finishing the first one.
The third, however, seemed to find a somewhat amicable balance between R.P.G. progression and gunplay, on top of partner and N.P.C. interactions, although never excelling in either.
The only thing I really hated from this collection are the inconsistencies between all three games. Perhaps they've always been there, but they are more noticeable now since all three are so easy to play straight through. Few examples are the thermal clip mechanics just for the sake of having ammo in the second and third game (gameplay wise), The captains cabin music in the second game changed from iconic tracks of the first game to some generic electronic by the time you reach the third game (or perhaps I didn't win enough tracks in the Citadel DLC), and exploration mechanics changing from game to game; the first was the nicest since you actually landed on the planets (though mostly barren). The second was the most frustrating since you have to farm the planets through multiple probes. The third rectifies this but it's more of an expedited form of the farming that comes from the second game.
Overall, I give this series a 8/10.

I can confidently say that this is the best sci-fi rpg game I have ever played as well as being one of my favorite games. Is it weird to say that in 2024 the Mass Effect trilogy is still the best scifi RPG/Story based game available? Because I still fail to find a real contender. Experience this universe and characters across these 3 games is really something special that stays with you even a while after you finish it.

Now each game in the trilogy is somewhat unique on the positives or negatives it brings.

The original Mass Effect is just dated in many aspects with the gameplay being the worst offender. It just never reaches above mediocre for the year 2024 even with the upgrades of Legendary Edition. However, to compensate the universe and lore work is outstanding even if sometimes presented in a boring way (out of the way side quests and text based exposition). A lot of the character setup which will payoff later is also done here which is an underrated aspects of ME1.

Mass Effect 2 is my favorite and it is just the better individual game from the trilogy. The setup with the suicide mission and having to recruit your squadmates just works brilliantly.  There is so much freedom in what way you can approach the content presented to you. If the first game sells you on the universe then the second game is the one sells you on the characters. The only flaw I can think of is that the plot of ME2 is somewhat disconnected from the main conflict which always felt a bit weird in retrospective.

Now the third game is complicated. I still think it is a great game that has a few rare terrible moments in it. The gameplay feels great still and ends up as a good iteration of ME2. The setup for the final part of the plot also work great with ME3 having a really strong opening. The plot points related to your companions from previous games are handled really well imo and take into account a lot of your actions across the entire trilogy. However, the main plot kind of stumbles after the initial arc with a very meandering middle portion and luck luster ending both from a story and gameplay perspective. This has been talked to death over the years so there is no need to rant anymore about it.

Overall, Mass Effect ends up being a lot more than the sum of its parts. It creates one of my fovorite SciFi universe and characters with moments that no other SciFi setting game has managed to top thus far.
This game was so much fun; the story and characters were great, your choices mattered and the gameplay was fun.

Title: "A Stellar Journey Revisited: Mass Effect Legendary Edition"

Review:

There are few games in the vast cosmos of RPGs that have left a mark as indelible as the Mass Effect Legendary Edition. As a fervent fan, I can unequivocally say that this game stands as my all-time favorite RPG. My journey with Mass Effect began during a summer holiday that now seems like a distant, yet cherished memory. It was a period marked by days and nights seamlessly blending into one another, as I delved deeper into its rich, immersive universe, barely pausing for sleep.

The experience of playing Mass Effect is like embarking on an interstellar odyssey. The game's ability to intertwine an epic narrative with deeply personal stories is nothing short of masterful. Each character I encountered was not just a digital creation but a being with hopes, fears, and aspirations. The connection I felt with these characters was profound, transcending beyond the screen and impacting me on a personal level.

One of the most striking aspects of Mass Effect is how it allows players to shape their journey. Each decision, each interaction, felt weighted with significance, contributing to a narrative tapestry that was uniquely mine. This level of personal investment in the storyline is a rare feat in gaming, one that Mass Effect accomplishes with aplomb.

Moreover, the Legendary Edition’s enhancements only serve to amplify this epic saga. From the refined graphics that breathe new life into familiar landscapes and characters, to the improved gameplay mechanics that make the experience smoother and more engaging, every aspect of the game has been meticulously upgraded.

There's a certain melancholy that comes with completing a game as rich and absorbing as Mass Effect. It's akin to saying goodbye to a dear friend, knowing that the experience cannot be replicated. I often find myself wishing I could erase my memories of the game, to play it once more with fresh eyes, to experience the thrill of the unknown, the excitement of first discoveries.

In conclusion, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition is not just a game; it's a journey—a saga that transcends its medium. It stands as a testament to the power of storytelling in video games and remains a beacon for what the RPG genre is capable of achieving. For both veterans of the series and newcomers alike, this edition offers an experience that is both nostalgically familiar and exhilaratingly new. It is, without a doubt, an interstellar masterpiece worthy of every accolade.

With that out of the way i can share some thoughts on this game and try not to spoil anything in the process.
This game is a good example of how games should evolve with each new sequel in terms of gameplay and integration into story telling that immerses players into lore of its world, admittedly it is not a perfect game by a long shot, but still a damn good experience if one gives it a fair shot.
All three games make sure that every choice you make have some impact on you and for good or bad, you will ultimately see results of those in final iteration that will reflect all of decisions you made throughout your adventures. Storytelling is great and in some cases it will pit you with some really difficult choices to be made in order to accomplish your goal.

PROS:
- Great storytelling that gives a lot of insight into world of Mass Effect via Codex logs.
- Choices throughout all of games make impact both small or big and may involve death of your companions if you are reckless.
- Game does exceptionally good job at conveying horrors of massive scale wars and no matter how hard you try, not everyone can have a "happy ending" and you can only do so much to help those in need. This is motive is prominent in ME3 and showcases protagonist's mental state.
- Very memorable characters that you grow to like and each one of them have their own stories to tell if you invest enough time to learn about them and try not to get them killed in action.
- Decent roster of romancing options if one desires so.

CONS:
- Enemy AI sometimes make some hilarious decisions during combat (eg. enemy turn their backs and walk backwards as they rush your position)
- In ME1 this issue is most prominent... biotic enemies if in great numbers (saving grace not many instances throughout game) will spam crowd control ability that will keep you stunlocked with hardly much chance to get up and defend yourself, all the while rest of their squad will gun you down.
- At times game is not very clear with you as to how story progress locks and will keep you stuck into rails and that in turn will make some quests locked.
- ME1 and ME2 sprint mechanic is limited and poor Shepard is in terrible condition for prolonged jog.

In overall i enjoyed time playing this game and suffering some of choices i made in my own playthrough and would recommend this game to any fan of good storytelling and butt kicking. A solid 7/10 on grounds of some emotional moments and impact it made on me.

Finely crafted video game with an exceptional story and surprising amount of depth not found in your average 3d person shooter.  

The story is engaging right from the start, with multiple dialogue options to choose from which drive the narrative in significantly different directions. The characters you meet are interesting and I immediately found myself invested in my character’s choices.  I focused on the main story but you could easily sink dozens of hours into completing side quests alone. 10/10

The combat on the other hand, definitely felt a bit dated.  While there is a rich amount of customization and weapons/abilities to level up, the combat itself lacks variety and depth. For example, there is virtually no difference between a body shot and a headshot. Most encounters basically have you hiding behind a wall, firing and moving on.  Combat  feels repetitive and ultimately serves as a means to progress the story.

There are a handful of hacking puzzles and driving section as well which help break up the combat.  The puzzles were actually fun and require a bit of trial and error.  

Overall, this is a fantastic game and undoubtedly worth a play through.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is my favorite series of games of all time. I’m not sure what kept me from playing through the trilogy sooner, but I’m glad I eventually came around to it.

The story, side quest content, and character development of your companions are still amazing all these years later, even compared to some of the more recent AAA releases. I think the companion loyalty missions in Mass Effect 2 stand out the most. That being said each game has many great moments that make it worth sticking through for. This is even more impactful if you play the games chronologically and import your character from one game to the next as some decisions you make in the first game will impact your experience in the second and even the third installment. This can vary from minor differences to major plot points.

Though obviously, the trilogy isn’t perfect. The combat, especially in ME1, can feel a bit outdated and annoying (the Mako sections come to mind), and the “one-button-does-everything” mechanic in the third game is frustrating as hell. Just let me sprint around and not pull me to every wall I run across like a magnet damnit! 

The quest log in ME3 is also a headache. Why do the missions not disappear off it if I can no longer complete them? And why is it more difficult to find out what you’re actually supposed to do or who to talk to concerning a quest? The first two games had the journal nailed down, so the change in ME3 seems inexplicable and pointless.

Finally, the ending of ME3 wasn’t all that great, but since pretty much everyone has complained about it already, I won’t elaborate too much. I just wish the choices you make throughout the three games could impact the ending in a more significant way as well as offer a more satisfying conclusion.

Again, all these criticisms don’t take away from the overall amazing experience that is the Mass Effect trilogy. And hell, if you don’t like something, you can bet there are mods to fix it - everything from textures and lighting to story and romance.

It’s also great that the Legendary Edition goes on sale quite often. I myself got it for €6, and can confidently say that those were the best €6 I’ve ever spent.

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Mass Effect 1[/h3]
The one that began it all, and that’s a merit of its own - even with all the clunkiness and half-assed mechanics it may have. In this Legendary edition, ME1 is the oldest and, of course, has received the best uplift from its former self. The remastering work, in some fields, borders on the “remake”; the UI was completely reworked and modernized in comparison to the unwieldy, clunky disaster of the original. Everything feels smoother, more responsive, more fluid. The visual upgrades are impressive, and a far cry from the original in almost all aspects; however, this probably weighed more on its dated engine, and that’s the reason behind the sporadic crashes and frame-drops in specific areas. 

Gameplay–wise, an effort has been made to rebalance the economy, loot tables, weapons and enemy difficulty. On one side, this makes the early-to-mid game phases more challenging on higher difficulties, so much that you might get 1-shot but snipers and other shenanigans; on the other it makes late-game much more trivial compared to the original. This is mainly due to the massive power creep in both weapons and attachments, other than absurd amounts of money gained from sales, and imbalances in the XP gained from side missions, far more than it would be reasonable. Result: Shepard will become an unstoppable killing machine, capable of 1-shotting most enemies with heavier weapons and ragdoll the rest across the battlefield by sheer bullet impact force.

The controls, UI, movement and cover systems have been largely overhauled, a large improvement over the clunky mess that were the controls of the original ME1, as now they’re more similar to the far superior sequels in handling. For the rest, the game remains largely the same, including the tedious side-exploring of planets for collectibles or the time-consuming meandering through locations with dubious fast-travel solutions, if any. It’s a good RPG, but in my opinion the weakest of the trilogy gameplay-wise.

[h3]Mass Effect 2[/h3]
Considered by many, myself included, to be the overall apex of this trilogy, ME2 has undergone visible but comparatively-minor overhauls if compared to its older brother. The lighting solutions are markedly improved, same for textures and effects quality, overall offering a crispier visual fidelity, but not without downsides. The visible, annoying aliasing (jagged edges) can’t be countered very well by the shoddy anti-aliasing solution, so you’ll either have to live with it, or use GPU control panel fiddling or external mods (such as ReShade) to alleviate the problem. Moreover, roughly the same results, except for lighting, could be achieved with existing mods, like the popular “ALOT” to name one. Is the remaster version better? Yes, it is, but not without additional performance issues, especially at the Citadel.

The balance shenanigans of ME1 Remaster are fortunately gone, and the game offers a consistent, well-balanced challenge (unless you play on Insanity, which I did, and is pure pain) that you will enjoy. The story and character arcs of this second entry are the best in the trilogy; most people that aren’t my dead-inside self will become emotionally-invested in the characters and events surrounding Shepard’s space opera epic in saving the galaxy. 

Unfortunately, the devs didn’t want to alleviate the tremendous pain that is planet scanning, which will take literally dozens of hours to 100%, if you’re a completionist or, like me, an autist. Be prepared to put an anime on your second screen (if you don’t have a second screen, buy a cheap one) and scan endless planets for miserable resources and the occasional artifact collectible. You don’t have a choice anyway, if you want upgrades.

[h3]Mass Effect 3[/h3]
This last chapter is, of course, the one that benefitted less from the remaster, as it’s the most modern and, even in its original state, had pretty solid visuals. The remaster’s results are not as noticeable here. Barely any change was made to the gameplay, UI or balancing compared to the original release. Considered by many to be the worst entry of the series (except Andromeda, but we don’t speak about that one…), I don’t think it’s fair to say that, especially gameplay-wise. Sure, the story is a downgrade from ME2 and the ending a train wreck, but it has its great moments; its gameplay is hands down the best in the trilogy, by variety of weapons, builds, combat feel and mechanics. It’s still better than Mass Effect 1 as far as I’m concerned, and having played this trilogy four times in my life, I can tell.

It’s downright a shame that the fun, engaging, varied multiplayer of ME3 was mercilessly scrubbed away. It may have been infested by dumb microtransactions, it may not have been well-balanced, but with some friends or even randoms it was a blast, and had plenty of content not available in the main game, like being able to play as enemy characters with unique abilities, unlocking unique weapons, and even unique enemies like “upgraded” Collectors.
An improvement over the original especial if you have a 4K screen (or 5K like me).

Before we start: Screw EA and their launcher. You cannot play these games offline, because EA doesn't want you to. 

The actual review:
The Mass Effect games are beloved by millions of people. Why? It can't be the gameplay, because it has aged horribly. Especially ME1 is janky as hell. Combat does get more interesting in the other episodes, but it's still mostly repetitive cover shooter nonsense. Tactical depth gets ruined by bullet sponge enemies and wonky squad AI. And don't get me started on the Mako in ME1 - this thing sucks, even in the remastered version. The hovercraft in ME2 is slightly better, but still far from being fun, especially because the missions you're using it in are extremely boring. (Go to objective -> shoot the baddies -> press button to do the thing -> rinse and repeat)

The mission design in general is very outdated. Almost every mission sends you down some kind of corridor. You go through doors, find some loot in adjacent rooms and as soon as you reach a larger room / open space, there's a combat encounter. The enemy AI doesn't flank or use terrain, it only knows three moves: duck for cover, stick out head to shoot, walk towards you. It was a good decision by BioWare to ditch the looter elements from ME1 in favor of a more streamlined shooter experience, but these games are mediocre shooters at best. ME3 has the best combat by far, but it's still not great. 

But let's be honest: Nobody plays these games for the combat. These games are all about the narrative. You're Shepard, the first human spectre - a spectre is basically space James Bond. Your goal is as simple as it is compelling: Defeat the Reapers, an ancient sentient machine species. The main plot moves at a snail's pace, but that's not a big issue, because the narrative focus lies on your companions. And that's where the trilogy is just excellent. Each character comes with a unique and (mostly) interesting personality. You really start to care about your rag tag group of misfits. Character deaths can happen and hit you like a truck. 

In many ways, the Mass Effect games offer typical post 9/11 storytelling. They're deeply rooted in that weird mix of angst and heroism which shaped the 2000s. The council (= space UN) is being portrayed as corrupt and incompetent, meanwhile the military mostly consists of heroes - some of them with tainted morality. Speaking of morality: The paragon / renegade system is a very light take on a morality system. It's mostly flavor and doesn't impact the game too much. It's still fun to punch journalists, though.

Visually, these games have aged surprisingly well. Character models still look nice and the environments are also cleverly designed. You have to remember the technical limitations of the consoles these games were developed for. That's also the main reason for all the corridors. On the flipside, the linear level design leads to a very fluid experience. There's no backtracking, you press forward, shoot stuff and progress. 

The sound design is also great. Each location comes with some nice ambience and the sound effects (weapons!) are also fantastic. And then there's the voice acting: It's nothing short of spectacular, especially if you consider when these games were released. The actress portraying Jane Shepard did an exceptional job.

Summary: Get the LE if you even remotely like sci-fi. It's still worth playing and there's nothing like it.
Do not buy if you want to play these games offline, because... you know why. EA is worse than Krogan poetry.

Mass Effect is often lauded as one of the best trilogies in gaming. I can't disagree, I know I really love the games. So when I say they make pretty much no sense when you actually think about them, I mean it from a place of love. Mass Effect 1's verisimilitude doesn't hang onto the next few games very well. Mass Effect 2 doesn't gel well with the overall plot cohesion at the best of times. Mass Effect 3 has the weakest writing in the series all throughout if you actually spare a thought or two. Some character arcs really don't make sense or can feel forced. Renegade and Paragon accidentally may pigeonhole the player into a single play style. Mass Effect is a really fun power fantasy. If you're looking for a more philosophical angle sci-fi is used for, this is not your game series even if Mass Effect 1 sets up that kind of tone with some of it's choices. The game is carried hard by presentation, intrigue, and characters that keep the player engaged and interested. For that it is one of the most beloved games I have ever seen.

The mouse acceleration feels a little off. The shine and flare added to the graphics can be too bright and blinding at times haha. AI can sometimes get a little bit silly as a treat. EA requires an online connection to play the game via their launcher. I'll still do it because the series is wonderful but that is not a positive. For people who have played Mass Effect I think 1 in particular has had a lot of positive changes from graphics to mechanics. For new players its convenient to have everything in one go as well.

Generic pro-tips for the interested:

-Paragon and Renegade are 'supposed' to be more than simply Good and Bad. Renegade in particular experiences a whiplash in meaning across the games. Experiment and find out whats fun for you

-Vanguard but truly any biotic-adjacent class tends to be fan favorites, mine is Engineer

-Try to go unspoiled for as long as possible. As an older game people have long since formed a generic 'best possible outcome' and it is copy and pasted absolutely everywhere. The game can always be replayed, and no set of outcomes is canon to you but yours(until another game releases and firms things up, of course)

-For returning players play something new. Mass Effect has quite a lot in it, go hit that Renegade option and see something new

Mass Effect Legendary Edition: A Stellar Compilation with Heartfelt Additions

The Legendary Edition of Mass Effect is a breathtaking journey through the captivating universe of Commander Shepard. Packed with visual enhancements, gameplay improvements, and all previously released DLC, it's a definitive experience for both series veterans and newcomers.

Notable DLCs:

Lair of the Shadow Broker: This DLC dives deep into the enigmatic world of the elusive Shadow Broker, offering intense action, gripping narrative, and a chance to reconnect with Liara T'Soni. The added cinematic flair and impactful decisions make it a must-play.

Citadel: A love letter to fans, Citadel brings humor, camaraderie, and heart to the forefront. It's a perfect blend of lighthearted banter and emotional reunions, allowing players to forge deeper connections with their squadmates in a farewell celebration.

Omega: Immerse yourself in the gritty underworld of Omega alongside Aria T'Loak. This action-packed expansion adds layers to the Cerberus threat while offering a unique perspective on the galaxy's darker corners.

Jack's Romance:

For players seeking a passionate and tumultuous romance, Jack's storyline delivers. The scarred and rebellious biotic powerhouse opens up layers of vulnerability, making her a compelling partner. Navigating through Jack's tough exterior to discover the complexities within adds a poignant touch to Shepard's personal journey.

In the Legendary Edition, the visual enhancements bring these emotional moments to life, allowing players to experience Jack's romance with a newfound depth. Whether revisiting the romance or discovering it for the first time, Jack's storyline remains a poignant highlight in the Mass Effect trilogy, contributing to the emotional tapestry of the entire saga.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a compilation of the original Mass Effect trilogy so I will write a review for each individually. For $60 this is well worth the price.

[b]Mass Effect[/b]
This is probably the most underrated in the trilogy. It has the most memorable cast of characters and some amazing missions (and some pretty bland ones too). Even though this was the first one, for me, it was the hardest. The only time across the three games that I switched difficulty was in the final boss fight of this. Even though this is a really great game, it doesn't offer as much side content or areas to explore as Mass Effect 2 and 3. But by far where this trilogy shines is in its story. From the beginning it gives you just enough information to hook you and absorb you into its vast and lore-filled world. While in the middle there are some slightly boring missions, once you get to the end it pulls you back in and makes you want more. - 9.5/10

[b]Mass Effect 2[/b]
The game that many consider to be the best in the trilogy. At first, the beginning can be a bit jarring especially if you start this directly after completing Mass Effect 1. You're introduced to entirely new characters after spending many hours growing close to the characters from the previous game. Once you complete the prologue mission, you reunite with some old friends and meet some new ones too as you get back into things with another fantastic story. While it has the weakest beginning, it definitely as the strongest end. The [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler] mission is one of the best in the trilogy. This game also offers tons of new side content and new worlds to explore after a stressful mission. - 9.5/10

[b]Mass Effect 3[/b]
What I consider to be the most over hated, mainly because of the ending (which we'll talk about in a second). This game ties together everything you've experienced from the previous two games. And features so much side content that I didn't bother doing any of it because it felt like too much (and to be honest I only cared about the main story at this point). It starts out with high stakes and sets the tone immediately of a mission with little hope of success. As you progress you learn more and more about was is actually going on and how to stop the main threat of the trilogy. The final mission is one of the best in the series...until a certain point. Everything else about this game is amazing, but here is where everyone's gripes lie. The ending. This game has multiple endings that you can choose from, depending on choices you made over the course of the trilogy. However, some of the endings leave you feeling a bit unsatisfied by the end. They also added some unnecessary details at the last minute that I felt deterred a bit from what the game was initially about. I believe it should've had one ending, and one in particular that I won't say for spoiler purposes. Regardless, I don't think the somewhat lackluster ending is a reason not to play this game. Still amazing, start to (almost) finish. - 9/10

Overall, one of my personal favorite game trilogies of all time that fans of science fiction should give a try.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a complete package that puts you into an intriguing and creative universe, which is pretty multifaceted and full of important choices to make. You are in for an awesome ride and will definitely have an exciting experience ahead of you. 

Now let's talk about what makes the franchise so awesome. The choices you have to make, the character building and the world you are thrown into. This is a true RPG, so playing as Shepard will let you decide on your own, what kind of person you want to be. Want to be a self centered, bad mannered and sneaky character? No problem. Want to be a kind, well mannered and courteous character? Also no problem. The possibilities are nearly endless but keep in mind that every path you choose, will have big consequences for yourself and even whole planets. Some of these consequences will also be very far reaching, so that a decision you took in the first Mass Effect will also have an impact in the last entry of the trilogy. 

The character writing is done very well and the crew of your starship will surely grow on you after a while. They have all different personality traits and interacting with their peculiarities is a big and very fun part of the experience. You can become their friends or foes and even begin a romance with them. They surely don't feel generic in any way. The worldbuilding and art style is top notch and is bursting with attention to detail. You will travel to vastly different planets which inhabitants will all have their own customs and manners. 

Another big role plays the combat. At the beginning, you can choose between different classes which will unlock different traits for the Commander. These will influence the gameplay in a lot of different ways, for example towards a more aggressive playstyle. Sadly, the weapon variety is rather limited and the shooting mechanics feel a little bit weak throughout all 3 titles. It's not unenjoyable by any means but there's a certain punch missing behind it. 

In revue, a great collection which offers a nice visual upgrade, better controls and a beautiful world that will suck you into itself. All the DLC are already included which is a pretty neat thing, also thanks to their high quality. Just buy it, you surely won't regret it. 

Have fun!

First, the complaints about having to run the game through Origin are outdated. The current EA app does still have to launch to play the game, which means that you will have to be online to play. This isn't a deal breaker for me - many modern games require an online connection to play - but it could definitely turn people off.

I've played this trilogy since the release of the OG Mass Effect - hundreds of hours across various platforms - and it is my favorite gaming experience of all time. The sci-fi world building is top notch, the voice acting is phenomenal, the gameplay - while wonky in the first game - is fun, and the relationships that you will build with your crew are among the best that video games have to offer. By the end of the trilogy, other story-focused RPGs will feel shallow in comparison.

The Legendary Edition on PC is the definitive way to play the trilogy with one important caveat. After you install this game, go to Nexus Mods and download ME3 Tweaks Mod Manager. Then install - at the very least - the Patch and Community Framework for ME1 and ME3 and the Unofficial Patch for ME2. These patches don't change the core experience of the trilogy, but they create an experience that is fuller and more coherent. There are some bugs in the base game that carried over from the Original Trilogy - and there are some that didn't exist in the OT that made it into the LE. The mod patches smooth those out and restore some cut content that polishes up what is already an incredible experience.
