It offers a substantial upgrade over the original trilogy in terms of visual improvements,this compilation also includes almost all single-player downloadable content that was originally released for each game.
The original game also received a significant amount of gameplay updates, which was done in order to modernize the experience and to remove inconsistencies with its sequels.

Patience is the key to unveil one of the best story in video game industry. Don't rush it ,don't skip dialogues and codex entries if you want the best experience. 

You can expect around 40 to 50 hours per game,so we're looking at 150-200 hours if you decide to go for achievements. Oh and if you decide to make a female Shepard and play again do it,because personally i think the female Shepard voice actor is so much better than his male counterpart. If you get in on sale ,thats a steal.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a remaster of the original Mass Effect games and their DLC, which include visual enhancements, technical improvements and gameplay ajustments.
You play as Commander Shepard on a routine mission to recover an ancient artifact. During this misson Shepard is attacked by geth, a synthetic alien race, lead by Saren Arterius, a rogue turian Spectre. Shepard now must investigate why Saren betrayed the council and stop his plans.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]ME1, ME2 and ME3[/b] - Awesome story with incredible characters.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Great world building.
[*][b]ME1, ME2 and ME3[/b] - Choices have consequences for the overall story.
[*][b]ME1, ME2 and ME3[/b] - Improved textures and lighting, though much more sublte in the last 2 games.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Improved HUD.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Improved Mako handling and physics.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Any class can use any weapon.
[*][b]ME2[/b] - Combat is fun and fast-paced. Huge improvement from ME1.
[*][b]ME2[/b] - Overlord DLC is fantastic.
[*][b]ME3[/b] -  Combat is the best in the entire trilogy.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - Citadel DLC is one of the best DLCs I ever played.
[*][b]ME1, ME2 and ME3[/b] - Great soundtrack.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]ME1, ME2 and ME3[/b] - Some areas are poorly optimized which cause big fps drops.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Many bugs like black screens during loading, the character going a different direction than the camera is pointing (also present in ME2) and the Mako getting stuck and dying out of nowhere.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Combat is clunky and outdated.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Planet exploration is not very fun.
[*][b]ME1[/b] - Hacking minigame isn't fun.
[*][b]ME2[/b] - Ocasional crashing when messing with abilities in the HUD.
[*][b]ME2[/b] - Resource gathering is boring.
[*][b]ME2[/b] - Classes are restricted to certain weapons, though you can choose another weapon to carry later in the game.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - The ending is truly godawful and makes no sense. Nearly ruins the entire franchise.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - Some enemies go out of bounds when using certain abilities and survive which makes killing them hard and might force you to reload the save.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - Some enemies don't get up after being knocked down.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - Shepard's audio fades during certain missions.
[*][b]ME3[/b] - Javik's Vengeful Ancient rank skill titles don't match their description.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Mass Effect Legendary Edition has many improvements to graphics and gameplay and each game improves upon the last. Despite ME3's terrible ending, the tilogy still has amazing stories and many interesting characters that make these games some of the best in all of gaming.

This game is an easy 11/10 for me. They just don't make games like this anymore. Narratively, it's outstanding, and while the core idea might seem as silly as the typical 'hero's journey' where you're an all-powerful super soldier, the atmosphere, music, and lore that BioWare has crafted make it an unparalleled experience. The ending of the third game was a bit underwhelming, but they rectified it with a DLC, so no hard feelings there.

The game can be a bit buggy at times, particularly if you're an achievement hunter aiming to conquer it on insanity mode. This difficulty level feels somewhat unfair; enemies turn into bullet sponges, and they'll take you down even when you're in cover. And let's not forget those moments when the camera goes haywire due to nearby explosions... Overall, it's a fantastic experience, but I might think twice before tackling insanity mode again.

Definitely recommended, especially if you can snag it for 10 euros during a sale.

Okay, I'm going to start this review off with some information real quick. I never played Mass Effect back when it was still current. I still didn't until recently because it was two things I thought I disliked. Third-person shooter, and sci-fi space-y stuff. Those are two things I generally just dislike... however, when I started to play this game, I quickly realised I made a massive mistake. That mistake being that I didn't play these games sooner. Holy fuck, these games are the best games I've played in years. Almost a decade, they are that good.

Here are some pros:
- The combat across all three games is definitely pretty good. I don't think it really has many downfalls. Even if it does, they are downfalls of the games being as old as they are. I found the combat to be satisfying and fun across all three games.
- The sound design is really good, I didn't notice any moments where I really felt the sound was lacking or too much at any point. Generally, it's pretty damn good.
- This is kind of an extension of the "sound design" point, but for the most part... holy crap the voice acting in all three games is good. The characters sounded believable, and they conveyed the emotions they were meant to convey... except for ONE MAJOR EXCEPTION. 
- The characters... oh, the characters. Holy shit, this is some of the best character writing I've witnessed in a long time. Possibly just my opinion, but I LOVE the character writing in all three games. I sympathised with characters when I was meant to sympathise with them, I felt sad when bad things happened to people I cared about, I felt angry when characters did awful things, I genuinely fell for the romance partner I picked in real life a little bit (I chose Tali'Zorah. Tali'Zorah supremacy gang), I genuinely cared for the characters that cared for me... it's just so fucking masterfully done. The characters FEEL like real people, and that's harder to do than you'd think it is.
- The writing in general I'd say is really damn good, the story is interesting and engaging, the character motivations, desires, actions and all that are all believable and make sense. I genuinely think this is some of the best story writing in a game I've played in a while.
- This could be a con depending on how you swing, but this game PULLS NO PUNCHES. You can legitimately get people killed if you don't do things right... even your squad mates. Granted, it's only at certain, specific spots throughout the games, but you genuinely have to be worried about killing people you care about. I was so invested into these characters that I used a walkthrough to MAKE ABSOLUTELY SURE everyone survived, and I succeeded. I didn't want to see anyone die. For example, in Mass Effect 3, in order to get the best ending where everyone survives, you are REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE ENTIRE GAME to make sure everyone gets out alive. Your actions have consequences. Pick them carefully.
- The abilities of the characters made complete sense and were very useful in combat. You can swap your ammo types to do more damage against synthetic enemies, or organic enemies, or slow enemies down, or any wide variety of other things. You also have lots of abilities to play with like combat drones, slowing down time, lifting enemies helplessly up into the air... there's a lot of stuff to play with in these games, and I loved it all.
- The missions were never boring, honestly. While I was playing I never found myself wishing a mission was over, they were fun and they ended before they had a chance to get boring, which is always a good thing.
- The weapon selection across all three games is pretty good, I didn't really have a complaint about that at all. There was a weapon for every play style I could've thought of, and that's a good thing.

Here are some cons:
- Mentioned it before in the "pros" section, but honestly Male Shepard's voice actor is just not good. He just sounds like he's trying too hard to seem cool, and he sounds completely emotionless. Female Shepard's voice is so, so much better, but then you're unable to romance some characters. Characters DO have preferences in this game!
- They are all old games, so they come with their "old game problems". The movement engine in all three games is a bit wonky and janky. I found myself getting annoyed with the movement engine in ME3 every once in a while because sometimes I'll be sprinting past a wall and Shepard will just magnetise to it and take cover on it, getting me shot a few times in the process.
- There are some bad bugs that STILL exist in these games to this day. There's a few bugs in ME3 where some missions will just straight-up break and be impossible to complete if you do certain things. None of the missions that break in this way are main story missions or missions that are required to get the best ending, but it's still pretty annoying that some of the missions are straight-up impossible to complete if you do certain things that a player might just do absentmindedly.
- I had this consistent problem across all three games with the dialogue, it's a similar issue that goes on with Fallout 4. What some dialogue options are labelled as feels completely different to what you end up saying. You might select an option for Shepard to say that seems like a decent thing to say, then he/she suddenly snips at the character in a way you didn't expect. Like... what? I was just trying to tell the character I'm talking to that we don't have time to ask this other character questions, I wasn't trying to be sarcastic and rude! There were genuinely a few times where I reloaded a save because I felt annoyed with the dialogue choice I made that ended up not being what I thought it would be.
- I wouldn't say this is an objectively bad thing, but Mass Effect 3 took itself a lot less seriously than the previous two games did. There were constantly jokes and quips going on in Mass Effect 3. A lot of it was funny, but there genuinely were moments where I was like "Okay, stop. I'm trying to take this game seriously, and you're making it difficult". It might be something you actually LIKE, but I personally thought the game was at its best when it was serious and dark.
- This is a minor gripe, but it felt like Mass Effect 3 removed some things that were actually good in the previous games. For example, In the first two Mass Effect games, when you were doing a mission, it would give you updated information in your mission log about what you were doing, and what you need to do next in the mission. In Mass Effect 3, that's COMPLETELY gone. The only information you get is the overarching synopsis of the mission, that's it. Figure out what you have to do next yourself. What if you took a break from the game for a few weeks and now don't remember what it is you were doing? Too bad, you'll have to look up a walkthrough to see where you have to go next! It's genuinely pretty annoying.
- The U.I is honestly pretty horrid. Especially the combat U.I. In order to switch weapons, you have to hold a certain button, move your mouse down to the "weapons" section, click the weapon you want to use, and then let go of that button. It's really just not good at all.

TL;DR: The Mass Effect series is a series I skipped for a while for various reasons, and after playing the games included in this collection... I regret having skipped it for so long. I now understand why this series is a cult classic and I highly recommend anyone who's at least vaguely interested in the series to try it. You may be pleasantly surprised. All three games are absolutely fucking fantastic - and while they have their issues at times - I think these three games are some of the best games I've played in a good few years. I'm literally trying to find one of those little statues of Tali'Zorah as I write this because I love her character so much, best character I've seen in a video game in years. Buy these games, I think you'd like them.

They're my friends.

OK, they're not really my friends; claiming to be buddies with imaginary characters is a little too geeky even for me. The Mass Effect series is not without its flaws, and some are truly Reaper-sized. But it has gripped me like nothing else in the history of video games, and video games and I go back a pretty long way (but I'll never be too old for video games)!

The Mass Effect universe is that rare thing—a fully-realized science fiction game setting that stands up to the likes of Star Trek or Star Wars. The universe in which the games take place has a rich and complex backstory, and even better, it's not a rich and complex back story that the player has to have info-dumped into his head. This isn't The Old Republic, where you have to read thousands of awful Kevin J. Anderson "Extended Universe" novels and have a working knowledge of the seven prime forms of lightsaber combat to get the most out of the game.

There's depth in the backstory, but it's not the kind of depth that ever compelled me to memorize the game's codex entries. (Do you really need to know that the "First Contact War" between humans and Turians started because humans activated a mass relay in violation of council law and that the war culminated in the siege of Shanxi? No. It's wonderful flavor, but it's not mandatory knowledge.) The world is alive and compellingly real just through dialogue and character actions, without needing endless narration. The first game's opening title crawl essentially says, "This is the future and aliens are real and you are a space soldier. Go." That's enough.

Instead of a galactic civics lesson, Mass Effect focuses on a human, the forever-first-nameless Commander Shepard, and her fight against the ancient Reapers, an enemy that aims to rid the galaxy of advanced sentient life for a whole bunch of really complicated reasons. That fight is the central focus of all three games, though Shepard's path from soldier to savior twists and turns and doubles back on itself like a demented snake.

[h1] A Strange Series [/h1]

This is by far the longest review for a steam product I can give (it's 3 games worth of content), and I feel like i need to give some background. I grew up with BioWare games, I started with Dragon Age Origins back in 2009 and have played a good deal of their catalog, I've gone through Baldur's Gate 1 and 2, Kotor and SW:TOR, played through all the dragon age games and their dlc, went through their first original title in Jade Empire. However Mass Effect has been a blind spot for me, I've played 2 quite a bit growing up, but never really touched 1 or 3 at all prior to this playthrough. My opinion on the series due to that is a bit different from those that did go through it at the time of release and grew up with it. In this review I'm gonna be singing the games up and saying some contentious things, I don't think it's the best thing the studio has made, but before I get to that I will say I do overall recommend the series and this game. It's by far the most ambitious thing BioWare has ever done, but with ambition comes varying degrees of quality.

Also should mention for this playthrough I went with a Paragon Male Shepard, class was Vanguard
[h2] General Praise and Criticisms [/h2]

First bit of praise I can give is that there is no other game series like this. Mass Effect as a universe is one of the most unique video game settings out there and for the most part that setting feels huge and unique. Every alien race you come across has something going on and especially in Mass Effect 1 the focus that is given to them makes it genuinely immersive and interesting to learn about all these different races, their cultures, attitudes toward humans and why they hold them, and the political backdrop the galaxy is in when Shepard comes into play. However, I do think they dropped the ball a bit on the setting with the focus humanity takes from Mass Effect 2 onwards, it feels like from that point on the other races only exist to stall and thwart humanity when in the first game it comes off as much more complex than that. The villains also just get worse with every entry. Saren was a great villain, the collectors were bland and harbinger is an annoying joke, and the Reapers went from being a cosmic horror threat to a more powerful version of the Borg in TNG. I will not even mention Kai Leng other than to say yeah.....he's really bad.

Another bit of praise i can give is that the characters throughout the series are fantastically written. Garrus and Mordin are probably the best written characters Bioware has ever made and for the most part every other character is well written. I did not even mind Kaiden or Jacob like a lot people seem to. They're a bit generic, but they both still have something going on and provide good worldbuilding for humanity.

[h2] Mass Effect 1 [/h2] (8.5/10)

This is by far my favorite entry in the series, it is a great introduction to the universe and it feels the most grand. The writing is a good mix of serious sci-fi and humorous interactions between characters, and the gameplay is more rooted in rpg gameplay compared to the rest of the series, but the combat has aged the worst, and other than changing the aiming mechanics and the mako (which i do like, bite me), the remaster does little to update the moment to moment gameplay, it just makes it easier. If you can look past some aged mechanics though it's one of the best games BioWare has ever made. It's atmospheric, immersive, and grounded in a way the other games aren't which makes it stand out even among other rpgs besides it sequels.

[h2] Mass Effect 2 [/h2] (7/10)

This is a hard one to review. I've never played a game that has has so much stellar content and so much bad content. I will say that overall it is still very much worth playing with some caveats. The gameplay is improved and the removal of some of the rpg mechanics went ok in my book (minus how they made certain classes like vanguard underpowered cause not enough people choose that class i guess), and like with the first game the cast of characters is still great, I would actually say the cast in 2 is the best in the series which is why it has the reputation it has. The focus on the game is on the casts loyalty and recruitment missions, which are all either great or a bit mid (jack and samara's missions were eh, and some of the recruitment missions themselves are a bit repetitive). The problem comes in with the main story, it doesn't make sense, doesn't move the plot forward and a lot of the missions are just boring shooting galleries that take way too long to complete. At least there's only 4 main missions but each one is a slog other than the final mission which is actually really good. The Illusive Man on the surface is pretty interesting, but if you think about him for more than 5 minutes his knowledge of the collectors and how things play out is ridiculous. I won't say hes a totally bad character, his motivations make sense and he's compelling, just a bit unbelievable at times how he's able to predict how everything goes. The worst part about this game is the grinding for the final mission, you gotta do every loyalty mission and upgrade every part of the ship which you do by going to different planets and scanning for resources and shooting probes. It's fun for the first hour sure, and the music is chill, but for like 5 or 6 hours, it's just boring and slows the game down to a halt.

[h2] Mass Effect 3 [/h2] (5.5/10)

I can't say much about this game. It's just a chore sometimes. Every good part of the game narratively owes it's success to the first game, and it still messes things up, it turns the geth who are a hivemind who want to remain a hivemind machines that want individuality, which spits in the face of what Legion in ME2 has to say, it's just a bad retcon that turns a genuinely unique take on ai and turns them into Commander Data. The genophage plot was the peak of the game, and all the dlc is good which is why i added an extra half point but the majority of the game doesn't even feel like it has any rpg elements in it anymore, those two plots i brought up, yeah they're the only times you get to make any meaningful choices. Companions are still good but theres very little focus on them at all other than half-baked callbacks. The gameplay is pretty good, but it overstays it's welcome, I said 4 missions on ME2 were bloated, every mission in 3 you take out at least 150-200 enemies at once, and some of them take place in what i can only assume were multiplayer maps. That scanning minigame, it's worse here if you want to get the "good" ending. I'm complaining a lot about this game, but i still came back and kept playing so it's doing something right, i just can't put my finger on it. Overall it does close some plots and character arcs well, but the first two games are so above and beyond better that it just isn't worth playing even as just a run of the mill third person shooter unless you have played the other games, which isn't something i'd say about 2 which can be played and enjoyed standalone, and the finale is just anticlimactic given everything that led up to that point.

[h2] Final thoughts [/h2]

Overall I think Mass Effect is a mess, at times an absolute masterpiece in video game storytelling but still a mess. The best indicator of a good rpg is if after beating it you could see yourself playing it again, and I'll say I will eventually. It does too much right to not justify another playthrough and even though it got frustrating near the end, The good outweighs the bad with the series. The setting is great, the characters are great, most of the writing is great and it just has that BioWare charm to it. I would say with a good discount it's worth anyone's time. Just don't expect the uber AAA masterpiece people have built it up as and you'll have a good time overall.

I've been a fan of the Mass Effect trilogy for 6 or 7 years now; played through it multiple times back on the PS3 and I like it even more on PC.

There are a number of improvements over the original games; all the DLC is included (minus Pinnacle Station, but that wasn't in the PS3 version either), lot's of QoL additions, many bug-fixes,, drastically improved graphics, and the Infiltrator is an actually usable class in the first game now. It's also worth mentioning that it runs extremely well on Linux; I never had any frame drops or stuttering.

There are still flaws of course,  It still has a decent amount of bugs, very few graphics options,  bloom that seems to be hard-coded in, and some more small things that I can't really be bothered to list. [strike]However, the biggest issue is the EA App. In a nutshell it breaks achievements in the 2nd and 3rd games; unless you set it to offline mode.[/strike] If it loses connection mid-mission it may prevent you from getting said mission's achievement unless you restart it. It happened to me right at the end of the Citadel DLC.

EA App and Legendary Edition aside, the actual games are truly amazing. Each of them are very different from the others in terms of gameplay. Mass Effect is very much a 2000's BioWare RPG. Mass Effect 2 is still an RPG, but with more action-adventure elements and a less comprehensive skill tree.  Mass Effect 3 is basically an action adventure game with skill points; not in a bad way though.

The overall story throughout the trilogy is solid and they all mesh very well together and they're well written. My only real complaint about the story is of that most of the (once) DLCs' don't really fit too well. they're just kinda thrown in there. Don't get me wrong, they're still good, they just stick out.

Despite it's flaws, Mass Effect :Legendary Edition is very good, and I highly recommend it.

The Mass Effect Trilogy is my all time favorite video game experience. Everything from the lore, to character development, to the rich and engaging story telling, has been meticulously crafted by an amazingly talented group of people at Bioware. To me, gaming doesn't get better than this. It's rare that a game provokes meaningful thought, or connects you so deeply with a cast of characters. It's done here in a way that cannot be described as anything but masterful. 

The gameplay evolved significantly over the course of the trilogy, and you can still feel the differences between ME1/ME2/ME3 here in the legendary edition. However, the combat has been improved for all games, especially ME1. The improved models and textures are also something to behold, so incredibly improved from the original. It definitely helped with the immersion, as does ultrawide support. Also, the addition of all DLC with this package is the icing on the cake. It was almost surreal going back through and experiencing things I never had the chance to with the originals, it was like playing it for the first time all over again.

The game does have its issues, even still to this day in the legendary edition. But those small issues are so easy overlooked by the ambition and execution of this game. If you like story driven or sci-fi games, this is truly an unmissable experience in gaming. I've sunk over 300 hours into this on my first playthrough, and by the end I just wanted to go back and experience it all over again. Just go buy it, it's worth every penny.

Originally played the trilogy as they released on Xbox and adore them. This is my first time playing through the trilogy again with the Legendary Edition.

My favourite was ME1 in terms of the story, but mechanically its the most clunky and dated. Each subsequent game improves on gameplay until, by the third, it is really mechanically solid.

Unlike most people, ME2 was my least favourite of the 3. Mostly because it just feels like a side story that ignored nearly everything from the first game. Playing the games back to back makes the story shift much easier to stomach. For that reason I saw ME2 much more positively this time around.

I really enjoyed ME3, even at launch and was one of the few people that didn't mind the way that it ended. I feel much the same way, perhaps even more positive about it with some distance since my first play through.

This is a phenomenal trilogy of games (I recommend skipping ME:Andromeda), made better with the Legendary Edition. This is an easy recommendation.

I don't have high hopes of ME5 but playing through this again has really made me hyped for it. One can only hope!

Got this on sale as I've heard many good things about it.
Controls are janky though, with a very low FOV.
Stuff like automatically getting into cover are quickly getting frustrating.

I assume this was acceptable on console with controllers, but on pc using kb/m the game doesn't feel nice to run around or shoot.

Since the reviews are good and people like the IP, there must be a good game hidden behind those, but I'm not going to get used to those controls just for the sake of having a good story. I'd rather watch a Let's Play instead.

The game isn't perfect, I would lie if I said it was, but it is definitely an experience you won't find anywhere else. 
The best of Mass Effect 1 is the scale of the universe. Although the game is dated, it still holds up fine, especially when looking at the citadel, my absolute favorite place in the first game. The characters feel a little shallow in the first game, but you can see the potential of them. 
Mass Effect 2 fleshes those characters out a lot more, and gives you a lot more to love. The environments feel a bit more enclosed and don't feel as grand. There are still plenty of nice and detailed places to visit though, and the ending of this game is the best one in the series in my opinion. 
Mass Effect 3 gave me everything I wanted out of the characters I learned to love. The interactions with them are the absolute best part of this game, hands down. The environments feel more open again, more like they did in ME1. The DLC is really good, and feels like a breath of fresh air. It would have been my favorite out of the three, if not for the ending. It felt lackluster and detached and was not up to par with the quality of the rest of the game. 

It is however an amazing game, and I can't help but miss the characters that I spent al those hours with. None of three games are bad, and everyone should play this game. There is just so much to love.

It has been a long time since I last played Mass Effect - 3 came out at the tail end of high school for me and it was a huge deal in a lot of ways.

Now with the benefit of ten years behind me, I can safely say that all those fond memories were not *entirely* a product of some big new RPG on the scene but created with the help of a setting and system that by and large really doesn't have a good analogue to modern games.  While a lot can be said about 'choices' and 'consequences' that ULTIMATELY don't matter too much, there hasn't been anything quite like Mass Effect released that drags some of these decisions out quite a ways and making them feel not entirely like a case of planting 'member berries for future harvest.

The Legendary Edition changes are, by and large, positive. I think that the balance of ME1 in particular runs into a strange issue of just how lightning fast it is to level up and max out abilities and get all kinds of sweet gear which can trivialize encounters but 2 and 3 still manage to maintain pace well enough. There isn't really a graphical overhaul to speak of - just updates that bring the first two games more in line with the style of 3 - and sadly the multiplayer component (which was genuinely a blast) is not present here.  I would argue that the games are a little easier due to some rebalancing but Hardcore and Insanity remain plenty lethal.

Overall LE is well worth the money on sale for nothing if not a consolidated experience but it still has plenty going for it all the same.

Mass Effect has always been more than just a game for me. It has been a window in time. A window to my carefree childhood days.

It was one of the first games I had ever played. The characters felt memorable and alive with their own little quirks. The story felt compelling and threaded together wonderfully over the series to lead up to a grand finale. There was one little agony however. For a certain reason, I never got to finish it. That gnawed at me for years, until, like everything else in life, that memory got lost in time. 

Fast forward 10 years and I am presented with the "Legendary Edition". Those repressed and forgotten memories from my early childhood got unearthed. I wanted to travel the stars again. Liara, Ashley, Garrus, Tali, Joker and the rest of the Normandy crew over the entire saga -- I wanted to meet them again. I wanted to go adventuring with them again, as a band of swashbuckling intergalactic space knights. 

I wanted to look them in the eye and ask, "Do you remember me my friends? It has been so long, yet I have not forgotten you." 

This game helped me go back in time to my childhood and finish an unfinished tale. I won't spoil it for you but I did what the game might call the "perfect ending" and even then, the ending felt poignant and made me keep wanting for more.

Thank You BioWare for coming up with this timeless classic. I shall cherish it forever. And keep hoping that one day I might get to see all of them again. To see the Normandy soar through the galaxies. To see Commander Shepard again! 

Till then, Au Revoir!

I knew next to nothing about the Mass Effect trilogy before going into it. I wasn't expecting anything too crazy, just a space RPG.

What I got was one of the best stories I've ever experienced in a videogame. Mass Effect tells a story of galactic scale, yet never fails to focus on the individuals that move the story forward. You will grow attached to the cast of characters that inhabit the galaxy. That's not to say the galaxy itself is underdeveloped, though. There's worldbuilding galore and codex entries for you to peruse as you make your way through the games. A galaxy filled with life needs to be filled, well, with life. There are so many societies that exist in the universe and although you only meet a fraction of them, the ones you do paint a picture of a living, breathing, interstellar world, filled with stories waiting for you to play your role in. 

Mass Effect is an incredible tale in a fascinating setting. If you're a fan of sci-fi and looking for an enticing plot, then you will love it.

This is an update to my previous review as of August 19th, 2023. In 24 hours and 14 minutes, it will be 2024.
I will leave my previous review as is, and I'll add the update in a separate segment:

***Previous Review***
My goodness, this game is not how I remembered it in my teen years:

Now that I'm playing this on mouse and keyboard, I've noticed that Mass Effect 1 is incredibly easier than it should be, even on higher difficulty due to aiming the cursor with a mouse and the fact that there's infinite ammo... I could've sworn that the writing was a bit more cohesive and absent from plot holes. But, it left an impression where the principles to defeat a great evil wasn't strewn together well, and important characters who could've raised awareness had conflicting motives (either that, or they weren't cut out for their job as a galactic counselor).

Despite these set-backs, I really find Turians--and on especially rare occasions, Quarians--to be kinda attractive. The majority of these characters are very quirky and lack the depth // narrative that I was hoping to expect from Bioware. Nonetheless, my nostalgia reigns supreme and I can't stop expressing excessive sympathy and attention towards them.

My biggest complaint is the gameplay for keyboard and mouse:
It feels that Mass Effect 2 and 3 puts the player at a major disadvantage when the game recognizes that they're not using a controller. The mini-games to hack terminals are noticeably more punishing unless the player uses a controller, and the combat clearly wasn't designed for mouse and keyboard.

It's strange for me to say this, but I believe that using a controller (PS4 controller in my case) makes the game feel comfortable and more enjoyable. It's truly such a shame that so much effort for the Legendary Edition wasn't adequate for the mouse and keyboard experience (unless you're playing ME1, then it's towards the player's favor).

In conclusion, the game simply didn't age well, but I'm still a sucker for Garrus Vakarian.

-

***Recent Review***
I think Mass Effect's biggest issue as a whole is its indecisive identity between a first-person shooter and an RPG (the kind where looking at numbers matter). Mass Effect does a terrible job reminding you that numbers matter. Because, the developers chose to hide those numbers from the player in the first place.

I have the impression that decisions about how characters in one's party greatly impact combat and conversations // relationships. However, it simply doesn't!
At the end of the day, the RPG elements of what a character can do for the player, and their involvement in the story is merely for flavor. No depth or actual impact of affecting combat and conversations. 

Garrus, for example, is a good boy who tried his best to do what's right, but got fed up with obligations, rules and authority. So, he went just a teensie little renegade to accomplish what's legitimately right; I like it! I love it! I want MORE of it!
However, he's terrible at fending off enemies with barriers and armor (which are the norm towards mid-game), and there's nothing I can do to change that.

Ultimately, the game feels like I was playing two different kinds of games that weren't fully meshed together. Between a TV show where the storytelling was prioritized, and a first-person shooter that didn't present the RPG elements to the player with impact.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition از آن دست بازی‌هایی است که خیلی راحت می‌توان تجربه آن را به همه پیشنهاد کرد. حجم فوق العاده محتوا، بهبود‌هایی که اکثرا در راستای بهتر کردن بازی بوده‌اند و همه موارد دیگری که مفصل در موردشان صحبت کردیم، این مجموعه را به تجربه‌ای ارزشمند تبدیل می‌کنند که می‌توان برای مدت زمان طولانی غرق داستان درجه یکش شد و از بازی کردنش لذت زیادی برد. پس اگر کمی به بازی‌های اکشن نقش آفرینی علاقه دارید، زمان آن فرا رسیده تا یک بار دیگر سوار نرماندی عزیز شوید، پای صحبت‌های جوکر و بقیه شخصیت‌های دوست‌داشتنی بازی بنشینید، دوشادوش گاروس و سایرین بجنگید، شپرد را به همان روش و هویتی که دوست دارید شکل بدهید، غرق موسیقی‌های فوق العاده بازی شوید و از یک سفر فضایی فوق العاده که لذتش تا مدت‌ها زیر زبان‌تان خواهد ماند، لذت ببرید. Mass Effect Legendary Edition، قطعا بهترین راه برای تجربه سه گانه مس افکت است که شاید تا مدت‌ها، مثل و مانندش را در دنیای بازی‌ها نبینیم.

This game has completely tanked my opinion of bioware. Mass Effect 2 is to the ME series, what Dark Souls 2 is to the DS series. 
Here are a few of the notes that I made while playing this game:
In the 2 years while Shepard was dead they forgot how to make weapons that don't require you to pick up ammunition. They also forgot what grenades are.
Everything is dumbed down significantly, feels like a console game. You level up way less often and to be hoenst it doesn't matter if you do. 2/3 of the skills you used to have are gone, all you have left is some sad little bare bones of a skill tree. Leveling up used to be fun.
You no longer get exp for killing every enemy, so the game doesn't mind spawning infinite enemies if it feels like it, like in the Garrus loyalty mission (and that's beside the fact that a lowly smuggler on the run from C Sec has a giant warehouse full of armed guards and infinite mechs). 
The AI was already really bad in the first game, but here it feels even worse. Your companions may as well not exist, because they'll stand in front of cover, get 3 shot and die. The entire reviving companions system is worse as well. At least before you could use it as many times as you wanted as well as heal them with a separate limited amount of medigel. 
You can never quicksave unless the game randomly feels like it, even if there are no enemies nearby, even if you're not in combat. Considering how long the battles are with many waves of enemies, getting 3 shot and restarting from the beginning is awful.
All combat is now wave based horde modes instead of the much better limited but well placed enemies in the first game. The game also tries to cheese you on every occasion, putting heavy guards with rockets everywhere it can.
Do any of the enemies suffer from limited ammunition? Of course not. But you do. Guess what I love the most in a mass effect game? Running around collecting a generic tube of ammo (same for all gun types, why did you even bother?) back and forth.
There is no longer any customisation of your weapons and armor, no mods. In the first game you could swap them out at any time depending on the situation. Now they just don't exist and they don't show you any stats of any weapons you have. 
Gun damage is awful, gun balance is awful, can no longer use all weapons like before unless you unlock 1 or 2 in a story mission.
Even the writing got worse. There's occasionally a spark of brilliance, but the way entire missions are written is just sh1t. The "Save Dr Kelso" mission is a prime example, where you wake up inside a locked medical room, where the button to release you on the other side, but look at this, there's randomly a convenient console right where you woke up which lets you, check this sh1t out, control and UNLIMITED amount of combat drones that spawn in the room that has the release button. You can't make this sh1t up. Either a r3tard wrote this or the devs think the players are r3tards. 
I have 2 more pages, but this is enough. What an awful game.

I was late to the Mass Effect train and had always wanted to see what the hype was about. I decided to let the re-launch be the time for me to create my version of Shepherd and run through all 3 games in order. I felt like the graphics and gameplay remained true to the original but was polished enough with RTX and modern graphics updates to provide some eye candy. The gameplay is great, the story is greater, and playing through the trilogy at least once should be a bucket list item for any gamer.

These games mean something to me beyond what I think I'll ever be able to describe properly in words alone. Sure, they're all around decent games with an amazing story and just as much wrong with it as there is right with it. The only way to really "get" it, I think, is to play through the trilogy. But if everyone got into media based on a "just trust me" approach, then we wouldn't find anything good. So let me tell you about my history with Mass Effect and what it means to me.

I first got into these games in 2017. I got a copy of the first game on from trading Team Fortress 2 items, for the equivalent of about five bucks. I fell in love with the universe it presented to me right away; I had never experienced a game story like this before, one that drew me in and gripped me with the characters, the details about the setting, the presentation and the music. Six years later, I see the flaws in it much more clearly, something not helped by Legendary Edition breaking some things or disrupting the presentation in its attempts to "modernize" these games. 3 is impacted the least in this regard, and the absence of the multiplayer in this release is also unfortunate, though not terribly significant in the long run due to it making the mechanics of that game slightly easier to control. But there is really nothing else like this out there, nothing that I've found. With this kind of science fiction aesthetic, detail in the world construction, wonderful characters and a grander narrative that will be a part of me for the rest of my life, even with the ending being what it is.

If you have the chance to not know anything about these games, and are ready to go in fresh, if you want to uncover a deep and thought out universe to fulfill you, then these games are a must. They aren't perfect, far from it. There's lots of problems with how they handle certain topics and the writing only gets more shoddy the further along you go, but none of that stops Mass Effect being greater than the sum of its parts. You will find characters you love, stories that you'll want to see through, and these games may help you think about the world, stories, and yourself in ways you never have before; they did for me. In that way, these imperfections are what make Mass Effect so wondrous. It's so very human in its construction, flaws and all, a time capsule of trends in gaming around its release and an escape to a time where things in the industry were less homogeneous, or at least an escape to a pretty damn good illusion of that. They have their rough edges; the games sometimes break in front of you,  the developer isn't what it used to be, the third party launcher stuff is annoying, and if you're like me, the ending will really hurt the first time, to the point that I don't feel the need to hide that behind a spoiler tag. You know it has a mixed ending, by now. But that changes nothing. These are my favorite games and story within games, and one of my favorite stories of all time. I do think you, whoever you are, would like it as well.

Not gonna lie: recommending Legendary Edition feels kinda icky because it fixes a lot of the issues EA's greed created, but the fact of the matter is - this is the most pain-free way to experience the trilogy. This is a complete no-brainer if you're buying the games for the first time, and even if you already have them - I'd consider this when the deep sale hits (it hits surprisingly often).

In terms of content on offer:

-ME1 feels like the amusing mix of a genuinely good game and a total showelware. The main quest is good and engaging and almost all side content is not. Like, «go to the same wasteland and into literally the exact same shed to kill some randoms» not. I’d recommend to finish the main quest, some companion quests, the Moon quest and Bring Down the Sky, and leave it at that. 7/10

-Replaying ME2 was one of those life's little tragedies when you realize that the game that you loved is not as cool as you remember it being. I remember it as an 10/10 game that always had something cool and interesting to say. Well, it still have all that, but the main story is filler, your companions barely talk to each other, many loyalty missions are over before you know it, and most importantly companions run out of things to say way too soon. Calibration is a meme for a reason, poor Garrus might as well be dead in the entire second half of the game. The good stuff is still really freaking cool. 8/10

-ME3 was the surprise of the year for me. I was ignoring it for a decade because of the ending stink, and it is exactly the game I remember ME2 being. Something epic and сhill-inducing is happening every hour, series-long conflicts have a satisfying resolutions, companions NEVER run out of something to say and have proper relationships between each other, what kind of sorcery is this? It was very fortunate that I waited a decade tho, because Bioware and most importantly the fans fixed the ending for me. Extended cut mixed with Audemus' Happy Ending Mod and Citadel Epilogue Mod made what was a total embarrassment right into one of those «you just stuck the landing» homerun endings. Mass Effect 3 was totally saved in the editing room; it fits like a glove. 9/10

Graphics

Beautiful: The remastered visuals bring a stunning new lease of life to the beloved trilogy. With updated textures and lighting, the game looks modern while still maintaining its original aesthetic charm.
Gameplay

Good: Engaging and smooth. The Legendary Edition fine-tunes the gameplay mechanics of the original series, providing a more cohesive experience across all three games.
Audio

Very good: The audio in Mass Effect Legendary Edition truly enriches the immersive experience with a compelling score and high-quality sound design.
Audience

Kids, Teens, Adults, Grandma: A wide-ranging appeal, with content suitable for a diverse audience, although younger kids may find it complex.
PC Requirements

Decent: The game is well-optimized and should run smoothly on modern PCs without requiring high-end hardware.
Difficulty

Easy on lower difficulty and Challenging on higher difficulty: Accessible for newcomers on lower settings, while still providing a solid challenge for veterans on higher difficulties.
Grind

Isn't necessary to progress: The game offers a balanced pace without the need for excessive grinding to move forward.
Story

Amazing: A rich, deep narrative that offers an engaging and emotionally compelling sci-fi experience, remembered as one of the best stories in gaming.
Game Time

Average: Provides a substantial single-player experience that should keep players entertained for a decent amount of time.
Price

Worth the price: The collection offers tremendous value, combining three epic games and most of their DLC into one package.
Bugs

Minor bugs: While largely polished, players may encounter the occasional, typically minor, bug.
Rating

10/10: A must-play remastered collection that successfully brings the epic space odyssey to the modern era, staying true to the classic experience.
In summary, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition excels in revitalizing an iconic series with careful enhancements to the visuals, gameplay, and overall accessibility. It remains faithful to the original trilogy, offering both new and returning players an opportunity to experience this groundbreaking sci-fi saga with modern refinements. Buy for at least 66% off, play the first game and uninstall, because this series made all the wrong adjustments in all the wrong ways. This remaster is a mixed bag, and if you like Mass Effect, you'll like this. But the series as a whole? I kept getting burned out halfway through the second game, and I could never figure out why, but I think I finally figured it out.

Before we even get to the graphics, first impressions. You got this on Steam, but EA's traffic is down, so get ready to play with two launchers running at the same time, and if you try and open it through the EA app, it just opens Steam right back. Annoying.
Graphics: A slight improvement over the version I saw on Xbox 360, but considering you can just get the original game for 5 dollars and get the MEUITM texture mod on Nexus for free, and it actually looks better than the version EA is charging for, that counts for nothing. It is nice to be able to play with a controller without modding controller support in too, though. Unfortunately, that is my favorite thing about this game. The first game is much improved with QoL changes like UI tweaks, a streamlined inventory system, and a slighty more agile Mako. All is well.

What's not to like in ME2?

First of all, they removed the loot and inventory management, and dialed up the difficulty a notch, and at first I thought this was a positive thing, because at Level 60, with all level 10 (or X) weapons and armor, the first game gets a little tedious in the late game, after multiple playthroughs. If you're getting multiple playthroughs out of me, something is working. So what did they replace it with? Well, it turns out, together, these two main changes are a disastrous combination. The skill tree and the degree to which you can improve your equipment are vastly simplified, leading encounters to feel stale and predictable. Now, on the standard difficulty setting, they've managed to hit this disgusting middle ground where here the combat is insultingly easy, but when you dial it up to Hardcore, it becomes literally impossible, so either way, right away I'm not having fun. I gave up on a mission where you have to destroy a bunch of giant mechs before they can destroy 20 crates. Why yes, that does sound like the worst level of all time, and it turns out it is, because on Hardcore, no matter who you pick or what you tell them to do, both of your squadmates quickly die, and then you empty literally every bullet you have into the nearest mech, including the heavy weapon, and you manage to take out most of his shields before he dices you into powder with two out of ten million minigun bullets flying at you.

Wait a minute, I hear you wonder. Bullets? Ammo? Why, didn't they carefully establish in the codex already that a little laser shaves off a little particle from a block of metal in your future space pistol, and you have theoretically infinite ammo, and all of your guns cool off in seconds because it's the year 2130 whatever? No, it turns out that years after the first game, technology has actually improved so much that we found it far more efficient to remove all ability for our guns to vent even 0.01% of heat by themselves, defying the laws of physics, and instead rely on magical thermal clips that instantly restore your weapons and work exactly the same way as bullets from a thousand years ago so we can retcon this to be more like Gears of War without any of the interesting weapon, enemy, or level design. Hey, if you just want to play through the story on easy mode and be totally unchallenged by the gameplay, that's your prerogative, but I'm falling asleep here.

Perhaps picking Infiltrator was a mistake, because not only is there no reward in any of the level design for sneaking around anywhere that I've seen, during a fight or otherwise, the cloak also feels like it was balanced for a multiplayer the game does not have, because it never seems to work half the time, and wears off in seconds. Oh, and maybe if you told me up front that the AI hacking doesn't even work until you've removed two thirds of their health bar, I would have picked something else, because maybe that would have helped me out in that terrible mission, but no.
You find different weapons and token upgrades, but they all feel the same, so you don't feel like you're making any progress.

They did what devs always do when they can't design a shooter, just gave the enemies another billion HP per difficulty level and changed nothing else. The fact that ammo didn't even need to be a thing, and is now part of the problem, makes it doubly hilarious. They took out inventory management, but then they replaced it with busywork when now you have to remember to open the stupid menu and put the stupid fire on your stupid gun at the beginning of every stupid firefight, but on Hardcore it made no tangible difference anyway. When you pour points into disruptor ammo and get it to level 3 of 4, put it on a gun designed to work against mechs with shields, and then it doesn't work on mechs with shields, that's an uninstall, bro. I honestly can't believe I avoided spoilers to ME3 for over a decade for this. I won't be seeing the Endingtron 3000 for myself.

I have almost 300 hours logged for the Steam version of Mass Effect Legendary Edition.  I have another 300-ish hours logged for the Xbox version and likely more than that for the original 360 games.  So, I have put 1000+ hours into the original games and remaster combined.  A quick game-by-game rundown:

-Mass Effect 1 is a masterclass in world building and my favorite of the 3.  There is no game I've played that gives me the same sense of wonder and amazement, like I am truly living in a hypothetical sci-fi future.  The world building and atmosphere are so good that they more than make up for any other flaw in the game for me.  The combat is more fluid with the Legendary Edition, but still has some jank to it.  It is a blend of 3rd person cover shooter with crpg DNA under the hood.  Honestly I really like the combat in ME1, but I understand why others do not.

-Mass Effect 2 is my least favorite, but many others have it at the top of their list.  It's kind of like saying cheese pizza is my least favorite pizza.  At the end of the day I'm still happily eating pizza.  The combat is streamlined and fluid, but at the cost of much of the rpg elements.  The atmosphere and cinematics in ME2 are much more polished compared to ME1 and the squadmates are given a lot of attention and characterization.  ME2 directly references your savegame from ME1, and the world state changes somewhat based on your ME1 choices.  The characters are the biggest highlight in this one.

-Mass Effect 3 is flawed, but amazing for what it is.  ME3 references your save data from both previous games and your choices in those games really affect how you experience this one.  The pacing can be rough at times and the story-telling can feel rushed and unpolished, but ultimately ME3 successfully completes the trilogy of games and does so in a way that really gives you a sense of agency throughout the journey.  Even though ME3 has some controversial elements, it also has some of the best moments in the trilogy.  The combat in ME3 is also a highlight.  It preserves the polished feel from ME2 and adds back some of the rpg feel from ME1.

All 3 games are pretty great on their own, but the collection of all 3 is greater than the sum of its parts.  ME Legendary Edition is worth its full price and even more worth it when you can find it on sale.

Note: The EA app is kind of annoying and can sometimes cause a headache here and there on the Steam Deck, but I haven't had any issues with it on my Windows PC.

I have nothing but the highest praise for the story told in the Mass Effect(ME) Trilogy, although the final endings in ME3 admittedly leaves much to be desired. The way that all three games melded almost seamlessly together to form a grandiose space opera makes the Legendary edition one of the best gaming experiences I had in recent times. 

The companion characters are all so memorable and fleshed out with each having a unique motivation and backstory, which you can gradually explore through multiple conversations and their side missions. Each alien species you encounter has their own history, culture and opinion of Humanity that you can slowly get a sense of as you travel around and complete the optional quests. 

Finally, some of the decisions that you make will directly affect whether a companion will survive into the future games and even the survival of entire alien species will depend on your whims and wishes. 

Still, that is not to say that these games do not have areas that performed poorly. The combat mechanics are quite lackluster, particularly for ME1, though by the time I play ME3 it has definitely improved considerably. Lots of the side quests also unfortunately fall into the common cliche of being generic fetch quests for the sake of padding game time. 

Overall, this game took me around 100 hours to complete all three games, all the DLCs and most of the side quests. Some of the choices I had to make and the dialogue between characters seriously tucked at my heartstrings. Spending so much time interacting with my companions have made me grown attached to them and it really was tough getting all the way to the end. 

This game is a must-play for all RPG lovers. Getting this game at 80% off in the 2023 Autumn sale was the best trade deal in the history of trade deals for me.

"Mass Effect Legendary Edition" isn't just a game; it's a masterpiece that has redefined my gaming experience. It's a phenomenal journey, allowing you to progress with the same beloved character from ME1 through ME3, crafting a personal and epic narrative.

The mechanics in ME2 and ME3 are particularly impressive, with ME3's shooting mechanics standing out. The gameplay is fluid, engaging, and evolves meaningfully across the series. Every decision, every battle feels impactful.

The story is the heart of the Mass Effect series. It's a rich, complex narrative woven through a breathtaking galaxy. The companions - Tali, Legion, Garrus, Wrex, Grunt, and others - are not just characters; they're friends with deep stories, making the adventure even more memorable.

Visually, the game is a feast for the eyes. The remastered graphics bring the universe to life in a way that's both awe-inspiring and authentic to the original experience.

If I had one wish, it would be for more exploration of the Protheans, an intriguing aspect of the lore that begs for deeper exploration.

In summary, "Mass Effect Legendary Edition" is a must-play for any gamer. It's a beautifully crafted love letter to the original series, maintaining all the elements that made us fall in love with the Mass Effect universe, while enhancing it in all the right ways.

When I first embarked on the journey within the 'Mass Effect Legendary Edition,' I was immediately struck by the controls, which seemed unconventional to my seasoned FPS player's instincts. This initial encounter served as a stark reminder of the game's roots in an earlier gaming era, slightly tempering my initial enthusiasm. 

However, as I delved deeper into the vast expanses of the 'Mass Effect' universe, my initial reservations were quickly overshadowed by the game's immersive qualities. The controls, which had initially seemed jarring, soon became intuitive, seamlessly integrating into the overall experience. This ease of adaptability is a testament to the game’s meticulously crafted design, which remains captivating and engaging, rivaling many contemporary titles despite its vintage.

The crowning achievement of the 'Mass Effect Legendary Edition' lies in its narrative. The storyline is a paradigm of video game storytelling, intricately weaving complex plots across a galaxy brimming with diverse species, cultures, and intricate histories. The depth and richness of the lore are truly breathtaking, inviting players to immerse themselves deeply in its intricacies. The character development is exceptional, with each companion bringing a distinct story, personality, and viewpoint, enriching the galactic journey with personal and impactful nuances.

The game's mission design deserves special mention for its astonishing diversity and non-repetitive nature. Each mission in the 'Mass Effect' universe is not just a task or an objective; it's an adventure in itself, filled with unique challenges and story elements that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging. The designers have done an extraordinary job of ensuring that each mission contributes meaningfully to the overarching narrative, while also standing out as a distinct and memorable experience. This diversity in mission design is one of the many aspects that makes the 'Mass Effect Legendary Edition' a masterpiece in the realm of interactive storytelling.

In addition, the comprehensive volume of content in the Legendary Edition is remarkable. Encompassing three full games and all their DLCs, this compilation offers an expansive and enriching experience that can captivate players for countless hours. The graphical enhancements, while preserving the original’s charm, bestow a rejuvenated look to this epic saga, broadening its appeal to both newcomers and returning aficionados.

I have mixed feelings about this remaster.  The game's compelling characters, extended continuity, masterful world building and gut-wrenching arcs make for a space opera that rivals the likes of Star Wars.  There's hours upon hours of video essay material that do a much better job than I at elaborating on why this trilogy is one of the best examples in gaming history of world building and character writing.  The modding scene for this game is more than alive and well: incredibly detailed overhaul mods, among others, continue to breathe new life into these games already brimming with expert world building.

Now that the mountain of praise is out of the way, the harsh reality is that this is an EA game.  You need EA's shady DRM to even run it, the same DRM that is essentially the exact same program as Origin was except this time, you have to sign new terms in which you agree to allow EA and its affiliates to sell all of your data including but not limited to your address and even your payment information.  You can't turn this feature off as now none of your games that run through EA app will run without an active internet connection.  The first two games in this trilogy do not even have an online component.  You will pay for this product and then only have access to it when EA says so.   Unless that sounds like a fair deal to you, I'd go ahead and just download it elsewhere (legally) (haha... unless)

There's also the matter of the obvious plot holes written into the final game of the trilogy.  I understand that the main voice of the series' writing left the company some time during the development of ME2, and the more you examine major plot points after ME2, the worse things get for this story.  [spoiler] The entirety of Mass Effect 1 and Mass Effect 2's Arrival DLC are completely pointless once you start ME3, and it's glaring.  The Reapers show that this entire time they had the ability to use conventional travel to reach the heart of Citadel space within just 2 years, and that a surprise attack was never necessary for them to gain a strong upper hand in the war immediately.  There was never any point to Sovereign, the conduit, or blowing the relay in ME2.  They were always able to show up whenever they wanted, apparently.  This breaks canon and also makes Shepard's sacrifice of over 300k people completely in vain. The Catalyst at the end of ME3 is also just a giant black hole in the plot.  It argues in circles and really has no sound reasoning for why the games played out the way that they did. [/spoiler] I could go on for another hour about these 2 glaring plot holes but it's far easier to just tell you not to think about them and enjoy what is otherwise an absolute gem of a sci-fi story.  

The truth is that ignorance is bliss, and this game provides an excellent illusion.  The world building and characters will pull you in and fully immerse you in a truly grand sci-fi experience.

I haven’t played any of the BioWare games, and the Mass Effect Legendary edition is my first experience. 

I always prefer open-word games more than non-open-word games. As non-open-word games usually provide a restricted choice of routes, which implies the player having little to no impact on the storyline's direction. The lack of real choice in many of those games kinda put me off in a way that I know the world of the game is not going to change anyway. My gameplay, my investment in the world, and my choices in that game are often meaningless. The word just demonstrates no respect for my decisions, and it resembles an artificially tailored game rather than a virtual other-world.   

I am glad that I am wrong. Linear games are often JRPGs and JRPGs-like games in my earlier experience, and I was misled to think that all linear games are like JRPGs, in which players follow a pre-determined path and the game does not acknowledge the decisions of the players. This creates an impression for me that all linear games are as restrictive as that. Unexpectedly, there are linear games, that respect players' decisions, and allow some degree of freedom for the player to decide the route they would like to take, the friends they would like to make, and most importantly, the fate of the world. Mass Effect trilogy is one of those examples.   

I bought this game when it was on sale, hoping to get some space RPGs before the release of Starfield. Just expecting an Okay-ish game. It is not, and it is in fact, a masterpiece.  

The companions are all unique in their own ways. Their questlines are deep enough. The world is linear yet not confined. The player enjoys the autonomy to explore and do whatever they wish to do.  

There are some flaws. The combat of the first game feels kind of outdated. And the ending of the trilogy feels unrealistic and childish. It gave me the impression that this is not the intended ending originally planned by the developers, but they ran out of ideas to end the storyline properly, so they just threw this to the player.  

But all things considered, I would still very much regard this game as a masterpiece. The freedom of choice is just so prevalent in this game, and it is so hard not to like it.  

By the way, the achievement of this game is broken (garbage EA launcher). It is something that you might need to bear in mind if your gaming motivation is achievement-oriented. The are ways to work around it (kinda) but you need to do some work. Keep it in mind that the achievement system of this game is just not going to work without a little bit of tinkering.

[h2] A must-play for anyone who loves Sci-Fi, RPG's, or a compelling story with amazing characters. Three genre-defining games rolled into a package and sold for the price of one game, sometimes less. [/h2]

[i] (TLDR at the bottom) [/i]


Now, when i say "genre-defining" that doesn't always mean in a good way. (we will get to that at the end)

[h3] Science Fiction, as Told by Modern Man [/h3]

  First off, I had never played Mass Effect 1 until I bought this game and played it all the way through (twice). What an amazing sci-fi experience. I had just watched through Star Trek: The Next Generation for the first time, and coincidentally diving into this game after felt so right. Mass Effect was clearly inspired by the worlds of Star Wars and Star Trek, bringing a modern action game feel and media dialect to those older stories and making them feel new in Mass Effect 1.

   When I think of the strengths of Mass Effect 1, I think of 3 things: Writing, Writing, and Writing. This doesn't mean other aspects aren't great, it just means the writing is so above and beyond all other ingredients of this game. Bioware was fresh from their work on Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 1 & 2 (PLEASE CHECK THOSE OUT), and their amazing writing from these games follow through into their own original universe. The foundation laid in this game carries on into the entire trilogy. Things like each alien species' identities, your party members individually, and the factions at play in this world. 

   The dialogue is amazing in and of itself, and you as the player can make choices that change it dramatically. This feat is overlooked as 3 games have come and gone, doing this system justice. Writing one game's dialogue is hard enough, imagine writing 2 games worth of dialogue, packing it into one, and making it work interchangeably to account for all player choice, due to the morality system in these games. Bioware set the standard for single player RPG's in their time. 

[h3] Perfectly Balanced...[/h3]

   Mass Effect 2 chose to embrace the action side of the Action-RPG, and aimed to be a perfect hybrid between gameplay and story. This game's story is honestly within a bubble when it comes to the main conflict of the Mass Effect trilogy, it could be described as plot filler with tons of character development, but in hindsight, this is to the game's benefit. Mass Effect 2 is my favorite game of the series, and one of my favorite games of all time. 

   Darker (before it was cool), Rebellious, and full of misfit characters, this game differentiated itself greatly from Mass Effect 1. Almost an antithesis to the squeaky-clean Citadel of Mass Effect 1, this game had you exploring the criminal underbelly of the universe, shacking up with gang leaders and human supremacists. I love the diverse group of aliens you can meet in this game, and I also love seeing how returning characters have changed since the first game. 

   Mass Effect 2's greatest strength is the absolute devotion shown to its main cast of characters, their writing, and how you interact with them. An entire set of unique loyalty missions define their arc's conclusion and allow you as the player to take part in their moral choices. I love characters above all else, and this is why I find Mass Effect 2 to be so amazing. The structure of the game is built on recruiting allies, and then using your bond with them to lead them through hell and back. The final mission of this game is one of the greatest moments in all of gaming, perfectly executed and challenges you as the player with REAL stakes that get your blood pumping. If you have interest in playing Mass Effect 2, the less you know the better. 

[h3] Time Heals All Wounds [/h3]

   Mass Effect 3 is the black sheep of the trilogy. Its ending was a gigantic controversy felt anywhere video games were discussed in 2012. One of the reasons I consider Mass Effect 3 to be "genre-defining" is because the game's reception was a warning sign to everyone else in the future to take extreme care in how you end your series. There are however, other lessons to be learned from Mass Effect 3 that are often overlooked.

   Right now, if you could think of the number 1 reason a game comes out feeling unfinished or rushed, what is it? Crunch Time. Employee Crunch. Mass Effect 3 was hugely anticipated, and so Bioware, under EA's care (ha) was extremely rushed and forced to release the game early, without wrapping up all loose ends. Remember when I said Mass Effect 1's greatest strength was writing, and Mass effect 2 is a balance between action and writing? Well.... Mass Effect 3 starts to swing the other way and become a very fun action game with satisfactory writing. Lots of things either don't make a lot of sense, or seem too convenient. These minor errors are completely overlooked because of the game's ending, but play a large part in why this game feels... off.

   Mass Effect 3 ramps up the main plot of the trilogy, and it feels like everything is coming to an end. You are forced to make world defining choices, picking your allies, and betraying others. How far are you willing to go to save the universe? This on paper, handled by the Bioware we know and love up until this point, could turn out amazing. The sad part is that Bioware was not given proper time to work their magic, so these world ending stakes fall flat in most areas. Choices feel like "The normal person choice" or "The mustache-twirling villain choice." The morality system has finally been turned on its head and become a joke. Renegade (or the "bad-cop") choices are extremely villainous and no longer "ends justify the means, to a reasonable extent." This decay of logic creeps in a lot during Mass Effect 3, to the point where it seems meaningless to make certain choices. 

   All of the negativity aside, Mass Effect 3 is very fun to mess around in. With the most modern controls, the action gameplay feels fluid and actually challenging on the highest difficulties. Furthermore, the story, especially with the characters themselves, has amazing moments that can give closure to you as a player. Lastly, DLC included with this Legendary Edition really does a great job patching up some of the story issues, Bioware wanted to make up for their misstep in the ending, and created one of the finest pieces of "fan-service" (I'm not saying this sarcastically swear) as a gift to the fans to enjoy. The Citadel DLC is a big reason this game healed over time, a must play for someone who made it this far. 

[i] These games came into and shaped my life in a way I can never fully comprehend, they are fantastic and even at their worst offer something you will fondly remember. [/i]


[h3] TLDR [/h3]

Mass Effect 1: Cozy, beautifully written world with a ton of lasting charm. 9.4/10

Mass Effect 2: Gritty, amazing character writing with an insane conclusion that never leaves you. 9.8/10

Mass Effect 3: Fun Combat, (comparatively) so-so writing with an unfinished story that earns its Black Sheep status. 8.2/10

 This collection, and this trilogy as a whole, is iconic, and It is truly a gift we can buy them, DLC and all, in one place, for the price of one game.

[h3] Hall of Shame - Legendary Bugs and Glitches Edition! [/h3]

[b] Mass Effect 1 [/b]

- Multiple crashes and plenty of visual bugs and glitches
- Mako can get stuck in mid-air; can partially clip into terrain due to improper collision. 
- Shepard is forced to walk facing backwards at times. I've seen walking simulators with fewer glitches and this is a remaster of an old game.
- Squadmates get stuck on Feros, thus leaving you on your own if combat is located further away.
- Cryo weapon mod sound effect out of sync with the visuals.
- Combat sometimes overlaps character dialogue, essentially requiring a reload. Press F9 to pay respect.
- Mid conversation crashes are particularly hurtful. In my case the game even crashed during the 1st council dialogue. Not a good look. 


[b] Mass Effect 2 [/b]

- Due to the frequent nature of crashes, the autosave feature here was a true breath of fresh air. ME1 needed it too!
- Conversation with Aria= crash. 1st conversation with Mordin= crashed 4 times.
- Can't skip the intro and initial cutscene. Imagine wanting your own custom Shepard and not being able to make fine changes without re-watching everything. I imagine speedrunners face a similar issue. 
- Crash in the galaxy map
- Crash mid-fight


[b] Mass Effect 3 [/b]

- I don't concern myself with whether or not Huerta is a vegetable or a cyborg. However, I do care if gossip about him is going to lead to a blue screen of death while on my way to completing an objective.
- Enemies falling through debris, becoming unreachable and effectively stopping the flow of the mission. 
- Fumbling in the dark with a flashlight isn't my thing. I'm counting this as a bug. Deal with it. 
- After helping Conrad find his soulmate, if you activate the medical dispenser you'll be incorrectly pointed back to the refugee doctor's location, despite already having completed this objective. 
- Head movement in some scenes must've been inspired by owls. Near 360 degree rotation. Go figure.
- Specialist Traynor is a bit late with the notifications sometimes.
- Crosshair randomly showing up and gradually vanishing upon loading a new game on the Normandy V2
- Why are there med kits on a Geth Dreadnought? Explain. [No obvious answers pls]
- Enemies get stuck in between objects or out of bounds, which is especially problematic in the Armax Arsenal Arena. No fix but to reload the match. 
- The "helmet off in dialogue" is rather hit & miss depending upon RNG at times. I just go without by default. No headshots, please. 

[b] Final thoughts [/b]
Go ahead and experience it for yourself if you haven't yet! It's one heck of a ride!
