The Mass Effect Series is an absolute gem of videogaming history. To me, it is the spiritual successor to my beloved Kotor games (Which I played in my youth and thought to be the pinnacle of rpgs). It has a lot of similarities to kotor in terms of roleplaying mechanics and the depth of the world- and character building, just instead of star wars it is set in its own wonderful and intriguing universe. It was released right at the edge of the era when all big AAA games (especially from EA) became soulless shitfests made only for profit. With this trilogy, you can still feel that delivering the best possible games was still the first priority.

To give you a quick summary of my Rating beforehand: The trilogy, all in all, would be 9/10 possible points. Its a wild ride from start to finish that takes you on an emotional rollercoaster. Each game has its own strengths and weaknesses, but all of them are overall an enjoyable experience bot gameplay- and storywise.

To rate every single game is hard. ME1 is good, but there are some questionable decisions regarding the gameplay and though the story is nice, I dont feel it is as enticing as what would follow in the later games. It serves very well as an entry into the series and solid basis on which to improve on though and introduces a lot of the decisions the results of which you will feel in later games.

ME2 is definitely my favourite of the 3. From start to finish, the story keep you invested. You are being kept in a loop about the true intentions of cerberus and thus cant really trust your employer - all the while fighting to protect the galaxy from a much bigger threat. There are some very deep decisions to be made here and what you did in ME1 will come back to you a lot in ME2. The characters are well written and played with lots of background to make you emotionally invested. The gameplay has been improved from the first entry of the series as well, making this an extremely good RPG overall. 

ME3 is a good game aswell. I feel like the gameplay is the smoothest out of all 3, making moving around and fighting more engaging and fun. Throughout the game, it manages really well to both play with the players emotions regarding certain topics, push them to make impactful and morally ambiguous decisions as well as display the horrors of an intergalactic war. One thing I really liked was the sense of urgency ME3 managed to create in me: It really felt like I had to hurry up and complete my mission lest the reapers or cerberus win. Many of the previous games characters return and are fleshed out more, which leads to you be even more emotionally invested into them. The Interactions you can have with them are also very nice. I didnt like that you were rather restricted in who you could have in your team and that there were rather few options, but I get why they did that. The atmosphere in ME3 is genius, many of the locations feel much more alive than in the previous games. What I noticed though is that the sheer scope of what they were trying to do with ME3 feels a bit much. Especially in the later part of the game some things feel rushed, which is a sickness many AAA games suffer from (Especially EA games). Sadly, it didnt feel like many of the decisions from ME2 or 1 mattered as much as for example in ME2, but that is something that can also be explained by the project being too big in scope and slightly rushed). I didnt really like the end of the game (As did many other fans), but I can accept it and still see the whole and acknowledge that even with its flaws, ME3 is still a good game.

So, to sum up:
Absolutely legendary trilogy: If you are into RPGs and havent played it yet, this is a must. A window into video gamings better days, right before it all went to shit.
Beware though, finishing it will leave you empty and emotionally unstable, similiarly to the feeling you get after finishing a long and good TV-show or book series.

This game took me.. forever to finish, due to family and work commitments. I also threw in a couple of games in between. Why was this game so hard to finish? 

First, the first and second games are, from a gameplay perspective, really not good enough anymore. It was very static shoot-outs from behind protection, and often with far too little control also of that environment, creating stale and unengaging combat. This is mostly fixed by game three, but by then you already have to spend some 50-60 hours to get there. 

What kept me coming back, was the outstanding characters and story. Even though Shepherd is himself not a very interesting character (a real missed opportunity, in a game with such outstanding characters), his crew, the different civilisations, and the galactic story unfolding around throughout the games, are great. 

The story continues throughout the three games, so even though I have my qualms about the gameplay in the first games, I still recommend going through the whole game. 

The much talked about "bad" ending of the third game, I wouldn't be worried about. I thought it was rewarding all the way to the end, and the ending fit well with the archs build over some 80+ hours of gameplay.

I purposely avoided spoilers for 10+ years, so that I could experience ME3 for myself.

The best game (trilogy, but since you can import characters from one game to another, it feels like one extensive game) in all of history, not because of its gameplay, which is quite basic, but because of everything as a whole: the story, the dialogues, the decisions, the connections formed with your companions, the music, the cinematics... all too epic. The story of this game is one of the few that captivated me from the beginning. You become Commander Shepard in their struggle against the Reapers, an alien race threatening to exterminate all life in the galaxy. Along the way, you'll encounter numerous characters—some will become your best and most loyal companions, friends, and even lovers, while others will be your worst enemies. The different interactions you have with them are what sets this game apart from others, and decision-making is also a crucial factor. Some aspects of the story change, and there are situations where your companions can die permanently if your decision is not right. All of this creates a tense situation when deciding certain things, especially the first few times you play without much information. For me, this game has been personally significant, and I wish I could erase my memory and play it for the first time. I envy those who can have that experience. Highly recommended.

Man, I feel weird about this trilogy. Having played it like over 10 years after the release of ME3, I never got the same OG experience as people back in the day. However, I do think it IS a fantastic trio of games... kinda.

ME1 is an oddball. Its gameplay is booty cheeks, completely messy, horribly boring, and samey exploration if you don't do stuff that sticks to the main story. The writing was still getting started, so almost everything acts as a foundation for the other two games, from worldbuilding to character establishment. The romancing is awful, you can lock yourself into a relationship just by being nice and wanting to hear your companions' backstories. The inventory management is AWFUL. The only reason why I didn't drop the trilogy right there and then was because I had curiosity to see how ME2 and ME3 would go, and frankly, I am glad I stuck around...

ME2 is great. Clunky and a bit dated, yes, but the gameplay still is decent enough to not be a detriment while the characterization is at its peak compared to the rest of the trilogy, the narrative is very strong and highly compelling, and the completely different vibe to ME1 in general, from gameplay, to tone, to even setting, makes it stand out a lot. I don't have much to say about it other than to give it high praise, and it feels like in ME2, Mass Effect as a whole truly started to shine. 

ME3 is... odd. It's good, very in fact, having the best gameplay of the trilogy (at least up until the endgame when it gets a bit too messy and spammy, almost feeling like ME1 in terms of clunkyness), and really strong, compelling narratives, from the continuation of all of the previous story arcs, to the introduction of new ones, to the best iteration on AIs I have seen in any media ever... I REALLY like ME3, even with its clunkyness here and there, it's a brilliant videogame. 

So, should you- YES. The entire trilogy is like 10/15 bucks on sales. Get it. I don't care if you need a stupid Origin or whatever they are calling it now account, this trilogy alone is worth it. Buy it, play it, have a grand old time, and have interspecies relationships if you're into that. So yeah you read all of this just to get a "lmao i really liked it" message get fucked nerd

Extremely dated. 

I played Mass Effect 1 and Mass Effect 2 and just didn't bother with 3. If I skip the first 2 games, why bother with the third in the trilogy. Even if it is good, the biggest draw of the story is gone. 

The two games show their age in the gameplay and the storytelling department. 

The gameplay is so awkward to control and doesn't feel great to play. You can't cancel queue up commands or cancel weapon swapping while in the tactical pause which just gets it awkward. The power cooldown just seems obtuse, at least for trying to equip elemental rounds putting a cooldown on your other active skills. Squadmates are dumb as bricks and you're always going to be needing to medigel-ing them on higher difficulties. 

The environment is dated and I'm not talking graphical fidelity. The directional sound for Mass Effect 1 was absolutely atrocious. For example, standing next to the main circular stage in the club on the citadel and facing a orthogonal direction has all of the music coming out of one side of your headphones only. And it's a small room. Even if it is in an open field with no sound wave bouncing, it would still be incredibly jarring. 

I would be far more immersed with the drawing point of the story but personally, I can't get over terrible "editing". You ever watch anything budget and in the script, it's written that someone is supposed to be cut off and it's super obvious? They say the last word of their sentence and don't even try to continue to make any more words or even seem surprised if they are interrupted. Instead they just stand there and look at the person that's supposed to interrupt for half a second and then that person remembers that it's their cue to start talking. That's this game. Actual story can be great but I just get pulled out of it. 

And don't even get me started on modding to fix how terrible this game is. The base game size is 100 GB approximately (I think). Downloading just QOL mods and community patches takes me to 15 GB. Grabbing graphical improvement mods can net me another 50 GB. And then to mod it, the program requires you to back up the game that you are going to mod, so there's another 100 GB on your storage gone for backup. After installing the mods (which isn't great, it isn't drap and drop nor is it vortex but also EA can just make a good game instead), you then have to install the texture mods. This process can take 30+ minutes and also at that point, you can't upgrade or add or remove any mods without re-installing the texture mods. That means that if you have texture mods and ever think you want to change a mod, you have to keep the downloaded mod file on your local disk on top of the changes that it makes to your game files. You end up with 300+ GB worth of Mass Effect on your PC. You don't need to mod all ME1+2+3 obviously and just mod the one you are on but still. It's kind of just a demonstration on the quality of this EA game.

[h1][u]Story[/u][/h1]
Pretty sure everyone knows the gist of the ME trilogy by now. You're Commander Shepard and you carve out your story while dealing with the imminent reaper invasion. Memorable cast of characters and locations. The story, characters, and dialogue are what push the trilogy up to one of the best in gaming.


[h1][u]Gameplay[/u][/h1]
ME1 still feels pretty dated but all three have the similar premise of using cover, guns, and powers as you keep pushing through the locations. Sometimes there's vehicles to use but those feel like awkward to use most times. RPG heavy in ME1 with the weapon/armor looting, leveling, etc. ME2 went a bit more streamlined with the RPG experience. The third ME followed ME2's footsteps and kept the streamlined experience of a RPG design.

As you go through the games you can import your character to the next entry to continue the story of your Shepard. And there's several classes to choose for your Shepard that play differently enough to try other runs. Main classes are Soldier, Adept, and Engineer as well as three others that are mixes of the previous ones listed. Using your powers alongside your guns definitely makes the experience much better and is generally mandatory for the harder difficulties.


[h1][u]Difficulty[/u][/h1]
ME has never been a difficult set of games. Even on the hardest difficulty so long as you use cover properly, and use your team mates powers and telling them where to go, you can brush through the games with relative ease.


[h1][u]Graphics[/u][/h1]
By today's standards it's not all that impressive but back then the games were quite amazing. For the Legendary Edition itself I honestly wish the graphics got more of a boost in all three games. This is EA we're talking about.


[h1][u]Audio[/u][/h1]
The ME trilogy always had some of the best sounds and music. There were some weird situations with audio in certain points throughout all three games but for what they offer it's great.


[h1][u]Performance & Bugs[/u][/h1]
I did come across a few bugs though I couldn't say if they were ones from the original versions that somehow still got in this LE version or new bugs. Performance was okay. Felt like it could have been smoothed out a bit more in terms of performance but nothing you can do if EA doesn't want to optimize something as much as they can.


[h1][u]Summary[/u][/h1]
The ME trilogy is one of the most amazing experiences to go through. That being said this is still an EA game. So I can understand people not wanting to give EA any money. If you're really hesitant about buying an EA game wait for a sale. From what I recall hearing there are mods being made, or have been made, to help this release be a bit more polished.

How odd, it has been 10 years since it released, but I have only just now played Mass Effect 3 for the first time, despite loving the hell out of 1 and 2 in my youth.

An absolutely stellar experience from beginning to end that brought me back to my youth. A great tale to be had despite its noticeable blemishes, the stories told therein are incredibly enjoyable and the characters to adore.
As well, it is an interesting peak into the ideas of game development at the time and through various evolution of the cover-shooter genre, for better or worse, mixed with an RPG system that really makes me want to play Knights of the Old Republic again.

But the blemishes, they are noticeable. Often times frustrating.
To start, the animations leave a great deal to be desired. There have been numerous times, primarily in 1 but present in 2, where animations outright broke and impacted the game. Sometimes my character doesnt turn exactly and is 'frozen' in place with a loop of trying to turn and interfering with movement. Sometimes i'd be in cover, but the character themselves will be raised above said cover and vulnerable. In one moment in 2, I was even unable to progress because due to the application of a pull the enemy in question got stuck in the ceiling and I had to try and find the right vertex sticking out to hit.
I can't speak for Mass Effect 3 exactly, but these add to an air of jank that I quite frankly cannot recall having been present in the original 1 or 2. A blemish brought on by improvements from the legendary edition I imagine, but to be quite frank they are not too impactful. In my own experience, especially playing through these on insanity, the higher the difficulty you play on, the more noticeable they'll become. If you play on normal, they'll just be there. But its frustrating to die on insanity because my model was sticking out of cover and slowly sliding back into it. 

And let me reiterate, these are only small nitpicks. The only legitimate complaint I have that'd affect ranking would be small story elements in 3. And even then, these did not affect the rank much.

No more needs to be said, absolutely gets a crow seal of approval.

The graphical improvements are mind-blowing. Every pixel feels like it's been touched by the hands of gaming deities, rendering the Normandy and its crew in breathtaking detail. The updated textures are so vivid that I can practically feel the cosmic dust on my skin as I traverse the galaxy.

But it's not just about the visuals. The enhanced gameplay mechanics have redefined my approach to decision-making. Every dialogue choice feels like a cosmic ripple, affecting not only the fate of entire civilizations but also my very essence as a gamer.

The Legendary Edition isn't just a game; it's a cosmic odyssey that has become a spiritual experience. The epic soundtrack is the celestial hymn that echoes in my dreams, and the storyline is a narrative masterpiece that has rewired the neural pathways of my gaming soul.

In conclusion, Mass Effect Legendary Edition isn't just a game; it's a transcendental journey through the cosmos. Liara's mesmerising presence and those celestial assets have left an indelible mark on my heart, transforming me into a devout pilgrim on the altar of gaming greatness. BioWare, you've not only created a legendary edition; you've forged a gaming legend that will resonate across the universe for eons to come!

The story, the companions, the compelling main character, the choices that have actual consequences to the story line... it's all relatively unparalleled (with perhaps an exception being Baldur's Gate 3).  I've played this game through more times than I care to admit, though this is my first run through on PC.  I had previously played on Xbox.  However I wanted to try a computer run, and to pop some of the steam achievements.  I will keep playing it on PC for now, but if I ever want to do another runthrough, I'll be going back to my X-box.  It's just not worth it to try to load the game through EA's dumpsterfire of a launcher.  My recommendation- absoltely play this game.  Just do it on a console so you don't have to go through EA's radioactive launcher.  It took me the better part of an hour trying to get the game to work though EA Launcher.  First it wouldn't recognize my account.  Then it wouldn't sync.  Then it just kept endlessly crashing.  Then it would try to load and nothing would happen.  Then it crashed my entire computer.  An hour of troubleshooting this nonsense that people have been complaining about since EA abandoned Origin for this idiotic new game launcher.  

I sometimes use video games to cope with anxiety.  I was on the verge of a panic attack when I started trying to get Mass Effect to work.  The only good thing I can say about EA is that trying figure out how to get their janky game launcher going induced such a plethora of rage within me, that my anxiety temporarily went away.  So there's that I guess.

Mass effect is no doubt hands down the best game series of the latter decade, now remastered with textures, models, lighting, (more obvious) lens flares and more.

The series itself is an epic space opera/rpg that covers trilogy of games in the legendary edition, Mass effect revolves around the now infamous Commander Sheppard (female obviously) traversing the galaxy to stop an intergalactic threat to humanity and the galaxy. Choice's really matter in this game, and they have consequences which do unfold throughout the entire game series. 

Game play itself is from the 3rd person perspective, (making you think 3rd person shooter and technically yes the combat is just that, with a pause menu to issue commands to your team), however the depth of the game, the characters, missions to accomplish, levelling up and skill progression, emotions conveyed, and even the atmospheric music all sets the mood for one of the greatest rpg's of all time.

"Were counting on YOU commander, get out there!"

It's the Mass Effect trilogy, but all the dialog lines trigger correctly. Some gameplay changes were also made, but the games all still feel like the originals.

Up front, it does require the game be launched through the EA Store (formerly Origin). Also, the launcher for selecting which of the three games to play was pretty broken a few months back. It's working at time of writing (Oct 2023), but your mileage may vary.

The full run down:

Mass Effect 1 looks better and plays mostly the same (the various weapons now have different fire rates and properties, but the stats screen doesn't convey any of that info). The Mako is still hell on wheel and the autosave system is still an afterthought. However, it's MUCH more stable, I didn't get any crashing or glitches.

Mass Effect 2 is virtually identical to the original 2010 release, but all the DLC items are now found in the shops and not just given to you. The load times are like 1/100th of the original, which is nice.

Mass Effect 3 is unchanged expect there's no multiplayer (which is a shame, cuz the multiplayer was great).

TL;DR: It's Mass Effect, but runs a little better on modern Windows machines.

The Mass Effect Legendary Edition, the trilogy in remastered form, is the new intended way to play it in it's entirety. You can start at any of the 3 games, but you cannot pick which ones to install, all 3 must be installed for you to play them, making this version a better choice for beginners / people starting over than for those who might want to continue from between games.
 
The games themselves are good, but are showing their age, even with the visual and gameplay touchups they got. What is particularly notable in it's age, I think, are the dialogues. They're pretty well written, as you'd expect from Bioware, but the direction wobbles between "ok" to "jarring", as the dialogue cutscenes frequently fail to transition cleanly between...what I'll call "consequences" dialogues, giving them this strange "videotape cut" feel to them.
 
Everything else from the games is what you'd likely expect from them. They're Unreal Engine (3) games, so any ancient machine should be able to go through these games with not much problem even with the remastered elements, though I'll note the small Mass Effect 1 issue of V-sync being slightly broken when traversing the planetary exploration maps with rather severe fps degradation.
 
Final note regarding Mass Effect 3: All multiplayer and companion app content got cut and the game's systems were rebalanced around this fact. Ofc, this being a good or bad thing hinges entirely on whether you liked/wanted the MP or not. Personally didn't feel it's omission during gameplay at all.

Always loved ME1 & ME2. Just wish they'd rework the character creation screen for the Legendary edition. Have no real complaints over the first two installments. I do resent that I never engaged with either Liara or Ashley in ME1, but after importing a save to ME2, the game decided my Shepard must've had something with Liara because Ashley died.

Now, ME3:
+ The reworked combat system (especially playing as Vanguard) is so much fun. It's exhilarating to be able to engage in melee, dash through the battlefield, and take out one enemy after another with just phisical attacks. It's a power fantasy done right. Feels so good.

- Quest log, in comparison to previous games is inferior. It is near impossible to learn what needs to be done without extensive time spent reading the wiki instead of playing the game.
- No scanning of the planets.
- No hacking minigames.
- The story is a lot more streamlined, no more branching intimidate or charm options, just interrupts
- At times, the developers are just shoving some of their pet characters, and their problems in your face. (Steve Cortez)

(Spoiler free.)
Having never played the original Mass Effect games and going in blind, this was my first introduction to the world. And I'm glad it was.

The Mass Effect trilogy has one of the most immersive, subtly funny, and unique worlds I've ever seen. Despite being quite old design-wise, it manages to do more things right than many modern games.
For one thing, the side quests are actually worth playing.
Additionally, all the side characters have interesting dialogue that changes and builds up both the world and their characters.
Even more impressively, the game design matches perfectly with the story. Particularly in the third game.

The world and characters are incredibly charming, and I often found myself chuckling at jokes or grinning upon seeing my favorite characters returning. I'm currently nearing the ending of my second play-through, and I'm still finding new things or smiling at things I forgot happened.
I cannot stress how worthwhile interacting with the world is in Mass Effect.

If I had to name one thing that annoyed me, it would be the "space to run but also to hide behind cover" controls in the second and third game. It doesn't make much sense and often resulted in me hiding behind cover when I was trying to run from an enemy.
That said, it didn't hinder my enjoyment much, as it was primarily a problem when I was already in trouble, difficulty-wise.

When it comes to the story, I have no real complaints. It felt as though my choices had an impact, not just in the cutscenes, but also out of the cutscenes. There were serious consequences to some of the choices I made which, though they might not impact the overall story, still expanded the world for me and me feel bad for making them.

Overall, I'd say it's best put it like this:
"It really makes you feel like Commander Shepard."

And that's not just a joke.

I recommend to all who loves RPGs to buy this game if you have not ever played this game. Totally worth it! I love these games!

Shows its age a bit, and I find some flaws are more noticeable without my rose-colored glasses, but still a trio of good games. Further, it's a great deal as a three-in-one pack.
ME1 has a great sense of exploration and wonder. While the gameplay can be awkward at times and some of the systems can be clunky, the Legendary Edition does a good job at fixing some of the game's issues to make it a bit more approachable. Given how the game presents its story, it does a good job at making it feel like there's a whole galaxy out there to explore, even if a lot of the explorable planets are just awkward vehicle playgrounds. Great writing, decent gameplay, overall a very memorable game.
Playing ME2 right after really shows the impact EA had on Bioware. Exploration and atmosphere are less of a focus, while gunplay and abilities have been tightened up. Much more of a TPS action game than a shooter RPG that ME1 was. While the overall story is clumsy, the individual characters and their arcs are great, and there's very few duds in the large cast. Still a lot of fun, but there are quite a few questionable gameplay decisions that hold it back from being great, and the strong cast can't shore up the overall story. The weakest of the three, in my opinion, but still worth playing if you're looking to try all three.
ME3 continues where ME2 left off structure-wise, but there's more focus on the main story as opposed to just the characters populating it, giving it a better balance. There's slightly more RPG elements than 2, but still not as much as 1, meaning it's still firmly an action TPS. Still a good cast of characters, and I find the overall story to be a bit cleaner, despite all the different elements that make it up. While the ending is a hot topic, even after all these years, I've grown more accepting of it as time passes, so I don't think it's such a let-down as to deter new players. YMMV though.
The amount of player choice in these games gives it a lot of repeatability, and in the end, it's up to the player if they want to take their time exploring the galaxy or simply rush from place to place, guns blasting. A real cultural event in gaming, and still worth playing now, despite its flaws.

It's always difficult to write a review of a remastered game, because it begs the question, what am I exactly critiquing here?

The Mass Effect trilogy is one of the best sci-fi RPGs of all time, made by BioWare in their absolute golden age. Having played the original probably 4 times over the years, I can tell you, this is definitely the game, you wish you could forget, so you could experience it all over again.

Having said all that, I have not once wished for a remaster during those playthroughs, [b] mainly because of the extremely talented and dedicated modding community. [/b] With a bit of patience, you could actually modify the games both graphically and gameplay wise to be up to date. Hell you can even change the ending to one that is not [spoiler] the absolute garbage abomination that we got in the first release. [/spoiler]

So to be honest, I wasn't so sure, why this remaster was needed, other than to found the studio after their catastrophic Anthem release. Sure, the first game was dated, even with mods, but I would say it added to it's charm. 

When this was released, it made absolutely no sense to buy it. Other than the first game, the original trilogy didn't need any graphical enhancement. Pair it with the bugs, the lack of mods and the expensive price, the lack of multiplayer, and with the broken achievements, due to the absolute s**tshow that's EA app, it just wasn't a good deal for someone who already played the originals. And I most certainly i would not have recommended it.

Now, after 2 years, I would say things are changed a bit. The modding community did catch up, and not only that, but the release has bought some new life to it. With that, most bugs, and annoyances are fixed (by the community...) and you can enjoy all the graphical, gameplay and story enhancing mods from the originals. After 2 years, they fixed the not so small issue, with the achievements, so you don't have to jump hoops with the now retired origin app method.

All in all, I would say, if you haven't played the original, or maybe started the first one, but were put off for some reason, it's now a great time to experience it. Buy it with a reasonable discount.

In the vast cosmos of gaming experiences, Mass Effect Legendary Edition emerges as a celestial masterpiece that transcends its original brilliance. As a dedicated fan of the iconic Mass Effect trilogy, I approached this remastered edition with a mix of excitement and nostalgia. Little did I know that BioWare had meticulously crafted an experience that not only preserved the soul of the originals but elevated them to new heights.

From the moment the Normandy takes flight, it's evident that Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a labor of love. The visual enhancements are nothing short of breathtaking, breathing life into the rich and diverse worlds that Commander Shepard and their crew traverse. The updated character models, textures, and lighting make each alien species and human character more vivid and expressive than ever before. Even the Citadel, with its towering spires and bustling atmosphere, feels more alive and immersive.

The improvements extend beyond mere aesthetics. The gameplay enhancements seamlessly blend the refined mechanics of Mass Effect 2 and 3 into the original Mass Effect, creating a cohesive and polished experience across all three titles. Combat is more fluid, responsive, and strategically engaging, allowing players to relish every intense firefight and tactical decision.

The heart of Mass Effect, however, lies in its narrative, and Legendary Edition pays homage to this aspect with unwavering devotion. The emotional depth of the characters, the intricacies of the branching storylines, and the moral quandaries that define Shepard's journey are preserved with the utmost care. The inclusion of nearly all DLC content adds layers of narrative complexity, making the Legendary Edition the definitive way to experience the epic saga.

The remastered soundtrack is a symphony of nostalgia and new discoveries, complementing the epic space opera with a renewed sense of grandeur. From the haunting melodies of Virmire to the pulse-pounding beats of the Suicide Mission, the music is a captivating companion that enhances the emotional resonance of every moment.

Perhaps one of the most commendable aspects of Mass Effect Legendary Edition is its commitment to accessibility. The inclusion of a unified character creator across all three games, the option to skip the often polarizing planet scanning in Mass Effect 2, and the streamlining of certain mechanics demonstrate BioWare's dedication to making the trilogy more approachable for both veterans and newcomers alike.

In conclusion, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is more than a remaster—it's a celestial odyssey that honors the legacy of the original trilogy while redefining the standards for what a remastered collection can achieve. Whether you're a seasoned Spectre or a first-time explorer of the Mass Effect universe, this edition is an essential pilgrimage that captivates the soul and leaves an indelible mark on the gaming cosmos. Commander Shepard's legendary journey has never shone brighter, and the stars have aligned to deliver an experience that will be remembered for generations to come.

ME1 is the cult classic that went underappreciated and was way ahead for its time. Set the foundation for this franchise brilliantly but it sadly shows its age

ME2 is the spin off/side story that expanded the world and is probably my favorite (empire strikes back of mass effect). A slight nitpick is that they streamlined everything down, almost completely stripped the RPG elements but luckily the gameplay and story made up for it.  

ME3 is the blockbuster conclusion that fumbled a bit with its ending....... not that the endings were bad but it didn't feel like your actions directly influenced them like the previous game and it feels worse considering this is the conclusion to a trilogy. Apart from that they improved on literally everything and that citadel DLC was amazing and imo,  made up for any shortcomings and is probably the best DLC ever made

In conclusion, amazing games in a convenient package that's essential a must play

Steam Deck Review: 
If you can get around EA's wonky background app (which is annoying but not too hard), the Mass Effect Trilogy is amazing on the steam deck. It runs great, looks great, is the perfect game for being able to load it up anywhere to enjoy. In terms of needing to always be connected (thanks EA), you just need a connection to start-up the game. My advise: Keep it running and put your deck to sleep. That way you can start it up again and keep playing where ever you are regardless of an internet connection. Also, let's talk battery life. Since none of the games in the trilogy are super demanding, I usually get A LOT of battery life before needing to plug in, especially compared to a more demanding title like Cyberpunk.

If you are a Steam Deck user and see this game go on sale, buy it! Or don't wait. Given how many hundreds of hours of gameplay there are, and the replayability factor, just buy it!

I won't be buying any other EA game until the company allows launch directly from Steam.

I have invested hundreds of hours on the Mass effect trilogy, only recently adding it to steam.. The story is truly epic.
The first game is looking a bit aged now and is a bit slow for action game enthusiasts like me. However, the new enhanced version is worth playing to make decisions which can have consequences in ME2 and ME3. It has one of the most exciting end of any game I have played.

Mass Effect 2 is very much an action game. It is mostly about recruiting a team. And what a team it is! They are all fully rounded characters which you can genuinely like. It also builds up to an exciting final mission where there is a real danger of losing some of your "friends".

Mass Effect 3 is another action game. it uses he best features of both preceding games to maximise your enjoyment. There is some controversy about the ending but that shouldn't put anybody off.

Having played the games before the Legendary Edition was released, I wondered if it would be worth it. It certainly wasn't when it was £50! However, now it's cheap as chips and worth having for a cleaned up Mass Effect 1 and the renewed ability to import you character from ME1 to ME2 and finally to ME3.

You can play the three games individually as stand-alone games and accept the default conditions or use the interactive comic to change the major decisions. However, there is great satisfaction to bring you character through all three games and meet characters in different circumstances.

In the end, it's terrific value. It's a trio of games you can revisit again and again.

Although they put the guy on the cover I guess the game was originally written for Jane Shepard, who is a great main character. Some people might think it's normal to just pick the guy but Jane Shepard really is a great main character so I hope you give it a chance. If you want to be a good or bad Shepard that is up to you. Someone recommended playing this way to me and I'm grateful so maybe can return the favor to another new player.
There are also good supporting characters, and interacting and going through the story is I think the main strength of ME1.(I've only just started ME2 at this time.) It also does a good job of either informing the player, or being intuitive, so you don't feel frustrated or the need to stop the game, go on google and have random people explain, as in a poorly designed game. It will reward you for spending more time analyzing and upgrading equipment, skills etc. but if you want to just keep playing, the game is friendly to that.
There is a main story, and side quests, and that's about it. If you are expecting professions and some random encounters/events when exploring like a skyrim rpg, maybe come back to this one when you just feel like playing through a good interactive story.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a must-have for fans of the iconic sci-fi RPG series. This remastered collection brings together the original Mass Effect trilogy, complete with updated graphics, improved gameplay mechanics, and all previously released DLC.

One of the standout features of Mass Effect Legendary Edition is the stunning visual overhaul, which breathes new life into the beloved universe of Mass Effect. The updated character models, textures, and lighting make for a truly immersive experience, allowing players to revisit the epic story of Commander Shepard and their crew in breathtaking detail.

The gameplay improvements in this edition are also noteworthy, with refined combat mechanics and streamlined controls that enhance the overall experience. The ability to seamlessly transition between all three games while retaining progress and choices is a welcome addition, providing a cohesive and seamless journey through the trilogy.

In addition to the technical upgrades, Mass Effect Legendary Edition also includes all previously released DLC, allowing players to experience the complete story of Shepard's fight against the Reapers without any content gaps. This comprehensive package ensures that both newcomers and longtime fans can enjoy the full scope of the Mass Effect universe.

While the Legendary Edition has been praised for its enhancements, some players have noted minor technical issues and bugs that can detract from the experience. However, these issues are relatively minor and do not overshadow the overall quality of the collection.

Overall, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a love letter to fans of the series, offering a visually stunning and comprehensive package that celebrates the legacy of Mass Effect. Whether you're a returning fan or new to the series, this remastered collection is a worthy investment that captures the magic of one of gaming's most beloved franchises.

The Mass Effect Trilogy is renowned for being great, immersive, splendid,  and other adjectives. If you haven't heard of it, you should.

Incredible and epic storytelling, Characters, Gameplay, Music... almost everything is good. If you like games where choice matters, the Mass Effect Trilogy takes the experience to a whole new level, your choices are carried over across three games.

This is a technical review. There won't be any spoilers, summaries, or anything related to the game's story.

 [h1]Mass Effect:[/h1]
 [h2]"Is Submission Not Preferable To Extinction?"[/h2]
 [h2]-Saren Arterius[/h2]

The first game of the trilogy is an excellent start. The best in story writing

In contrast to the other two games, the first game's movement and combat have not aged well, even with remaster improvements.

The secondary quests in the game feel repetitive, and the planet exploration is not that good, most of it is empty, with some bases to explore. However, the story writing and worldbuilding make you overlook this problem, You will meet your first companions, who may appear in all three games based on your choices.

Overall it is an excellent game even though it seems outdated.

 [h1]Mass Effect 2:[/h1]
 [h2]"Information is my weapon, Shepard. It's good." [/h2]
 [h2]-Illusive Man [/h2]

Overall the best game. With the best character writing.

An exceptional and truly unforgettable cast of characters, each one of your companions has its own personal quest that makes you want to complete every quest.

The side missions, exploration, customization, and combat have been significantly improved in this game. The final quest is brutal and many of your companions can die.

Although the game's plot is short and feels like filler, it is still great.

 [h1]Mass Effect 3:[/h1]
 [h2]"Stand in the ashes of a trillion dead souls and ask the ghosts if honor matters. The silence is your answer" [/h2]
 [h2]-Javik[/h2]

The best in terms of Gameplay

The narrative in this game is exceptional, it offers a more cinematic experience. Your choices matter in this game, but some choices have time limits and can lead to character deaths, we have to make sacrifices too.
The story is great, but some choices are questionable. The ending is lazy and makes you feel that everything you've done to that point was irrelevant.

Despite its flaws in the ending, ME3 is a great game.


 [h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

Mass Effect is an exceptional Sci-Fi RPG trilogy, one of the greatest ever made. I recommend it to anyone seeking a captivating experience. If you like Star Wars or Star Trek, you will enjoy it too.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1328670/Mass_Effect_Legendary_Edition/]Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition[/url][/b] is an excellent sci-fi trilogy of games!

Although I had never played this series before, I had heard great things about it.  So, when I saw it on sale for 80% off, I decided to give it a try.  This was my first foray into this franchise, aside from wearing the N7 suit in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1238060/Dead_Space_3/]Dead Space™ 3[/url], and I played the full series on the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/steamdeck]Steam Deck[/url].  Overall, it worked well, except for a slightly longer start-up time due to the EA launcher, and one hour of downtime when my internet went out (unfortunately, you have to be connected to play 👎) . The launcher automatically loads a Mass Effect launcher where you can then launch [b]Mass Effect[/b], [b]Mass Effect 2[/b], and [b]Mass Effect 3[/b].


[h3]Mass Effect[/h3]
Set in the 22nd century, this game combined various gameplay styles, including foot exploration, space and planet exploration aboard the Normandy, and planet surface exploration using the Mako. The story unfolded gradually, captivating me with its rich lore and excellent sci-fi writing. The unique planets and locations in the main quest kept things fresh and exciting throughout.

The only major downside was the repetitive bases, which featured only 4 base styles (mine, square, bunker, spaceship), differing only in their decorations and goals. Additionally, it wasn't until I explored the second-to-last star system that I realized there were hidden places to visit within the asteroid belts, and that information should have been made clearer earlier in the game.

Overall, it was a fantastic game, with great graphics, a vast universe, and an excellent story, where I spent a total of 45 hours playing.

[h3]9/10[/h3]


[h3]Mass Effect 2[/h3]
I began playing this game immediately after finishing Mass Effect (ME1).  It picks up shortly after the first chapter but truly begins two years later. The game let me import my ME1 character, carrying forward the choices I made in the previous game.  It also provided an interactive comic that summarized the events and choices from the first game.  These were both very nice touches!

Mass Effect 2 offered more squad members, planets, and places to visit.  One significant improvement was that each location I visited was unique, and I never saw any replicated areas. While some places were small and short, many of them were visually stunning and awe-inspiring or amazing to behold. Although the Mako was absent in this game, there were instances where I could fly a car, or an M-44 Hammerhead hovercraft, which added to the enjoyment, even if they were sparingly used. The star chart and space travel mechanics were significantly improved, requring the use of fuel and probes to explore planets.  Additionally, the foot combat was also upgraded, introducing ammo and reloading mechanics, which differed from the cooldown-based weapon system in the first game.

Overall, this was an excellent sequel with even better graphics, a larger universe, and more engaging story telling, where I spent 65 hours playing. However, as this instalment was a middle chapter in the story, I had to continue on to next chapter.

[h3]10/10[/h3]


[h3]Mass Effect 3[/h3]
I started this game immediately after completing Mass Effect 2 (ME2).  It takes place six months after the events of the previous chapter, thrusting you right into a grim invasion of the galaxy. I imported my saved character from ME2, but unlike the previous game, there was no comic to provide a recap, which was a bit disappointing.

A few changes were introducted in Mass Effect 3 (ME3).  Hacking and resource scanning was removed, and the only vehicle I could control was the Cerberus Atlas Mech, which only occurred a few times.  Nevertheless, the unique worlds still captivated me, and some scenes were truly excellent and outstanding.

This chapter revealed the final pieces of lore and history of the series, and the story was exceptional. Some subplots gave me goosebumps and even brought tears to my eyes, particularly when a squad member made the paragon sacrifice. The story almost remained perfect throughout the whole game. Almost that is, until the grand finale's choice of 4 endings.  [u]This is where the story [i]shockingly[/i] gave out[/u], as the choices were [i]unhappy, bittersweet, disappointing, or deferred[/i]. This [i]major let-down[/i] was a [i]massive strike against the entire trilogy[/i], detracting from an otherwise perfect game and trilogy, and impacting its 10/10 rating. 

Overall, and aside from the ending of ME3, the game's lore and history was well worth the experience, and I spent 52 hours playing it.

[h3]8/10[/h3]


[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1328670/Mass_Effect_Legendary_Edition/]Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition[/url] is an exceptionally excellent Sci-Fi RPG trilogy. If you're a fan of sci-fi, Star Wars, or Star Trek, you will thorougly enjoy it. However, I would advise managing your expectations regarding the final choice in the game, and try to find a silver lining in it, even if it may not bring the closure you sought.  [i]If you're really in need of a better ending, you can consider using [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffectlegendaryedition/mods/323]Audemus' Happy Ending Mod[/url], which may provide a more satisfying conclusion to this memorable sci-fi trilogy[/i].

Why do people like this series? It's horrible!
I've tried playing ME1 a few times before and finally bought this thinking maybe I missed something and would give it and the rest of the trilogy another go. And I regret getting it.
I keep hearing people say the characters are fantastic. What characters? Shepard is left to being a pushover or a complete jerk, which is par for BioWare's lineup. And none of those choices ultimately matter when you can pick what you want at the end anyway. The rest of the team are completely forgettable. Now 9 hours in and I only remember Ashley's name because she looked mildly hot in the opening scene, which quickly faded when she opened her mouth. Actually I keep finding myself saying out loud for them to shut up when they interject their opinions. Which are so important that they say nothing on major decisions, before or after. The dialogue system, which I understand was supposed to be so revolutionary for being able to select what to say next while the conversation is still going, doesn't actually match what you end up saying. Fallout 4 took a note from this book. Just like how you have to announce you're going to fight others and beat your chest in conversation instead of just doing it. That's before we talk about how unbelievable the reactions and behaviors of characters are throughout the game. 
Okay, the plot. What plot? Bad guy wants to bring about universe ending thing and you hunt him down. There's several hurdles along the way and I keep finding myself wanting to just get this section done and hope there's not another mcguffin stopping me from getting to the good stuff. I still love how you're introduced to the Batarians like they're the well known evildoers of the universe when you come across some random one's schemes. Okay. Just roll with it I suppose.
The game is very glitchy. I understand ME1 came out in 2007, but these couldn't be fixed by now? The load menu for selecting which game doesn't allow controller input and acts odd in general. Enemy projectiles pass through walls and terrain (most easily noticeable in the Mako sections). My computer barely holds 40 fps when it can run Cyberpunk 2077 at 60 fps with ease on the same resolution and high graphics. There's so many places to get the character stuck, especially in combat, that I avoid even entering cover for concerns that I will get locked in and killed. Enemies will utterly skip all animations and pop back into cover or teleport altogether to several feet away in every fight. I'm used to being ready to shift my aim quickly for it now. And while not a glitch, who thought being able to sprint for 10 ft before huffing and puffing was a good idea? Deus Ex: HR ran with this idea too it seems. It's extremely annoying, just like the boosters on the Mako that do literally nothing. Your screen gets stretched and there's camera shake, but you don't move any faster. I also love the touch of all these systems where the overwhelming majority you can do nothing with except the same random encounter map if you hunt around enough.
I feel like this is like GTA3. Where it's a bunch of poorly made systems, but because there's a variety being presented, it's greater than the sum of its parts. That along with rose colored glasses for those who enjoyed this as a kid. I'm a minority in thinking ME is dreadful on all accounts, but if you liked it in the original releases, you might like the refreshed graphics (did they really need to keep such a tight skybox around the Normandy's cockpit though?). For those who never played, I don't know why you'd bother when there's so much better out there. But maybe you're like me trying to find the hype, thinking it's one of those games where "it gets better after X hours" or something.

Most of the stuff that can be said to the Mass Effect trilogy has been well covered by Raycevick as my thoughts and criticisms towards the trilogy mostly align with his as well. Simply check out his vids on Youtube. Overall, the critic that I can sum up with this series is as Raycevick puts it: 

“The universe Bioware created outshines the game itself.”

The characters, the world, and the best moments of ME make up the very heart and bulk of the experience. Bioware successfully wrote some of the best characters and moments in gaming that you will truly invest time into knowing them and bringing them along your journey. And Bioware was completely aware of their writing and able to create many very self-aware and hilarious dialogues and one of, if not the best fan-service DLC that ever existed. The Milky Way galaxy is also such a living world that Bioware filled with all the established lore, world hubs, little moments and conversations you encounter throughout the playthrough to immerse yourself more into the world and grow invested into the stakes and characters beside the main quests.

All 3 games have their own strengths and weaknesses. There are the janky combat, often contrived writing and drama, unclear dialogue wheel, over-simplified moral system, wasted potentials, not so great reasoning of plot points, cut contents due to troubled development throughout all 3 games, but these faults here and there didn’t hinder me enjoying the best moments and the satisfaction of my cumulating choices. As of personal preference the cohesive narrative that progresses along the playthrough in ME1&3 suit me better than the combination of different short stories in ME2.

The legendary edition did a fair job in overhauling ME1 janks, but ME2&3 is practically an official texture and resolution upgrade, some minor bugs and visual inconsistencies still exist. 240 fps in ME3 is bugged and not usable since it stops your shield from regening. Though it is still a clean remastered experience, albeit a bit lazy tbh. But no matter how good it is, it is still fucking irredeemable that this single-player experience requires constant internet connection to play AND you need to connect and remain online to the shitty EA app. Which means: If your internet rests in peace or EA’s NASA branded potatoes went to the oven, you are not playing the game…which it happened to me once when EA had an explosive diarrhea and it is frustrating. It is not consumer-friendly and nonsensical. Fuck this shit.
 
All and all, to the series itself, I would confidently regard Mass Effect trilogy as a masterpiece of Sci-Fi videogames series and one of the best to date. And after my trilogy playthrough I reinforced my belief that ME3 endings and Andromeda were major missteps made by Bioware. Instead of realizing the mistakes they made with ME3 endings, they decided to ditch all the efforts of the vast universe and characters of the Milky Way galaxy that the ME1-3 team made. They instead soft rebooted it with a new galaxy, without properly realizing how immensely difficult it is to create somethings that pack the same charm and thoughts the original Bioware team came up with. And on top of that still focusing on the oldcomers from the Milky Way, which in the end created a very shallow and unimpressive game of Andromeda. It would’ve been more sensible if they decided to make a prequel about a lot of unexplored characters stories or events with the already established lore and source materials than spending 2 times the effort for creating something people may not grow as fond as and be as good as the original.

Either way, what’s done is done. The Mass Effect universe still leaves a lot of rooms and potentials for both sequels or prequels. But I swear to god I beg Bioware for the next ME. Treat our beloved characters good. They’ve been though a lot with Shepard and deserve a proper return. Not character assassination nor fan fic reiteration.

The Mass effect series is a lore rich, captivating and thrilling game. Its story and game play are incredibly well done. One of the things I like about the game is the controls and game play are designed for everyone from third person RPG novices to masters, without limiting the game play or reducing the experience. I have spent hundreds of hours playing all 3 games in the trilogy, and I can say with out a shadow of a doubt that the Mass Effect trilogy is my all time favorite game series to ever been created. I would recommend this to anyone and everyone.

For my gameplay totaling 88 hours, I suppose it makes sense that this series would be considered a singular game. It is unfortunate that the third game was rushed, because it was honestly my favorite of the series. Here's a brief overview, and then I'll go more into detail:

Highlights:
* Interpersonal dymanics are incredibly enjoyable.
- In ME2 and ME3, combat is just chef's kiss.
- Enemies don't respawn.
* A lot of ME2 and ME3 is hand crafted, and highly detailed (understatement).
- The portrayal of other aliens was endearing.

Mixed emotions:
- The arrival had one of the best fights in the game. But you don't get credit for winning it.
- The world and lore feels somewhat alive at times, and at others dead.
- The equipment mechanics are odd. Especially the armor. Some things can only be worn as a set, others as pieces. Can't just take enemy guns. Gun stats not always fully explained. But there are still some things I like about it, I mean, it does definitely change the experience and it's fun to seek them out.
- I enjoyed exploring space, but you don't really get to witness many alien cultures outside of brief mission areas and shops.

Low points:
* The ending of ME3 was AWFUL. And you can only get a satisfying ending with mods.
- The beginning of ME3 undermined everything you did in ME2.
- Various things you did in ME1 and ME2 don't matter as much as you'd like in ME3.
- ME1 exploration areas not pertaining to main quests were just AI generated and boring.
- ME2 put too much focus on resource collection, which loses its appeal after a while.
- Once again, the ending of ME3 was horrible.
- The messaging in ME3 is confusing.

Now, the mass effect trilogy was one of the best gaming experiences I had overall. There were so many intense, action-packed fights and cutscenes that just filled me with ecstasy. Especially in ME3, such as with the Krogan fight. You play the role of an intergalactic soldier throughout the game, and it's very easy to fall into that from a roleplaying perspective. The battles are captivating, and you really do feel like you're in danger at times. But for a game that you would expect your choices to impact, they basically don't, which is tragic.

In ME2 we don't really see the humans gaining more power, despite you dismantling the old council and the humans being given the upperhand. There are various inconsistencies with the beginning of ME3: first, your entire squad distanced themselves from you and none cared to stick around for you or even send word to you throughout your trial. Not even your love interest. Guns should've been returned with the Normandy, along with your armor. You start dreaming about some irrelevant kid for no good reason because you see him briefly. A singular reaper in ME1 and ME2 was so powerful that everyone almost died, but there's supposed to be hundreds in ME3 and they're all portrayed as practically instinctual predators and not super powerful beings. 

That rachni queen you killed in ME1? Yeah, doesn't matter, they're still using rachni through some made up space tech explanation and Krogan. Those geth you killed in ME1 or ME2? Doesn't matter because they're still around, even in ME3. Destroyed the premature invasion signal in ME2 with an asteroid? Doesn't matter because they're all going to attack in ME3. Befriended the leviathan in ME3? Doesn't matter, they're basically irrelevant to the story and ending.

The messaging is problematic. Let's start with the Geth: Legion claims that he will allow you to destroy the Geth, but then attacks you if you actually do, which you probably will unless you save Tali's questline for one of the last. This means that Legion, and Geth as a whole, prioritize their own survival above all, which is canon and makes sense given what we know about them, regardless of how Legion would like to portray it. One could make the argument that Legion is only working with Shephard because of his prior victories, and sees him as the winning side.

Then comes the part everyone hates: the ending of ME3. They introduce the starchild, which is so obviously an evil reaper trying to manipulate you. In this game, there is not a single indication that the AI can be trusted, besides the Normandy AI who arguably isn't completely free. And you're a soldier who has dedicated their life just to stopping them. How in the hell could the dev team say that the synthetic ending is the good one? All endings are horrible. We can assume by even seeing the starchild that indoctrination has begun. Opting to control the reapers means you get indoctrinated. Opting to turn everyone into AI is disgusting and means that you basically live in this pretend blue pill-esque world where everyone loses their consciousness and identity meanwhile everyone is being devoured by husks.

So logically, of course I chose to destroy the reapers once and for all. But stupidly, instead of it just destroying the mass relays and the reapers, you die (unless you have like 100% achievements but still) and your friends are stranded far away from you. No word about the lives of krogan, or any of the other aliens you saved, and the whole thing is just rushed, botched, and does such an injustice to all of the good parts of the game leading up to that.

And all that being said, the experience excluding that was still so fun that I'd love a ME4. Just please, do not botch the endings. The concept of a game series having choices that impact games to follow is amazing, but those choices need to mean something. The gameplay was really fun, and the cutscenes were cinematic and movie-like. The aliens were cool. There were so many things I heavily enjoyed about this game, but it is so flawed.

This is arguably the best trilogy from the best Sci-Fi franchise in the history of vidya. And now, it comes packed in a big bundle of joy with all the preexisting DLCs included, QoL changes, and technical improvements we would expect of a remaster deserving of that title.

Which means we don't have to worry anymore about compatibility/performance issues like before with the original versions.

We can also say goodbye to the hassle of downloading and installing each DLC separately (remember that ME2 has a ton of DLCs) because EA did not include those in the old "Deluxe" edition versions, which is just what you would expect from EA....

Something of great value too and worth mentioning is that all the mods I can think of that are considered "must" while also being vanilla friendly have been ported to this edition as well.

And trust me, even for those who are not "mod friendly" I would still encourage them to take a look at Nexus mods. 
It is well worth the effort just for the sheer amount of quality stuff there is to improve the experience and add things that we can argue should've been there in the first place.

There also seem to be quite a fair amount of bugs from the originals that carried over to this edition, so even if you're not friendly with modding I would still advice to at least check the Community Patches. 

I would go as far as to say they're mandatory if you want to experience this trilogy with the minimum amount of bugs and with all the improvements and love the community has given to these games.

But what about the actual games, you might ask? Well, I'll let you experience that for yourself. No it's not that I'm lazy. Well, I am, but I also don't feel like spoiling any details. 

It's just what I did back then 10 years ago when I first played Mass Effect; I jumped in completely blind, and was wholly rewarded for that!

This is Commander Shepard, calling in from the Normandy. I've taken a moment from my duties—battling Reapers, uniting species, and sometimes deciding the fate of entire planets—to bring you my report on "Mass Effect Legendary Edition."

Having lived through the original journey, saving the galaxy from the brink of extinction, this remastered edition is like reliving my greatest hits—and the low points—with sharper visuals and smoother combat. It's a chance to retrace the path of the Shepard you choose to be, with every decision, every alliance, and every sacrifice rendered in stunning detail.

The Legendary Edition stitches together a tapestry of a universe so vast, so alive with lore and heart, it’s as if you could reach out and feel the heat of Tuchanka’s sun or the cold sterility of the Cerberus labs. The relationships I've forged—whether friendships or rivalries—now resonate with renewed clarity, the bonds forged in fire and starlight stronger in high definition.

For newcomers to the Normandy, welcome aboard. You're about to embark on a saga that'll challenge your ethics, your strategy, and your capacity for compassion. For veterans, it’s a polished return to a beloved universe, where every enhanced texture and tune rekindles the embers of past glories.

However, not every FTL jump is smooth. The journey can sometimes be hindered by remnants of old design, a stark reminder of the trilogy's origins in a previous era of gaming.

This report concludes with a personal note: "Mass Effect Legendary Edition" is my most beloved in the armory. It’s the saga at its best, a chance to relive my story, our story, with the reverence it deserves. We were born to do this.

Played ME1 not too long after it came out in 2007, and ME2 not long after that.  Now, some dozen-odd years later, we have Legendary Edition.  I'm excited to play through them again. review is based on 13 hours of ME1, and what I remember of ME1 and ME2 from years ago.  I have not yet played ME3.

TLDR: A 9/10 for its day, and still a solid 7/10 or better.

PROs:
   - Novel combat mechanics.
   - Balanced and satisfying combat (on normal difficulty)
   - Scalable combat difficulty
   - Good story.
   - Great voice acting.
   - Good sound.
   - Great RPG mechanics.
   - Varied and interesting NPCs join your team.
   - Well done cut-scenes, of appropriate length and frequency.
   - Cut-scenes reflect who is really in your party at that time.
   - Neat "dialogue wheel" mechanic
   - AI (friend and foe) tactical behavior reasonable for 2007.
   - Good art
   - Non-irritating music.
   - There is romance to be had if you make careful dialogue choices.

CONs:
   - Conversation branches can sometimes be repeated. If selected by mistake, you get to listen to the excellent voice acting twice.
   - Sometimes getting around the Citadel seems like a walking simulator.
   - Searching planets in ME1 can get old by the time the game is done. (ME2 is better.)

I may be the last person on Earth to play the Mass Effect series, which begs the question of who I'm writing this review for.

But this trilogy is really extraordinary. Almost* without exception, the writing is outstanding. The alien races are wonderful. Their stories are brilliant and frequently moving. The voice acting is all top-notch. The unpopular original ending of ME3 is the stuff of legends, and it's still there.  I can understand why people would have been furious at it at the time, but the improvements they made for this edition left me reasonably satisfied. All I will say about the ending is this: I'm so sorry, Jack.

I do think that ME2 is the highlight of the series from a main story standpoint.

The extra EA launcher is definitely gross, and I could probably reinstall my computer and still not be totally convinced it's completely gone. But at least I didn't have any of the problems getting things to load like others have reported. The game was smooth and more or less bug free. I experienced maybe one crash in 120+ hours of gameplay.

I played as an Infiltrator and the gunplay was highly enjoyable throughout all three games, despite the differences between them. Many game systems seem to get simpler from one game to the next, which is weird. Usually things get more complicated as a series progresses.

*Almost. The "romance" in the first two games is utterly cringe-worthy. (I'm aware this is a minority opinion. Don't @ me.) I was essentially gaslit into a relationship that I never wanted in the first game, and in both the first and second game, displaying basic courtesy toward most members of the appropriate gender results in a harem fighting over you. The heavy-handed nature of it was such a shock compared to the deft writing of the rest of the game. But I was extremely pleased to have a very different experience in ME3 where Shepard was finally able to develop meaningful non-romantic friendships with opposite-gender characters. The stuff in the Citadel DLC was particularly good. (And, as an aside, Grunt at the party is one of greatest scenes in gaming.)

All in all, despite small flaws, this is an extraordinary game and its echos can still be felt today. I recommend it without hesitation.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition review with no spoilers.

First of all, the story is brilliant.  It is worth playing just to see the story unfold.  These kinds of games with cutscenes in them are like playing a part in a movie to me.  And the movie was outstanding.

Second.  I played this game on linux.  Electronic Arts does not make it easy.  Sometimes suddenly the game would not start.  Removing all the compdata for that game and re-verifying the game files seemed to get the game operational again without losing my progress.  If they haven't fixed the problem and you are playing on linux it helped to disable everything you can in the EA Game Overlay or disable it entirely if you can figure out how.

The balance of the game is good.  Easy is pretty easy, you can pretty much sit back and enjoy the show.  The AI is good.  Your teammates will back you up sufficiently but hang back and let handle plenty of enemies at the same time.

I got the Legendary Edition with all DLCs on sale on Steam and I HIGHLY recommend this game.  I don't know how you get a superstar like Martin Sheen to play the "Illusive Man" but he was brilliant of course.

All the DLC content is well integrated into the game.  You could hardly differentiate the DLC content from the original game.

Things that could use improvement:

I've never seen game designers that don't want their content to be seen.  In this game, the designer does not make it easy to find everything there is that can be done.  They seem to think that people don't mind wandering helplessly all over the galaxy map to find these objectives.  They are wrong. 

Thus they inadvertently hide content from players.  For instance you will get a message claiming there is something to be done on so and so planet but it may not tell you the cluster and/or system the planet is in.  This one simple addition to all communcation on what needs to be done would be much appreciated.

Mass Effect 3:
The Armax Arsenal Arena DLC is great for testing your gear and your teammates behavior.  Necessary because the weapons rating system is weak.  Instead of giving you numbers like this weapon holds 6 rounds with a force of 100N each they give you a bar which isn't even accurate.  They give you an information icon to find out information on weapons you already own but NOT those for sale.  The information is flowery but lacking actually useful detail also as above.

Mass Effect was the result of Bioware taking their lessons from KotOR and channelling it into their own IP. It's one of the greatest gaming experiences I ever had, especially as someone who began with the third game and ended up playing through three times to try to save specific people and get different outcomes for major developments. Finally being able to do so was one of the best feelings I had in gaming.

Even outside of that, the story is ambitious, the points land, the final mission of the second game is one of the greatest missions of all time, and nobody is spared extensive characterisation that the DLC (all included in this release) expand on brilliantly. This is a game that genuinely has everything. You can see the influence games like Gears of War had on the third game - for the better, where the combat was nearly perfected short of some annoying instances of input.

It's also rare I'll say this but the Steam Achievements for this game are perfect too. I played from Mass Effect four times before this release, but the Achievements for this one forced me to learn and perfect aspects of the games that I had neglected before. By the end of the game I felt like an absolute God, and that I had genuinely mastered Mass Effect - so great decision by all involved there. Achievements that don't just reward you for completion but also act as an expert-level tutorial are the perfect kind, in my opinion.

A lot of criticism has been given to the ending of this one, with some citing previous drafts as possibly superior, other's lamenting that it didn't hold up to (sometimes explicitly stated) promises. Let me say without any spoilers that I think the ending is completely in keeping with the overall themes of this game, and is fully worth the journey. I only wish the Leviathan DLC was better integrated into it.

If you're a sci-fi fan, buy this game. If you're a role playing fan, buy this game. If you love a good story, buy this game. If you love a decent tactical shooter, buy this game. If you love a good time. Buy. This. Game. You will NOT regret it.

If you’ve never played Mass Effect before, I am deeply jealous. You have an incredible experience ahead of you. I’d give a great deal to be able to play this for the first time again.

This is actually a really easy review to write, because I’m in no danger of overselling things. This is the finest space opera ever written (yeah, I’d rate it higher than Star Wars). It’s the most influential RPG of the last twenty years (yeah, I’d rate it higher than Skyrim). I’ve played it four or five times. I am certain that you’ll love this game.

I have a single piece of advice for newcomers - play as female Shepard. Jennifer Hale’s voice acting is iconic, her range and talent perfectly expressing the incredibly varied emotions demanded by the complicated storyline. Male Shepards are voiced by Mark Meer, and props to him for a good effort, but he just doesn’t compare.

For those of you that already own the Mass Effect games in some form or another, this is a far more difficult product to recommend. The problem is that this isn’t a very good remaster - more of a convenient bundle. The original games still hold up just fine, so unless you have an obsession with graphics, why buy this?

Beyond that, there are quite a few technical issues - squad powers frequently glitch, and I got stuck on more ladders than was comfortable. Most egregiously, buying this on Steam forces you to go through the always-unpopular EA launcher. This is a fairly dodgy offering by modern remaster standards - look at something like the Master Chief Collection, and the paucity of this product becomes apparent. It simply doesn’t fit the price tag.

Still, this is Mass Effect, all in one place and ready to be played through all over again. I couldn’t resist it, and odds are good that you can’t either.

I'm writing this review after finishing ME1 and will update this as I complete ME2 and ME3. I will review them separately to hopefully properly inform you about the legendary edition. I intend to 100% the trilogy.

[b] ME1 [/b]
It's an old game, it has a lot of design flaws that are extremely obvious, but the story is worth playing it through IMO. There's a lot to hate and a lot to love, so i'll make a list of it for ease of reading.

Like:
- The story is great. Most characters are unique and have interesting back stories, and the way the story is built up both creates closure for the first game and sets up the story for the second game. I'm convinced you play ME1 for the story first, gameplay second.
- Enemy diversity is pretty decent for such an old game. I liked fighting all enemies, there were none that felt more annoying than fun.
- Voice acting. Everything is voiced.
- Weapon customization is pretty good, there's plenty of mods and ammo types for different gun types etc. Some are very noticable, some are useless.

Dislike:
- Vehicle movement is horrible. The fact that you need to drive a lot to get to POIs and collectables doesn't help.
- Inventory management isn't the best, and in the later parts of the game the loot becomes irrelevant, even on the highest difficulty.
- A lot of repeated room layouts. There are, if I remember correctly, only 2 different layouts for most POIs that are not main story related. There's boxes and stuff to make the routes different, but the maps are all the same.
- No way to revert skill points.

It took me 35 hours to beat with all ME1 related achievements. Some of them are annoying, but none are a real grind and they all have ways to easily grind them out within 20 to 30 minutes. There's no way of tracking your progress in these achievements which makes grinding annoying as you don't know when something triggered or not, but it's still doable.

[b] ME2 [/b]
My god, what an improvement over the first game. Playing ME1 is definitely worth it for the story, but also to make ME2 that much better. A lot of systems are redesigned, some better and some worse, but it just plays and feels awesome. Can’t wait to see how ME3 turns out.

Like:
Story continues from ME1. A lot of choices you make in ME1 and ME2 have results in the form of messages you get in your private terminal on the Normandy, which makes you feel like your actions matter.
Combat feels great, enemy variation is good, highest difficulty level actually has some tougher moments in this game.
No more mandatory vehicle gameplay! It’s still in the game, but completely optional. I skipped a lot of the vehicle related missions and still got all the achievements.
I loved the focus on teambuilding. Made me learn a lot about every one of the 12(!) companions. They’re all unique and interesting.
Skill point remapping. Good.

Dislike:
Weapon customization is dumbed down a lot. You can choose different weapons, but that’s it.
Farming materials via scanning planets is a grind I did not enjoy. I fixed this by downloading a mod to speed up the process, but it should be enjoyable without mods.
No minimap for most areas is a shame. Also, no keybinding for opening the journal to quickly check quests.

It took me another 35 hours to finish ME2. This includes all achievements but skips some DLC/side missions that did not get my interest. Also, trackers for achievements exist now, which helps.
