Well now. As someone who disdains Nu Bioware, loathes EA, and has bottomless contempt for the idea that games need to be retooled for the sensitivities of a modern audience less than a decade after their original release, I pretty much expected my review to be simply, "Should have just called it 'M Effect' because they got rid of the ass. >:("

But the anticipated bowdlerization turned out to be extremely minimal. Barely noticeable even if you're looking for it, honestly. The bigger impediment to my enjoyment by far was the mandatory and spitefully inept EA App, which occasionally annoyed me by eating my Steam achievements and several times exasperated me by refusing to launch the game at all, sometimes for hours. Also lamentable was the exclusion of Mass Effect 3's multiplayer which, despite having come out at a time when so many single player focused games included a multiplayer mode as a mere box checking exercise, bucked that trend by being thoughtfully integrated into the game's overall galaxy at war premise as well as just being a whole lot of fun. I'm rather ambivalent about the reworking of the first game's shooting mechanics. While I did enjoy being able to more smoothly pop in and out of cover and devastate enemies with headshots, the purist in me would actually have preferred a more faithful warts-and-all rendering, and yet another part of me is still just sitting here thinkin' 'bout Matriarch Benezia's fat, veiny Blue Suns, so whatever.

Gripes aside, all in all I found it a very decent way to revisit a classic if uneven trilogy and can give it a cautious recommendation. Maybe not at full asking price, but you're probably okay to grab it on sale for 14.99 Weimar Amerikanmarks or your local equivalent, which you frequently can do.

[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Mass Effect: Legendary Edition"[/h1]

Después de trabajar en [b]Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic[/b], el equipo de [b]BioWare[/b] se sintió tentado a elaborar su propia ópera espacial abundante en lore y argumento, y con toda la experiencia acumulada en tantos años liderando el género [b]CRPG[/b] supieron dar lugar a una de las franquicias más reconocidas de su década.

Poco había (Y sigue habiendo) en los videojuegos que represente con tanta fidelidad a este subgénero de la ciencia ficción, y mucho menos que destace por tal peso narrativo. Vas a notar diferencias mecánicas sutiles entre cada título, pero en términos generales son tan similares que me parece perfecto haberlos acumulado en esta Edición Legendaria que, además, los remasteriza sin trastocar aquello que los hizo tan especiales.

[b]Mass Effect[/b] cuenta con uno de los universos más ricos y abundantes en diversidad folclórica disponibles en el medio, cada especie tiene sus hábitos y se destacan de forma consistente y cohesiva a lo largo de los tres títulos. Escenarios como [b]Omega[/b] o la [b]Ciudadela[/b] son muy interesantes de investigar y explorar en búsqueda de alguna mejora o algún diálogo, y hasta leer el códice o las notas repartidas por el mapa tiene su interés.

Y al igual que con el campamento en el futuro [b]Dragon Age: Origins[/b], la [b]Normandy[/b] funge como un centro común para nuestro pelotón y miembros, con quienes podemos interactuar, ayudar, mejorar nuestra relación, prepararnos para su respectiva misión de lealtad o comenzar un romance, que tienden a ser historias de intimidad muy interesantes y que, al igual que gran parte de las decisiones clave, son exportadas a los juegos posteriores para continuar con tu mismo personaje.

Con respecto al rol, éste no se ve particularmente reflejado en los eventos clave del argumento. Los grandes acontecimientos van a fluir sin importar qué, sin embargo tus decisiones impactan en el modo en que esto ocurra y tu lugar como jugador define esencialmente [b]quién es tu Shepard[/b], si sereno o agresivo, de quién se enamora y cómo opera junto a qué pelotón, a quienes puede llegar a perder en ciertos momentos si no tomamos las decisiones correctas. Si bien no vamos a vivir experiencias sumamente distantes como si de [b]Detroit: Become Human[/b] se tratase, [b]Mass Effect[/b] sí logra que las buenas o malas decisiones sean compensadas o castigadas dentro de su universo y que esto se conserve a lo largo de los tres juegos.

Por desgracia hay varios aspectos que quizá podrían haber sido modernizados en esta nueva edición.

[list]
    [*][b]El combate y los tiroteos.[/b]
[/list] 
Continúan siendo emocionantes y únicos gracias a la customización del armamento y los poderes, pero los tiroteos continúan toscos, propios del 2007, a ratos incluso carentes de feedback. Por otras parte, la acción también puede provocar una sensación de repetitividad. Por mucho que adore las misiones de lealtad de Mass Effect 2, su estructura es [u]narrativa > tiroteo > narrativa[/u].
[list]
    [*][b]Las animaciones.[/b]
[/list]
El trabajo de animaciones corporales es fabuloso, pero por momentos se nota el uso forzado de animaciones repetidas. La expresiones faciales también son extrañas, habitualmente tiesas, pero considerando que son juegos bastante longevos es fascinante lo mucho que lograron con tan poco y lo rápido que se te olvida.
[list]
    [*][b]Puntos clave débiles y recursos narrativos pobres.[/b]
[/list]
No me malinterpreten. [b]Mass Effect[/b] es una maravilla sin igual en lo que a argumento, narrativa y trama respecta; no obstante no se salva de un par de momentos de debilidad, como [spoiler]el viaje de [b]Shepard[/b] antes de la misión suicida en [b]Mass Effect 2[/b], mientras que [b]Joker[/b] prepara el [b]Reaper IFF[/b], que convenientemente deja a la [b]Normandy[/b] sin nuestra disposición para combatir la invasion que da lugar al secuestro del personal de la nave[/spoiler].
[list]
    [*][b]Algunas falsas decisiones.[/b]
[/list]
Existe un par de decisiones que sugieren ser de gran importancia para futuros acontecimientos, sólo para terminar siendo irrelevantes, tal como [spoiler]la decisión final de destruir [b]la base de los Segadores[/b] o entregársela a [b]Cerberus[/b][/spoiler] o [spoiler]la poca importancia de tus decisiones en el infame final de [b]Mass Effect 3[/b][/spoiler].

Importante destacar que algunos de los DLCs (Obviamente incorporados en esta edición) son fabulosos, no podría imaginarme a [b]Mass Effect 2[/b] sin "[b]Lair of the Shadow Broker[/b]", por ejemplo.

También hay otros puntos minúsculos para comentar, como la imposibilidad de enfundar el arma y la desaparición del pirateo/derivación en [b]Mass Effect 3[/b] o lo fascinante del diseño e historia de todos los acompañantes de [b]Mass Effect 2[/b]; pero ya estamos entrando en terreno pantanoso del que sólo se puede hablar con constantes spoilers y la idea es disfrutar de esta trilogía legendaria por cuenta propia.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Indispensable para cualquier fanático del rol y la ciencia ficción, una trilogía inolvidable.

Mass Effect is possibly the best first person rpg ever made. The graphics are amazing and the performance is spotless, even on a Voodoo 3. The combat is good, even if it does 'borrow' quite a lot from Gears of War.

Or rather, that was the review when the game came out in 2007. If you have only played Anthem and wondered what the big fuss was about, this is what you have been missing. (And Baldur's gate ... and KOTOR ... and ...)

So how does it hold up today? The answer is pretty well, actually. You will feel hampered by the constraints of that time. Jump onto things? Nope. You see that big exciting thing in the background? Nope, you can't explore it. It's not open world, you are guided through passages.

But the combat is still good, the graphics are still brilliant. And the story? Oh, so much story. This still remains the best Space Opera RPG ever made. The world building, the side stories, and the villains, seriously, those villains...

A comparison can probably be made with Game Of Thrones. Huge cast. Beautiful production values. Great story telling, and an ending that makes you go "WTF? They made me wait all these years for ... this???" I believe the main writer was changed between episode 2 and 3, and it shows.

Still, it's a thrill and it's one of the all time greats. If you haven't played it before, you should play it now. There really is no reason not to.

This game reaches into your heart and pumps it full of life and rips it apart all at the same time. Individually, each game has simplistic writing, but when played as a whole, the cumulative impact of each decision you made is felt throughout the series. You saved some rando in ME1? They have something for you in ME2 or ME3. Bioware did a great job tying things toGETHer. 10/10 story, 6/10 gameplay. The story of the series is better for me than witcher 3 + dlc, and that's a tall order. I would also argue that ME is better than star wars in the sci-fi setting. 

You will feel the age of the series in ME1. it was an absolute struggle to finish ME1, but well worth it. For me, the fact that you can fully customize the weapons and armor of all your companions was great, just poorly implemented. They also give you too much medkits. The biggest shit stain in ME1 is exploring the planets, and running out of stamina while in a safe zone. Seriously, why make on-foot travelling so hassle?

By the time I got to ME2, the quality of life changes are great. They simplified equipment, and instead made upgrades a pain in the ass by adding resources. At least majority of the places you visit has a fuel station so you can travel to each system and scan for materials. I think I spent just as much time, if not more, scanning planets for materials, than shooting aliens. Gunplay and general mechanics are the same, but they did change how health works. No more 40k medkits lying around, you just regain health. Medkits are still used, but to revive allies. The gap between ME1 and ME2 is huge. By far the best improvements to writing and character dialogue. This game had the most companions of the series, and the best 


ahh ME3. What a blast. I'm not a fan the new health system, and the cover system fucked me over a few times, but nothing deal-breaking. Endings were implemented a little poorly, but I am satisfied with the epilogues. No more resources, thank fuck, and a little more customization with weapons and armor. Good balance with what ME1 and ME2 had. Gun play and general mechanics are still the same.

За всю серію певно 7 з 10. 
Велика сага, прописаний світ і приємні компаньйони. І фінал... Якого краще б не було.

Подібних речей мало. Згадується недавнішня Брама Балдура 3 і всього.

Окремо по частинам:

МЕ1 (7 з 10): вступ в сагу, динамічний, з декількома сильними моментами і вцілому прописаним світом.
Навіть умовний Мако мені сподобався - прикольна перебивка між стрільбою і є шо про досліджувати - покататись. 

Хоча звісно це анахронічний дизайн і певні рішення в бойовій системі просто не працють.

МЕ2 (9.9 з 10): гра про тих самих + нових компаньйонів. Вони дуже вписані в світ і з ним перетинаються, аналогічно як один з одним. Багато приємних діалогів і ігролад довели майже до піку його можливостей.

Мінуси банальні - деякі шмати інтерфейсу по типу: ромаснів чи вікі в діалогаїх краще б мати. А то запам'ятати якогосб чела з рандомної планети якого я врятував в першій частині - складно.

МЕ3 (3 з 10): ну бойовка на піку, режисура на піку, візуал теж. 

Але ВСІ вибори гра зводить на нівець. 
Деякі компаньйони не мають продовження історії - суто обрубок і живи з тим.
Фінал і взагалі спосіб вирішення проблеми Ріперів... Ну без матів - поганий, просто тупий, нецікавий, затичка і т.п.

Могла бути б найкраща ігрова серія, навіть якшо брати максимально низкі очікування, ну поганий фінал. Для гри, що трималась на прописанності світу і напарниках - прям ппц погано все зводити до просто "ну ок фільм на 30 годин".

This is one of the best games out there. To judge just how good it is, I challenge you to find at least one negative review that is complaining about the game itself and not about the EA Launcher (you will likely have a hard time).

Story, characters, gameplay, music, visuals are all great. The assembly of the three games into one is very smooth and plays almost like a single game. This game makes you think about big questions, what's important on the grand scale, and how one person can change the fate of the whole galaxy. Many people find the ending(s) controversial, but I found it very fitting.

You know that time when you play a game, and after some point you just want to finish it and start paying less attention / possibly skipping some conversations? Well, for this one, I only got that feeling near the end of my second playthrough, which is a lot of hours in (200+?).

"Mass Effect: Legendary Edition" is a remaster that brings the iconic trilogy back to life, and as a veteran of the original games, I'll focus this review on the remastered experience. If you wish you can check my review for [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/17460?snr=1_5_9__402]Mass Effect[/url] and my review for [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/2362420?snr=1_5_9__402]Mass Effect 2[/url], where I "talk" about Mass Effect & Mass Effect 2 as "whole" games.(unfortunately I have no Mass Effect 3 review, since I own it on EA App, not Steam, and there's no way, at the moment when I am writing this, for one to review a game there, but you can check my [url=https://www.metacritic.com/user/Ciocolici]Metacritic profile[/url], and search for the Mass Effect 3 review)

The improvements in "Mass Effect: Legendary Edition" are extensive and commendable. The first game, Mass Effect 1, receives a major gameplay overhaul, and all three games benefit from impressive visual upgrades and bug fixes. While the remaster enhances the overall experience, there are still some issues worth mentioning, which I've compiled into a detailed guide for fellow players to optimize their gameplay. I highly suggest you [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2583863570]check it out[/url].

One glaring omission is the lack of a FOV slider in a 2021 remaster, a feature that modders quickly provided as a fix. I find it puzzling that BioWare didn't include such a basic option. Additionally, the EA App Overlay negatively impacts performance in ME:LE, a frustrating carryover from the original games.

Remastering the ME trilogy posed a unique challenge, considering the extensive modding done by the community. However, BioWare managed to surpass expectations by delivering a remaster that not only matches the originals but also outshines the heavily-modded versions.

Mass Effect 1, in particular, stands out with its stunning visual overhaul. The game's environments are breathtaking, and the reworked Mako adds a new level of enjoyment to planetary exploration. The cinematics have been vastly improved, though I did have some reservations about certain character appearances. Nonetheless, the overall transformation is impressive.

However, despite the enhancements, there are still lingering issues, such as stuttering in certain areas like the Citadel. Although it doesn't ruin the experience, it's a disappointment to encounter such technical hiccups in an otherwise polished remaster. Additionally, planetary exploration with the Mako sometimes triggers FPS drops due to what seems like optimization problems.

Mass Effect 2 also benefits from visual upgrades, even if it didn't receive as much attention as the first game. The removal of Black Crush enhances the game's visuals, though I wish the cinematics had received a bit more polish to maintain continuity with the first game. Nevertheless, ME2 still looks significantly better than the original version, despite some new instances of stuttering and FPS loss.

As for Mass Effect 3, it didn't require as many improvements, but the overall enhancements make a difference in the gameplay experience. The better textures and lighting elevate the visuals, providing a satisfying remastered experience. However, I encountered unexpected FPS drops on the Citadel after a particular mission, and the Silversun Strip also suffered from FPS loss and stuttering.

Despite these performance issues, "Mass Effect: Legendary Edition" remains the best way to experience this beloved trilogy. It's an outstanding remaster that showcases a considerable amount of effort, particularly in Mass Effect 1. Plus, it comes at a significantly lower price than the original trilogy with all its DLCs included.

For achievement hunters: the game 127 achievements. Many from the original games, some changed to be easier (I am looking at you ME1). Doing the achievements in ME:LE is way easier than in the original games, for some of the achievements at least. Still, it is not an easy task, but if you love Mass Effect, you will have a blast doing them. And unlike the original ME1 and ME2, ME:LE has them integrated on Steam. Hooray!

While the removal of a specific ME1 DLC and the multiplayer aspect in ME3 may be debatable, it doesn't detract from the overall appeal of "Legendary Edition". But the bad optimization/fps issues in some areas are something that has to be fixed, and I am sure it will with future patches. Whether you're a new player or revisiting the trilogy, "Mass Effect: Legendary Edition" is the definitive way to enjoy this unparalleled gaming experience. The trilogy's remarkable narrative and captivating gameplay have stood the test of time, making "Legendary Edition" a must-play for all fans of the Mass Effect universe.

I played the first one on day one (technically, I played it before day one because at the time of release, K-Mart was still open and it made the game available in stores a week early. The ol’ Wild West of retail lol). I probably poured around 1,000 hours in the first two games getting all the possible outcomes, leveling up, getting all achievements, etc. 
Then the third game came out. I only played through it once or twice. I really got into the multiplayer, and while I didn’t think the ending was as bad as the internet made it out to be, I did feel very empty when replaying the third game. 
Then the legendary edition came out, and I fell in love all over again. So many things happen in the third came that really seal the deal on so many plot threads and so many character arcs. The combat is better than ever, and quite honestly, it’s better than quite a few games that are still being released today. I got chills, I gasped, and was shocked. It came from a game that I had played like 10 years ago and somehow after all that it still felt new and fresh. Above all, it felt satisfying. You got to love it, gentlemen! 

Disclaimer: I will be eternally grateful that sh*tty EA allowed for there to be as much work done to the first game. These are just some things I wish they could’ve done. 

ME2 forcing zoom while in cover during combat instead of having a blind fire or just a pop out and shoot without the camera zooming in has always bothered me a lot. It didn’t do it in the OG ME1 so I don’t think it’s ever been intentional. The mini game stuff and power cool down stuff can be taken care of with mods. I wish there was a mod for the one thing. 

The other thing is color filter rendering modes that are available in photo modes would be awesome if we could just leave them in at all times. Every single-player game should have this as a standard. It really helps keep environments fresh on that 20th play through. 

The other thing has been touched by virtually everyone. Multiplayer. I would pay to have Mass Effect 3 multiplayer as a DLC. (Don’t worry, I’m ready for the hate.) 

No matter what, I’m happy I was able to experience these games again!

I've played the original MEs 1-3 through at least twice and really enjoyed them, for what they were at the time.

I bought the Legendary Edition because is was "remastered and optimized for 4K Ultra HD" (I game at 1080p) thinking that, after all this time, they'd at least update the game engine (game play) and the previous games (MEs 1 & 2) would be brought up to the level of ME3.  Well, I was wrong.

As far as I can tell, this is only a visual update.  It is pretty nice, but definitely not worth the full $60 release price.

All of the game play issues of ME 1 & 2 are still there (getting stuck in ME1 so that you'd have to load an old save to continute), movement issues (ME 1 & 2), etc.  ME 3 still plays like ME3 did, but it, at least, had the best gameplay.

If you can get this on sale at 50% or more off, it probably would be worth picking up.  It is currently on sale for 80% off, which, to me, is a no-brainer.

Anyway, it was fun to play through again, but it'll probably be the last time for at least a long time (until I get nostalgic again a few years from now), if ever.

For what it is, I'll recommend this game, but not at full price.  If they had brought the game play of MEs 1 & 2 up to the standard of ME3, then I'd wholeheartedly recommend it, but they didn't.  IMO, they treated it more as, "Let's update the textures to 4K and improve the colors a bit... DONE!" money-grab than an effort to really "remaster" it.  Surely, it couldn't have taken THAT much more to update the gameplay/game engine in the earlier versions to justify the $60 release price.

Anyway, the bottom line is I recommend it... but only at the right price.

I did not play these games when they originally came out and based upon all the hype and my love of classic games these have been on my must play list for some time. Get the legendary edition on sale win win.

However be warned despite the tags saying "RPG", "Story Rich" and "Choices Matter" these games are none of these things.

Let's take these one at a time.

RPG. So starting to play either 1 or 2 you start off and the games feel a lot like Knights of the Old Republic. It's a Bioware game so they are building on a great legacy. Fantastic KOTOR is one of the best games ever made. I am going to love this. So all the ship based and any non mission based planetary play are good. You get to move around pick up missions buy stuff and talk to people. So far so RPG. sadly once the missions start these games expose their true nature. This is a cover shooter pure and simple. It is not a very good cover shooter and sadly if you are not a fan then you are in for a long ride. The biggest problem is that you are taken out of cover for apparently no reason but on top of that your squad AI is so bad that about 20% of the time you will be shooting allies and believe me they will complain. The next problem is that the game starts off giving the impression that this is a save anywhere game. It is on PC so yes finally a PC port which does not suffer from it's console parent. Well they fooled me again. Once on a mission you are back to checkpoints. You get to save once in a while and if you die right before a checkpoint back you go to do the same thing over and over again. This had me turn down the difficulty not because the game was hard but just because I didn't like shooting my party in the back of the head and then dying only to repeat more of the same repetitive game play again. If you wanted to not play a cover shooter. Tough it is the only way to play this game.

Story Rich. LOL. I don't expect my video games to be life changing. I don't expect them to be full of nuance. It is supposed to be fun after all. But the hype around this game was massive. Many people saying it has the best story ever and it affected them a lot. DO NOT BELIEVE THE HYPE. If you have read any sci fi then this will probably leave you cold. part 1 is OK in this respect. I sort of got what I was expecting. It is very much your Star Trek Planet of Hats trope. You have your war alien. You have your spec ops alien you have your science alien and you have you sex alien. Nothing wrong with that a lot of good science fictions uses these tropes well. Sadly the problem is that they went so far as to include non humanoid races. Sadly none of the non humanoid races are more than background colour. Every squad member or beyond card board cut out character has two arms two legs and presumably genitalia in the right place. so very yawn. Anyway I played Mass Effect 1 as a straight paragon. Which was actually a pretty good morality system. Gone is the Light Side Dark Side of KOTOR and we have paragon and renegade. No right or wrong choices...... Well at least until you play Mass Effect 2 where even though I am playing as a paragon it turns out I was playing it wrong. Whatever you do it seems you are railroaded into a renegade character. You are not really a commander in the military and whilst it fits the spectre moniker it really makes little difference in the end you are a pretty much a hard arse loose cannon who gets things done. Illusion of choice. Don't get me started on having to work for Cancer Man from the X-Files in Mass Effect 2. Control did it much better in a much more polished game.

Choices Matter. Well this review is already too long and I will probably only play Mass Effect 3 for the achievements so maybe choices will matter in that game (although as most people seemed to hate it I suspect not) With my 50 hours in the game I can only really tell that one choice mattered and that is in the first game and will determine the fate of one character. As far as I can tell the choice only matters based upon maybe a couple of missions and some small cameo appearance in Mass effect 2. So more "1 Choice" matters but not that much.

Conclusions. 4 / 10
It is kind of like James Bond in space. Do a mission, kiss the girl, save the world. Enough if you are 13 but not really enough to scratch a Sci Fi RPG itch.

If you want some great classic game action I would recommend lots of other games/series which are as old or older. Why not try KOTOR, TES3 Morrowind or The Witcher. All are better than this.

It was my first time in ME, since for some reasons I didn't have an opportunity to check this trilogy out when it was initially released. So, It was an amazing experience, but with some nuances especially taking into account that this game is pretty old and some mechanics feels odd or outdated now.

So ME1 seemed to me as vacuum cleaner simulator, since all that you're doing there - is travelling around absolutely the same rooms/hangars/corridors and cleaning'em out. Sometimes driving space all terrain vehicle and getting through the mountains to get to another room/hangar/restroom to clean it out as well.

About ME2 I've heard that it the best part of the trilogy. But when I've completed it - my impression was a bit different. Basically, story line structure is worst then it was in NWN with its "find four words of power or in KOTOR with its "find four star maps", so in ME2 the structure is the following:
- intro (1 mission)
- assemble a team (6 missions)
- 2nd story mission (after intro)
- assemble a team a bit more (3 missions)
- ???
- the end

And it feels like "piss off with your desire to follow the story, and go talk the dumbasses to take part in it, and maybe we'll show you a cinematic in the end". All you do - is hanging out with your teammates, dating with your gf/bf, and gazing into infinity of space sipping another beer, and very rarely moving the story forward.

So, ME3 - it is Syberia (that old old quest, yes, lol) in more large locations, where you constantly poking around the locations or the planets, trying to find NPC or anything that could trigger some quest to progress. Quest descriptions are brief and doesn't have any updates after you've moved a bit further than initial instructions, and this is total crap. And only in this ME part I've noticed that when you change an armor - some stats also changes))) And also I've laughed out loud when the main story goal is to complete the space dildo, like it was in Austin Powers)))

But jokes aside, it was a great experience and a I've had a lot of fun going through the Shepard's story, despite a really old game mechanics that hadn't been updated in this trilogy edition (which is sad). But if someone still didn't check this trilogy out - just go an do it)

[h1] Overall: 7.5/10 [/h1] I have some mixed feels about this game, but if this where my first experience playing the ME series - I would absolutely love this graphically improved one. I enjoyed the new textures, but in the end of the day that's all this was, new textures - and I can't give this a higher review on a remaster where they don't even update the low poly models.
[h1] Graphics: 8/10 [/h1] Not as good as I'd hoped. Now don't get me wrong - it's a HUGE improvement over the first game, a decent improvement over the second - and a teensie tiny one in the third, but it's still the old low poly models with a better paint-job.
[h1] Performance: 4/10 [/h1] Absolutely awful, even though I have a pretty decent PC and managed to get over 80 fps most of the time - they would just plummet at random points for no god-damn reason.
[h1] Story&Characters: 9/10 [/h1] Still what I remember - and the highlight of these games, arguably the best story driven game I've played.
[h1] Movement/Combat: 5.5/10 [/h1] A spawn of Satan, just like the original. They fail to make a pleasant cover system - and it only worsens with each game. HOWEVER, the combat part of it can be quite entertaining with some cool combos and weapons.
[h1] Multiplayer: NONE [/h1] What a shame, the only thing they removed that people REALLY wanted. They could have taken one of the the side characters out and caused less fuss. It wasn't a problem for me though, I have no friends.

The general premise of the games is that they're light RPG third person shooters with some ability-centric squad management. First game starts off rather dry, gameplay-wise, with really odd design ideas of hybridizing RPGs and FPSes, like all the dropped by enemies gear is automatically put into your inventory but also there's limited inventory space and you gotta go trough each item. But it's got it's moments. Later on the gameplay gets smoother and more varied with each game. Say ME1 classes are three unique ability sets and then three hybrid classses - meanwhile starting ME2 they become their own thing, say previously merely engineer and soldier ability receiving infiltrators become actual infiltrators with stealth and means to beat enemies with surprise attacks and sniper rifles. The companions get unique abilities too, minigames and setpieces also get more varied.

The series bigger highlights are definitely making big choices which can be transferred to a new game even, and the worldbuilding. The choices are usually just two options and not that deep and complex as you'd expect from an RPG, but the way how they stack up creating extremely distinct stories is genuinely cool and really alters the story in major ways. Worldbuilding is also lovely, a detailed space opera with culturally distinct species with histories, coherent pseudoscience to justify scifi tech, and fun tidbits here and there.

Now, with later games most contentious elements was EA's brazen monetization and the underwhelming and rushed finale. Seeing how this one was reworked to feature ALL the DLCs (except one for ME1 whose source code was lost), including extended cut for story and cinematics and loads of goodies, it all feels rather... generous. Multiplayer and spinoff app usage isn't forced onto players either, anymore - which is good as both are dead. Unfortunately some seemingly ancient bugs still remain unfixed and probably were never a priority in the first place.

Definitely recommend this, hell of an experience. Just don't hesitate skipping most of ME1 planet landing side quests, they're very raw and mostly unsatisfying.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is the cultivation of all three original Mass Effect titles and their DLC with an attempt made to fix legacy bugs and improve upon the graphics of all three games. It has proven to be one of my favorite games of all time if not my favorite game of all time. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has considered playing Mass Effect or currently owns the original titles separately for a number of reasons. The first and most obvious reason is because this contains every last ounce of DLC besides a small fan favorite from the first Mass Effect game called Pinnacle station. Second, the improvement to graphics is noticeable and has set a new standard for remastered titles moving forward. Third, and most importantly to me, the developers went back and fixed as many legacy bugs as they could before launch. A game this size will always have bugs but it means so much to me that BioWare wanted to create the best possible image of their dream for a new generation of players. Thankfully, PC players have the gift of mods which add a new level or replay value for those who dabble in the occasional mod or two.

[h1] Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition [/h1]

When it comes to video game trilogies, there is hardly one that is as iconic and influential as the Mass Effect series. And with the release of the Legendary Edition, newcomers and returning fans can enjoy all three games in higher resolution textures and downloadable contents all in one convenient package. And although the game is mostly fine to enjoy on its own, I'd be remised not to recommend that you play it with mods. Because even though the Legendary Edition is a decent step up visually-wise for the trilogy, it still leaves plenty to be desired concerning everything else. I don't make that statement lightly, and it isn't meant to be inflammatory, it's simply the unfortunate truth. If you want the true Legendary Edition and experience the namesake of the title, and play the game in its best possible state, then the only way to get it is through modding. Fortunately for everyone, myself included, installing mods for Mass Effect Legendary Edition is almost as easy as hating Batarians. As someone who's had experience installing mods for games such as Fallout: New Vegas, Skyrim, and Dragon Age to name a few, Mass Effect has to be the easiest and most painless modding experience I've ever had. 

Thankfully, a fan who goes by the name of SyntheticSyndicate on NexusMods had already done the bulk of the work for us. He created a beginner-friendly modding guide where he'd aggregate the best mods and quality-of-life improvements on the site into a single, mostly, comprehensive collection. It's convenient, easy to understand, and very well organized. Here's the link to his guide for your convenience: [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffectlegendaryedition/mods/1127] Modding Guide (and Mod Collection) for Legendary Edition [/url]

As much as I love that guide, there are several other mods I'd like to bring to your attention that wasn't included which I strongly feel should be. This is exactly why I've taken it upon myself to create a companion/supplement guide to the main one for you to use. I've put a lot of work into it, and I hope you find it useful: 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2964349289

Another issue I'd like to address is how players are forced to use EA's terrible proprietary platform, Origins, if they want to play, even if the platform is terribly designed and riddled with bugs. One of which is currently preventing players from earning achievements. It's a problem that has existed ever since the game launched and despite promising to get it fixed, it persists even today. It's a problem that many players had to deal with including me, and it's extremely annoying and inconvenient. Thankfully, there is a clean and easy workaround for this problem. There are many guides detailing the steps, but I found this to be the most reliable and effective. If you're a new player, be sure to follow it before you start playing. It's worked for me many times, and I think it'll work for you too.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2992866639

With that out of the way, how do I feel about the actual games themselves? All I can say is it's been legendary. I've been a massive fan of the series since 2012 and revisiting it after ten years has been incredibly exciting, emotional, and rewarding. Each game has its many strengths and weaknesses, but the one trait all of them share is unbridled passion and creativity. Each fully deserving of their own review but for the sake of time and real estate, an insightful but quick analysis will have to do. 

[h1] Mass Effect [/h1]

The first Mass Effect used to be the black sheep of the family. It was referred to by many as the gatekeeper of the series and with good reasons. Despite its strong story and characters, the clunky gameplay and rapidly aging graphics were becoming increasingly evident as the generation progresses. However, that's no longer the case with the Legendary Edition. With mods, I had the time of my life with this game. With all of the rough edges polished, the excellent plot, likable characters, and amazing lore were able to shine through like never before seen. To my absolute shock and delight, It went from being my least favorite to my second favorite game in the series, and the only reason it didn't take that top spot is because of the game I'm going to talk about next.  

[h1] Mass Effect 2 [/h1]

Otherwise known as the Crème de la crème of the series, it should come as no surprise to anyone that Mass Effect 2 is my favorite game out of the three, and so often the case with many others, and one only has to play a few hours to begin to understand why so many fans hold it in such high regard. A simple but effective plot gives us a strong goal to work toward, an incredibly memorable and well-written cast of characters, a darker and seedier approach to the tone of the galaxy, the enigmatic and charismatic Illusive Man played flawlessly by Martin Sheen, a more refined and streamlined approach to the gameplay, and what you have in the end is a game that epitomizes everything of what a true sequel should be. Whatever weaknesses it has is profoundly outweighed by the positives, and ten years later I'm thrilled to say that Mass Effect 2 is still one of my favorite games of all time. 

[h1] Mass Effect 3 [/h1]

Where do I begin with this game? On one hand, it has some of the best writing and iconic moments in the entire series. And on the other, some of the most nonsensical, insulting, and downright baffling writing and design choices I've ever seen. One moment you want to sing to the choir about how good the game is, and the next you wonder whether the writing team collectively suffered a massive stroke and were forced to hire chimpanzees to complete the story halfway through. In all seriousness, Mass Effect 3 is the product of a team who worked themselves tirelessly to the brink of physical and mental exhaustion, in states which I can only assume are akin to sweatshop-like conditions, and forced to meet impossible and unrealistic deadlines by Electronic Arts. Not only was Bioware trying to create one of the most ambitious RPGs ever made, but they also had to do it in significantly less time than any of their previous two games, while simultaneously developing a tacked-on multiplayer horde mode. So, as much as I want to scold them for doing such a half-a$$ job with what was supposed to be their magnum opus, I can't help but developed an immense sense of respect and gratitude that the game came out as competently as it did. If you can't tell by now, I'm emotionally torn on this game. [u] I truly do love it [/u] and see the potential in it, but I can't help but feel a sense of disappointment and regret every time I play the game knowing how different and extraordinary it could've been had things turned out differently. If I can leave a piece of advice for anyone going into Mass Effect 3, it's this: Enjoy the game for what it is because there is a lot to love about it. The highs are amazingly high, but prepare yourself for the lows because that sh!t will be lower than the Mariana Trench. 

[h1] Parting Words [/h1]

Despite its shaky and questionable finale, the Mass Effect trilogy had a profound impact on me as it did on so many others. Playing again ten years later, it reminds me why the series was so beloved and had rightly earned such legendary status among fans. Its breathtaking worldbuilding and lore, well-told story, and diverse and well-written ensemble of characters have forever etched themselves into the annals of gaming history. It truly was, and still is, the most epic sci-fi video game saga of all time. And that is why Mass Effect Legendary Edition is my favorite game on the Citadel. I should go.

Hands down the best sci-fi RPG trilogy of any video game generation. Rich story and deeply fleshed out universe, expansive and vibrant environments, a rousing score, and perfectly balanced mechanics make for a gripping and immersive experience. You literally cannot have a bad time playing through the Legendary edition, buy it now and rejoice in your decision.

I had never played any of the Mass Effect games before this. I'd certainly heard they were good. I had heard the ending of ME3 was trash and caused a lot of controversy back in the day. Otherwise, I didn't know much about these games. Not even the genre. No nostalgia blindness here!

Turns out, I missed out on a real gem! This sci-fi epic of galactic proportions was a wonderful experience. 

The story and characters are the primary focus here. The combat is just serviceable in ME1, while ME2 and ME3 feel better. The whole "your choices matter from game to game" novelty is pretty nice... even if it usually doesn't have that much tangible impact. It makes the game feel like a cohesive story that you're in control of, I quite liked that. These games reminded me of an old show I used to watch with my father from the 90s called: Farscape. A human running around with all these wacky aliens who're genuinely interesting characters in their own right. It's a nice memory. The galaxy you're introduced to in the first game genuinely feels massive... and that was awesome.

While there's a fresh coat of paint, especially on ME1, that doesn't change how some of the fundamental gameplay mechanics are a bit dated. As stated, combat in ME1 is just serviceable. The Mako in ME1 was cool in concept but the dozens of barren worlds lost their charm quite quickly. ME2's resource management was tedious and you barely even got to use the Hammerhead. ME3's galactic readiness mechanic felt underwhelming and many many more. With that said, these things usually didn't distract too much.

The story left me wanting more. I wanted more interactions with the alien races and the galactic community as a whole rather than JUST the humans. I wanted to explore worlds inhabited by races like the Hanar or the Elcor and see them and their cultures take front and center for a few quests. I wanted some of the morally questionable decisions to have more weight. I wanted to spend more time with characters like Garrus, Joker, and Tali. I wanted the Reapers to be as strange and unknowable as they claimed to be. [b]I just wanted more... and that's a testament to how well the world of Mass Effect sucked me in.[/b]

8/10 Highly Recommended. I enjoyed my time in this galaxy even if the missed potential sometimes made me want to pull out my hair.

I had heard the glowing praise for the Mass Effect series. It never interested me. All the animations look stilted and I wasn't interested in sitting through hours of conversation trees, trying to min/max a "best" outcome. The first time I played, I bounced after a couple hours; it felt like a dated game engine.  

While I was waiting for the Starfield release, I decided to give it a go.

Holy cow. I couldn't have been more wrong. 

Once I got off the Citadel and started to explore, the game began to grow on me. By the second game, I found myself doing all the side missions because I didn't want it to end. By the end of the third game...

This is easily the best RPG narrative I have ever played. The magic of this game isn't in the moment-to-moment game play, but in the cumulative effect of getting to know all the characters. Decisions made in ME1 and ME2 carry over and resonate throughout the series.

I was an emotional wreck by the end of the trilogy. I can't think of another video game that has affected me the same way. The Witcher 3 has some wonderful moments, but not to this extent. The writing is fantastic. The voice acting is pitch-perfect throughout the series. I cared about every companion I encountered. Characters I disliked the moment I laid eyes on them grew to become some of my favorites by the end. I felt every loss and every survival. It's remarkable that this level of excellence held up throughout the series.

I can't believe it took me this long to play it.

Buy it.

After finally concluding LE with some different approaches e.g. shooting the catalyst and romancing Garrus (yeah yeah, I like the female Shepard – come on, it’s Jennifer Hale!), I’m ready to review. The ME trilogy is one I hold dearly in my heart and definitely deserved a remaster. To have it all packaged into one game is a delight, despite the download size. I’ll be reviewing each game individually with the 1st paragraph focused on positives, and 2nd on negatives.

[b]Mass Effect 1:[/b]

ME1 represents for me a more golden era for Bioware that seems to have disappeared somewhat after Dragon Age: Origins (another masterpiece) when EA gradually reared its ugly marketing head. A time when storyline, moral choices, and RPG progression was something special. ME1 was also unique amidst Bioware titles by actually incorporating more open world exploration elements as opposed to just linear storylines with choices inserted. The game threw you into a unique world with loveable characters, memorable villains, and an epic story. I was 14 when I got into it and can never forget the first time experiencing the terrifying Reaper visions, the goose-bumpy Ilos mission, Vigil’s music… *sniff*, exploring beautiful terrains like Nodacrux and Chasca on the Mako, Sovereign’s and Saren’s badass themes, etc. Of course, there were also unpolished aspects even for its time. Fortunately many have been overhauled in LE. From the moment you launch the new game customisation screen, everything including the character models look more detailed and gorgeous than before. A lot of things have improved from the vanilla version without diminishing the other qualities. 

In terms of negatives, still no ragdoll and omni-gel mechanics not gone. Side-missions still recycle identical environments, but with assets re-arranged. Cutscenes are still unskippable, which can be irritating during replays. Though a minor fault, all choices throughout the story have no impact on the endings (though they carry over, to some degree, in the sequels).

[b][u]Verdict:[/u][/b] ME1 was always strongest in its storyline, atmosphere, world-building, and design ideas (if not execution). With the extra polish, it more than ever holds its place for me as the best of the entire trilogy, and one of my favourite games of all time.

[b]Mass Effect 2:[/b]

ME2’s opening is exciting and hits you in a direction you were not expecting. The storyline – though inferior to ME1 – did a great job of blurring Shepard’s morality by forcing him/her to ally with a normally hostile force. Beloved characters from before like Tali and Garrus are developed further, and new characters like Mordin are absolutely great. The cultures and lore of the alien species is also expanded. Combat is hugely improved and many new biotic abilities are introduced. Normandy ship is more interactable. But the biggest positive with ME2 for me is that, out of the 3 games, it’s the strongest in the choice-matters department. Depending on which squadmate loyalty missions you complete and the responsibilities you assign them with determines whether they live or die. And it’s not just cheap scripted moments with binary choices. It is possible to have EVERYONE survive or NO ONE, depending on how you influence the main storyline. If there is one thing ME2 excels in, it’s definitely replay value.

Despite being heralded as a “darker sequel” I actually didn’t think it was dark enough. Not when you compare to say, KOTOR 2 (a *genuinely* dark sequel that appropriately follows KOTOR 1’s story and premise). Yes there are moments, but the general tone of ME2 borders more often on shootouts and clashes with galactic crime syndicates than Cosmic Horror. It doesn’t develop the Reaper lore, aside from a cheap “twist” near the end. While the Suicide Mission was good, the setting should have been more horrifying given its subject, but the whole level is just too fast-paced and action-oriented to absorb the place you are in. I’ll always find Noveria and Feros creepier than the Collector Base. The soundtrack in ME2 is also mixed, sometimes sounding golden while other times quite generic. Combat gets extremely repetitive, with tedious and constant waves of enemies. Personally, I never liked this action approach as it made ME2 feel more like Gears Of War with dialogue choices rather than an RPG with GOW-style combat. Side quests are less interesting than before; One I recall literally involves nothing more than fighting several Geth up a hill till you reach the top. Compare that to exploring a map and finding a missing survey team underground turned into husks, or a hostage situation with biotics, is that really an improved side mission? Another unfortunate move was the removal of all ME1’s exploration elements. I don’t think people realised that the issues with ME1’s Mako was not the vehicle itself, but the awkwardly hilly terrain you pilot it on. Without that, the Mako was OK to control. Even though the ME2 Hammerhead is more fun, its levels are painfully linear. Unfortunately, ME2 replaces all former exploring with planet resource-scanning that just gets boring after a while.
 
[b][u]Verdict:[/u][/b] When you compare ME1 and ME2 side-by-side, you can tell that Bioware originally had much different ideas. ME2 changes a lot of story and design elements in ways that are hit-and-miss. Thus ME2 always struck me as a superb game by itself, but a disappointment as a sequel to ME1’s story. As the most replayable title of the trilogy however, the crown goes here.

[b]Mass Effect 3:[/b]

ME3 is a product of immensely rushed development (again EA’s ugly head), so in many ways the game is incomplete. On the other hand, it also makes its good elements shine even more brightly as a result. ME3’s intro on Earth is the most intense opening out of the 3 games, and the game’s overall tone is definitely the most depressing. In order to rally support for Earth, Shepard must be forced to make tough decisions that don’t always have a mutually beneficial outcome. You can really feel the stakes here, and many moments between characters might make you shed a tear or two. Combat is yet again improved with better weapons, more open environments allowing tactics and flanking, and long-overdue dive-rolling. The Leviathan DLC mission is very underrated, and should not have been DLC in the first place, as it does exactly what I wanted and give more lore to the Reapers. Though I disliked the retconning of the Prothean physical appearance in ME2, Javik is an awesome DLC character and you won’t be able to resist adding him as a squadmate on every mission just to hear his witty and unique comments.

Again, as a rushed game you can tell a lot was cut and this still applies in the remaster. To quote Zero Punctuation “the endings could have been worse”, but also could have been better. The war asset feature didn’t feel as impactful as ME2’s outcomes, even with the extended endings. The climax was also too brief; it didn’t necessarily need a boss battle, but I was hoping for more to happen than just… what we see after Shepard enters the Citadel beam. ME3 also suffers from the same questionable design decisions found in ME2 such as tedious shootouts with (respawning?) waves of enemies. Also, it’s criminal that Bioware still did not insert that Anderson Convo mod as a core part of the game. Oh well, at least you can still install the mod on LE, just have the tissues ready.

[b][u]Verdict:[/u][/b] ME3 could have been more, but Bioware sure gave it their all given the time constraints. Regardless of what you may think of the game itself, it will always carry the most emotional weight to the journey, as the Threequel of any trilogy should.

So those are the games for you. There’s not much else to say, except that if you were a fan of the trilogy then you must make the purchase. And if you’re new to this, well… you’ll be in for quite a ride!

If there is one game that I genuinely feel deserves the time it takes for me to right down a real review it is 100 percent these games.

All three of these games are full of fantastic character writing that will make you fall in love with each and every one of your companions. The universe is full of interesting lore and beautiful visuals throughout all three of the games. And the game-play connects everything quite well in my opinion. Mass Effect 2 and 3 are perfectly competent cover shooters that while doing nothing groundbreaking are still very enjoyable to play. Mass Effect 1 has a combat and levelling system which while definitely showing its age, has had most of its jagged edges rounded off by the remaster, and is easy enough, even on the hardest difficulty that it won't do much to get in the way of your enjoyment of the story and characters. As a whole the games are better as a whole trilogy than as any individual game, but for me Mass Effect 2 ranges as my number game of all time with Mass Effect 1 and 3 tied for second place.

I am going to have a paragraph talking specifically about Mass Effect 1 because it was the only game of the three that underwent any serious changes. First of all Pinnacle Station one of the two dlcs that were made for Mass Effect 1 has not been brought over to Legendary Edition. I personally am not disappointed by this because it was quite bad. If you happen to want to play it though there is a mod for it on the nexus last time I checked that will at it to the game for you. The hud has undergone changes to make it more inline with how ui design in the later Mass Effect games With the health bars of you and your squadmates being found directly at the bottom of the screen. In terms of gameplay changes it was largely just modernizing the game, adding in mechanics like headshots that were lacking from the original, tightening up combat arenas to prevent you from being able to fall under the map(looking at you Noveria), they also made levelling much more generous allowing you to reach the level-cap feasibly in one playthrough. All of this together does end up serving to make the game easier, but in my opinion it does so by cutting out elements that I would consider tedious and ends up only improving the game.

The final thing I am going to talk about is the graphical updates that the game has undergone for the remaster. Honestly they didn't change that match outside of certain pre-rendered cutscenes where the difference are very noticeable. They added the ability to play the game on higher resolutions, I cannot comment on 4k as my pc is not powerful to play the game on it. Mass Effect 1 looks much better, they brought it inline with the later 2 games in the series graphically, for Mass Effect 2 and 3 I might just be blind, but I personally cannot see that much of the difference between the original and remake. I apologize if I am an idiot, I am. With that being said, that is not a knock against any of the later games in this collection, they are both beautiful and absolutely hold up to a modern standard.

To try and make my ramblings slightly more concise. All three of these games have excellent writing, and characters that anyone could love. Simple but enjoyable gameplay across the board, and looks absolutely beautiful.

The emotional attachment I had to these characters is unhealthy. The last game made me cry like four times. Mordin, Thane, Garrus, and Joker were my best friends and Miranda was my wife. Love with game.

There isn't much that I can say about this series that hasn't been written with greater eloquence. But here are my thoughts as someone who has spent over 500 hours between the three games over the years.

The story is excellent and well executed, the characters come to feel like old friends, and the gameplay ranges from 'ok' to 'pretty awesome.' But it's the music that, for me, ties it all together into a package that is absorbing, that draws you in emotionally, and that delivers on its promises. I still hear the galaxy map music in times of quiet reflection. The ambient music lends a very unique feel to the games, and I still play the soundtrack for its own sake years later when studying or working. It's not a video game series so much as it is a complete experience, one that is entertaining, at times humorous, bittersweet, and triumphant.

Some characters are more flat than others. Some romances are shallow and unfulfilling. But the characters that are done exceptionally well feel larger than life. Some romances will provoke emotional responses that may surprise you.

There are bits and pieces from each of the three games that I did not especially care for. But they are small and inconsequential in the grand scheme of things. They are more often than not harmless quirks that don't subtract that much from the games. Overall I would say that this series is as close to perfection as you can get to a story driven video game with compelling characters and exciting gameplay. 

Yes, the ending could have been much better. But endings are notoriously difficult to get right, and the fact that we were even treated to a completed trilogy of games that gave us an ending at all is something I am grateful for. I've encountered too many stories in various mediums that never finished what they started, and no ending is a far worse fate than a sub-par ending. And honestly, I think that the games were so well done that it created an extremely high bar to clear. The ending wasn't bad so much as it was apparent from anyone who played the games that it could have been so much more, and that's where a lot of the angst comes from.

My one piece of advice is that if you haven't played this yet, take the time to play it without distractions, with a good pair of headphones, and treat it like an interactive movie. If the first game is too off-putting because of its age, start on 2 (in my opinion the best of the three games overall), and enjoy the ride. You won't regret stepping onboard the Normandy.

The Mass Effect series is an universally acclaimed trilogy.
Each game is a third-person shooter with an emphasis role-play.

The first ME feels the most raw and RPG-like of the series. 
The gameplay is somwhat clunky and you may get overwhelmed by a lot of information, the massive skill trees and the confusing amount of weapons, gadgets and armor.
But in total, it feels like a true passion project, with a great story and a memorable soundtrack.

ME2 is arguably the best entry in the series, 
finding a great balance between the shooter and RPG aspects.
A good story with a stressful and dignified finale.
Smoother gameplay and crew members with more depth.
And overall a more polished feeling, with side missions feeling less like a check list and more meaningful.
To my personal dismay, the weapons and armor arsenal has been greatly reduced after feedback from the first game. 
An example being grenades and weapon mods becoming part of already shortened skill trees.

Starting with Arrival (ME2's last DLC), the feeling of the series changes drastically.
It felt like ME3 puts more emphasis on the shooter than the role-play part.
Depite some shining moments and the gameplay being possibly the best it has every been.
I feel that ME3 relies on already established plots and characters a little too much.
And while I don't hate the ending, I have to agree that it is somwhat unstatisfying.
As a fan of Bioware, I love this series and the legendary edition give a ton of replay value.

Back in the day I played the first two ME games about half a dozen times each, went through every possible option and variable they had and was totally obsessed with them. Then ME3 came out, I played it once, and didn’t touch the series again for over ten years. So coming back to it.

Mass Effect is still a really fun game. It has very awkward combat, some pretty cringe dialog, and I think probably hands down the worst selection of side quests of any rpg I’ve ever played. But the story is strong, the characters are mostly very engaging, and it creates one of the most interesting sci fi worlds I’ve seen as well as one that is surprisingly well presented in terms of its themes and details.

Mass Effect 2 is one of the best video games ever made. Other than a few minor flaws it’s an almost perfect game. Even all these years later, and having played a lot of other great games, I really have nothing bad to say about it. I’ve still never really seen anything out perform it in terms of storytelling, character development, and feeling like you’re really in a story that follows and adapts to your choices.

Mass Effect 3 is a tedious slog that is honestly kind of baffling at times. It’s baffling how slow and disorganized it feels, baffling how repetitive and boring the missions are, baffling how awkwardly it deals with a lot of the story beats that it, itself, set up in the first game, yet seems totally unable to manage now. I can only assume the fact that the lead writer had left the series and EA had taken over management is the reason it feels so rushed and directionless. And the DLC, which I had never played back in the day, is also pretty bad. I seriously struggled to even get through it. Replaying the first two games made me want to play through them again and again. Playing the third one made me want to stop playing the series altogether. I especially like that every mission ends by putting you into a useless room that you have to immediately leave through a loading screen to get back to the only part of the ship you would ever logically want to be in when a mission ends. So glad the remaster didn’t fix that, it’s super fun walking through that load screen four hundred times, 10/10 guys.

Overall I still think it’s one of the best game franchises out there, and even the botched third entry isn’t entirely worthless. There are some decent parts hidden in there. I do think it’s worth playing, particularly since ME2 is about as good as video games get. But it’s a shame that the finale dropped so many of the balls the series had been juggling up until then.

[i] I LOVE MASS EFFECT WITHOUT THE M [/i]

[h1] Mass Effect: Legendary Edition [/h1]

This Trilogy Collection caught my eye when it was announced on Steam, as someone who never played any of the Mass Effects in the PS3/360 era. It's got action, drama, daring rescues and romance in a space-faring universe that more games should bring back in the future. 

Commander Shepard is completely customizable and can be transferred between games. Each entry remembers every choice and event from the last without any trouble, and its easy to bounce between games. The characters in every game are all memorable and also transfer between games while taking note past events and decisions. Plenty of human companions to relate to with Ashley, Kaiden, Jacob, Miranda, Jack etc. and their alien counterparts are just as good if not even better with Garrus, Tali, Wrex, Liara, Grunt etc. 

Unfortunately, the gameplay itself did not age well, but that's just what to expect from games made in 2007/09/12. It's clunky as all hell. Luckily, the story and choice mechanics outside fighting and walking/running more than make up for it. 

[spoiler] I romanticized Ashley Williams and the things I did to her are only half the things I'd do to her in real life... [/spoiler]

[b] [u] Mass Effect [/u] [/b]

Not too long, but has so much repeatability that you won't care (I sure didn't). You start off customizing and creating your character, and even if they have a predetermined last name you can still basically make them whoever. 
Since it's the first of the trilogy, they do a fantastic job at world building. Exploring really feels like a luxury and every world feels different in it's own way. Different people to explore, and aesthetically pleasing to be around. 
Gameplay wise, it has its own mechanics. Naturally it is the one to introduce us to useful squadmates, tools and abilites, character classes and combat. It's also the only one of the three (as far as I remember) to use vehicles in missions, called the Mako. Since's it's the oldest, this really feels the clunkiest so set your expectations on other elements. 
The Choice System is what grabbed me to commit to the rest of the trilogy and not stop after finishing the first. Choices aren't always black and white, but how you approach them is what actually matters. Renegade Choices give you extra dialogue that actually effect the plot and sets the dominoes for the next two games, which you earn with points that add up.
Definitely one of the best games of all time out there in terms of first impressions and being the first in a series.

[b] [u] Mass Effect 2 [/u] [/b]

The best one in the collection, it's a lot more action-packed than it is an RPG and it's a big change, one I would happily take. They've changed a lot of the weapons, which are more like natural guns used by the military and less like alien ray guns and laser beams used in sci-fi elements. 
Unfortunately, not as much exploration, but they make up for it with the way you are supposed to recruit and build your team. The missions you take to recruit them are great, but they add an extra incentive through loyalty. Do it right, and you can earn the trust and loyalty of your crew. It was probably my favorite part of the whole game, the whole experience.
You are revived and work for one of the other factions in Cerberus, in a nice change of pace. A very intriguing story with a big hook that has probably caused me the most depression in the whole series with the dark direction they took. So many people died in my first playthrough that I wish I had made sure to do the missions properly and plan ahead first.
Overall definitely the best in this trilogy and I'm probably gonna replay it the most.

Holds it's own weight to finish the series strong ( MOSTLY, [spoiler] outside of it's extremely controversial ending, who thought it was a good idea to turn your character stupid in the last few minutes of the game? Thankfully it's not bad enough to ruin the game for me. [/spoiler] ). 
The gameplay probably peaked here in my opinion, although I don't understand why in 2012 we still have the 'jump' button for sprint while being unable to change your camera angle at the same time, and why we can't jump but have to rely on parkour through arrows. I could accept it in 07 and 09 but by 12 this just gets old.
The characters peaked here in my opinion, even though we don't get the same full roster as ME2. The relationship building and character development really showed off, and the game has you starting off from Earth, instead of building your team like you did in the second game, this time you are recruiting the support and resources of entire alien races to fight a war against overwhelmingly unfavorable odds. It's a clever change of pace that I almost like as much. 
While not as good as the second, I largely prefer it to the first and that's no slouch to it either as it was a fantastic first game.

The Mass Effect series is to gamers what Star Trek is to movie fans. It is a grandiose space opera that unfolds an epic story about saving the galaxy on the surface of three RPG games.
Thanks to the incredible scope of the scenario, you will get to know the fictional universe and its inhabitants in unprecedented depth.

I will try to describe the core and atmosphere of the series without major spoilers.
As the commander of a unique spaceship and special strike force, you travel the galaxy to intervene where needed and make many difficult choices that you then have to live with. While you get to know the individual alien races and assemble your party, a very successfully dosed central plot slowly begins to develop in the background, revolving around the suspiciously similar mythology of many space civilizations - ancient records tell of a divine race of thinking machines that return in cycles to "harvest" organic life.

One of the main charms of Mass Effect lies in the gradual and slow unraveling of the complex relationships between the many cosmic races, blindly chasing the main goal while trying to tick off another completed game is completely counterproductive.

It is fascinating to observe from a distance how well all three parts of the game work even after all these years and fit perfectly into the mosaic of a single, perfectly connected story. It is in this interconnectedness that the great strength of the Legendary Edition as a package lies, as it offers an easy way to enjoy all the content of the main games as well as their often excellent or even absolutely essential DLC additions, which have been organically integrated directly into the main games for this edition. And although a great progress can be felt between the individual parts not only in terms of the setting or gameplay, but also in terms of storytelling, a certain naivety and old worldliness of the first part is suitably contrasted with the captivating personal level of the second part, so that everything culminates in an absolute war epic in the final three.

Epic soundtracks, an interesting and unique universe, one of the best stories in the gaming industry... there is nothing to think about, going through this trilogy is the duty of every gamer. [b] 95% [/b]

When delving into the franchise's origin with ME1, I found it to be a solid starting point for the series. While the remaster didn't address this, I wish they had integrated ME3's enhanced sprinting, dodging, and melee mechanics into this installment. Improved sprinting alone would've been a welcome addition, as Shepard seemed to exhaust quickly during runs. The handling of the Mako vehicle could be quite frustrating, particularly when navigating tricky terrains during side missions. Setting this aside, the game was enjoyable.

7/10

ME2 encountered some similar issues to its predecessor, ME1, but showed improvement in several aspects. Sprinting continued to feel lackluster. The Hammerhead vehicle brought better control than the Mako, yet its missions didn't quite capture a sense of fun. The hacking and bypassing mechanics experienced a regression from ME1, losing the simplicity that made them engaging. This game's resource-scanning mechanics were also tedious, despite the upgrade available. The upgrade system, however, was commendable, and the DLC content added value. Other than that, this game is a must play.

8/10

THEY FINALLY IMPROVED SPRINTING.

ME3 is my personal favourite (ending aside) among the 3 because it's gameplay is miles better among the first two, with improvements to melee and dodging. No more stupid vehicles to control, and no more hacking as well, which is better than ME2. Probe launching still exists, but kept to a minimum which is nice. They took all the bad things from the previous 2 and simply improved it or got rid of it. The game effectively conveyed the high stakes of the reaper invasion and the sacrifices required for victory, but the introduction of Kai Leng felt unnecessary and left me questioning its purpose. The ending felt underwhelming and didn't entirely honor the weight of the choices I made. This game has the best DLC in my opinion.

8/10

I've played through this series multiple times and yet after getting all the bioware games on sale, I immediately spent the past month and a half playing through this all one more time. I laughed, I cried, I fell in love again and I felt genuine awe for the sights I saw along the way.

It's crazy how years later this series can still have such a hold over me. If you haven't played it, play it. I could talk all day about how this is the definitive story based space opera game, but you'll only get what I mean if you actually play it. I know that the internet has its gripes on the ending, and while it can be divisive, I'd argue that the entire 3rd game is filled with payoffs for the series. That being said, go ahead and download the EGM and Take Earth Back mods, which add a lot to the third game (specifically the final mission) giving you more of a payoff.

Anyways, play the game, I don't have much else to say other than this series is probably my favorite which prevents me from saying anything deeper than that.

The way I see it, if you’re reading reviews of this game, you’ve either played this trilogy before, and so there’s no point in me explaining it to you, or you haven’t. The most fun I've had playing a game and diving into a story's lore came over playing these three games in a row in the last few weeks. While Mass Effect 1 set the mood and established a very compelling story, my only real critique of it is that it feels very PSP-corridor-style when it came to roaming around in the rover. Just coming out of a FF7 Crisis Core playthrough, it felt very much like that. Mass Effect really spiced things up a bit. Story line was excellent, flipping the narrative of Cerebrus from semi-antagonist in the first game to real up and center in this one was narrative genius. Compound this into Mass Effect 3 when ish really hits the fan with TIM and just excellent, fun, engaging combat and honestly I just really loved and looked forward to playing this game. Without spoiling too much, I do like the ending of this game. The premise of the series is that your choices have consequences and this does a good job at bringing it full circle with your choice at the end. Although not one individual game is a perfect 10 for me, as a whole, the playing experience from this trilogy is a perfect 10/10 for me.

essentially three different games in one, each one very different from the last. so lets go 1 by 1.

Mass Effect 1: My favorite of the series, fun gun play, fun companions, i enjoyed the weapon system the most in this game. The story is pretty solid, and is the one i look most forward toward replaying. the side quests do get very same-y after a while

Mass Effect 2: Kinda mid. A larger cast of companions, which is really nice and enjoyable, but the switch to limited ammo and a borderline nonsensical story makes it pretty meh. Not meh enough to never play again, but not hella excited for it

Mass Effect 3: So. Smaller cast, meh. Encumbrance system, sucky. Removal of ME2 companion loyalty quests, sadge. Continuation of the ME2 gun play system, annoying. The over all plot is way better than Mass Effect 2, but the ending i found to be pretty bad, personally.

Over all I did enjoy my time playing through the series, and im glad I did finally play it, but there are just a few issues I have that bug me, mainly the ending to Mass Effect 3. I would say it is worth it to buy for Mass Effect 1 and the companion quests and interactions in Mass Effect 2, and then you might as well just finish Mass Effect 3 just to wrap up the story, ya know? If you prefer RPG elements, you'll love Mass Effect 1, if yu prefer linear shooter elements, you'll love Mass Effect 3... just wish the NPCs weren't so racist towards each other...
