WAIT FOR THIS TO BE ON SALE.

First and foremost, no, this is absolutely not worth full price lmfao - video games in general stopped being worth $60 when we stopped printing them on discs and selling them at GameStop, those days are LONG gone and you shouldn't be buying shit for $60 imo

That said, it's Mass Effect. Moreover, it's the entire Mass Effect series (save Andromeda) in one bundle. That's gonna be a good deal no matter how you slice it.

SECTION 1: THE BUNDLE
========================
Upon buying this bundle, two problems immediately rear their heads. Both are relatively minor, but annoyances nonetheless, and I can totally see them turning people who've never played ME away. The first of these being the size of this bundle. Going in, I expected this to work like how most bundles do on PlayStation, where the bundle itself is simply a platform for the games and each one can be installed and uninstalled as needed (See: The Handsome Collection). This is not the case. This is a launcher, yes, but all three Mass Effect games are baked right in, meaning a very long install time (I'd recommend letting it install before work or before bed) and the need to carve out a full 110 GB for this game to install correctly. The other, more cumbersome, issue is the game's forcing of EA Play upon you. Surprisingly, EA Play actually isn't that intrusive, aside from opening on startup in much the same way Steam does, and the "Remember Me" box tending to just... not work, but it doesn't interrupt gameplay, urge you to buy anything or try to entice you with any kind of stupid exclusive content (Like how FC4 has exclusive uPlay weapons), and - I never thought I'd be saying this, but - hats off to EA on this one, it seems like they really did try their hardest to integrate the Steam version of this game more with Steam than with their own service, and that takes standards I honestly did not expect from them going in. The game installs fine and doesn't need any fan fixes or patches.

SECTION 2: ME1
========================
Mass Effect 1 is nothing short of a masterpiece. On top of laying the foundation for the series, it looks great in the Legendary remaster, and, from what I hear, I'm in the minority on this one, but I firmly believe it has the best gameplay of the three. It's a surprisingly good introduction to more old-school RPG type games, with a character sheet that offers depth, while also being streamlined enough that people who might not know how to build a character in a more proper RPG with a billion different stats and all those fancy numbers (See: Wizardry 8) will be able to pick up on it relatively quickly. The story, of course, is simple, but very fun and full of depth. I found this game the most fun when I went out of my way to try to pick up side quests, often finding even boring-sounding ones to carry more depth than they initially seemed to, in a very similar way to SWTOR's side quests. Again, I realize I'm in the minority on this one, but ME1 remains my favorite of the three.

SECTION 3: ME2
========================
A good game, with a lot of improvement over ME1, but also, a lot of questionable changes. It was a product of its time, I suppose, and is in no way a bad game by any stretch of the imagination. Personally, I'm not a huge fan of the switch from overheating to more traditional ammo management, nor the switch from on-demand medkits to cover shooting and regenerating health, the further streamlining of skill strees, almost to the point of oversimplification, the lack of choice regarding [spoiler]helping Cerberus, a supposed racist terrorist group[/spoiler] (although I realize you can play Shep as not liking them, you still have to play along regardless) and I just really really don't like Miranda in particular. It's pretty clear why she's there, and while she does have a pretty good amount of depth, I personally think the devs were trying way too hard to make her into this super badass mysterious sexy lady, and it ended up falling flat for me, but I realize that's personal. Also the fact that [spoiler]Miranda of all characters gets a romance path and Kasumi gets literally no dialogue after her companion mission[/spoiler] is an absolute travesty. ME2 also suffers, in my humble opinion, from a lacking Paragon/Renegade system in comparison to ME1, I feel like Para/Ren grow WAY too slowly if you don't deliberately build Shep around being purely one or another, I did a decent amount of side questing, and answered things exactly as I would irl, and finished the game with somewhere around 2 and a half bars in Para, and 1 and 1 quarter bars in Ren, and while it was never a super big issue, it locked me out of dialogue at a few small moments [spoiler]such as trying to resist Samara's daughter[/spoiler] which left me with this, like, slightly dejected kind of feeling, like "Aww, but that would've been so cool!"
My final, and probably biggest complaint about ME2 is going to have to be the ending. Nothing with the story itself, the story is fine, but the scene really rubbed me the wrong way. On my first playthrough, I kind of neglected upgrading the ship. Normally, when games do the whole "Upgrade the ship/base/whatever" thing, it's either cosmetic or some kind of stat boost. This is not the case here. Refusing to upgrade the ship enough will literally result in [spoiler]multiple companion characters unceremoniously dying without so much as dialogue in the final cutscene.[/spoiler] I get it, it's my fault, but the way it was handled felt almost passive-aggressive, as it was purely the consequence of me not engaging with a part of the game I simply wasn't interested in. I'm not going to go and say that it's necessarily bad design, but I would've appreciated more of a heads-up if it was going to be that important. Overall, ME2 has some really frustrating, and honestly, confusing decisions compared to ME1, but I really, really enjoyed it. Loved almost all the companions, as well - The only one I even remotely disliked was Miranda, and while a few (See: Zaeed, Kasumi) felt a little undercooked, I found myself loving both the new and returning characters, with Thane, Mordin, and Grunt in particular standing out as stellar characters to me.

SECTION 4: ME3
========================
So, Mass Effect 3 is more aptly called Mass Effect 2.5.
I love Mass Effect, but I'd be lying if I said ME3 wasn't a disappointment, in my eyes.
A lot of what's wrong with ME3 is that it doubled down on some of the worst aspects of 2 - and I loved 2, for the most part, but ME3 really killed it for me, between the slow-ass, janky dodge-rolls, the scripted """jump""" mechanic, the even further emphasis placed on cover, and the comparative lack of freedom, especially compared to the first game, ME3 more than dropped the ball by trying to be this weird mix of Uncharted, Gears of War, Call of Duty, and every other game that comes to mind when I say "2010s third-person shooter" instead of just being Mass Effect. Right off the bat, scripted sequences are obvious, cutscenes take way too long, dialogue is cheesy, and while Shep has always been a little autistic, it feels like they really hammed it up this time, to the point of making fun of it in one of the DLCs. I'm really not a huge fan of Mass Effect going from a tactical squad-command shooter with cover mechanics in the first game, to a cover shooter with squad-command aspects in the second game, to a full-on cover shooter in this one, but with the success of ME2, it was practically guaranteed that ME3 would follow up on it. Grenades are back, at least, but work more like traditional grenades than the ones we had in 1, which were almost like TF2's stickybombs, and I feel like that's a step backwards - I liked having these weird, oddball grenades that you had to use deliberately. Text limit reached, but I could go on. ME3 is bad, sorry.

This is one of my favorite series of all time, and I feel terrible thumbs downing it, but here we are. This is not a review of the story and I'm sure I will end up playing through this again as Mass Effect has a way of always drawing me back. 

The good: So much love has been put into this remaster, ESPECIALLY the original Mass Effect - and wow is ME1 a joy to play again. It still has some dated aspects but it is not difficult to get through at all and the Legendary Edition really lets you forget about all the wonkyness of the original to just get back into that story and enjoy the first ride around the galaxy.
Everything is beautiful and specifically when you are playing the game it runs amazingly. 

That last point leads me directly to the bad though. Actually getting this game to start is sometimes like pulling teeth with the EA launcher. Seriously, trust all the negative reviews citing that specifically. Yes, there are some with workarounds, but that is also a huge pain and really not accessible for folks who are not technologically inclined. Also, yes specifically the game runs well but if you have any peripherals plugged in (you know... a microphone, a midi keyboard.... a CONTROLLER?) there's a nonzero chance you'll encounter extreme stuttering and slugging playback of the pre-rendered cutscenes. I'm talking 7-14fps. It makes no sense. 

I got this for $15, and as of writing this review it is on sale for that price. Absolutely I would recommend it at that price point, for if you have or have not played before. It is such a wonderful series and despite all the issues I had a fantastic time once again. However at the normal $60? Stay away.

[b]A Flawless Remaster of Timeless Classic[/b]

Rating: ★★★★★

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is, without a doubt, the quintessential way to experience one of the most groundbreaking trilogies in gaming history. As someone who has devoted an immense portion of my gaming life to these extraordinary titles - from the nostalgic era of the Xbox 360 and PS3 to the present day - I am pleased to say that the remastering is nothing short of phenomenal.

The love and care poured into the Legendary Edition are apparent from the moment you launch the game. The graphical improvements breathe new life into familiar worlds and characters, adding a fresh coat of polish to visuals that I have admired for years. It's the same beloved universe, now presented with the vibrancy and detail that modern hardware allows. Yet, this edition maintains the essence and soul of the original games, making the experience feel nostalgically familiar yet beautifully enhanced.

The narrative aspect of the Mass Effect series is, as ever, unparalleled. Deep and intricate plots keep you engrossed, pushing you to dig deeper, to learn more, to engage further with the myriad characters who populate these worlds. Speaking of characters, Mass Effect’s roster is one of the most memorable in gaming history, and the Legendary Edition does them justice. Their individual stories, hopes, fears, and quirks are as compelling as ever, drawing you back into the personal dramas and epic galactic struggles that have defined the Mass Effect experience.

The lore in Mass Effect is deep and expansive, creating a living, breathing universe that is easy to lose yourself in. Whether you are a series veteran like me or a newcomer to this iconic series, there is always something new to discover, a piece of lore or a hidden backstory that adds depth to the overall narrative tapestry.

One of the key highlights of this edition is the ability to journey through the entirety of the saga in a seamless and interconnected manner. The narrative threads of all three games are beautifully woven together, forming a single, coherent epic that can be experienced without interruption. It provides the ideal opportunity to undertake a comprehensive expedition through the narrative - from the intense beginnings in the first installment to the deeply poignant and widely discussed conclusion of the third game.

In conclusion, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition is more than just a remaster. It's a love letter to the fans, an acknowledgment of the countless hours we have poured into this universe, the connections we have made, and the memories we have created. For those who, like me, consider these games an integral part of their gaming journey, the Legendary Edition offers the opportunity to revisit cherished moments with a new sense of awe and appreciation. And for newcomers, it’s an open invitation to lose themselves in one of the most immersive, well-crafted, and unforgettable sagas in gaming history. Mass Effect Legendary Edition is, in my book, a masterpiece that transcends time and technological advancement. It is, quite simply, [b][u]legendary[/u][/b].

The nostalgia trip of the decade

Mass Effect launched when I was 18.  I fell in love, bought each of the games as they released, and finished what I felt was the best video game series I had ever played (although the ending did turn me off from playing the third game multiple times).

I bought this and thought maybe youth had clouded my judgement.  I can confidently say that after having played the trilogy again, Mass Effect remains the best video game series to me. 

I love Commander Shepherd and how Bioware makes it feel like its YOUR Shepard even though there's only so much variation between yours and mine.  I love the companions and how memorable they are even after all these years.  I love the world building and exploration.  I love the music and visual design choices.  I love the ways they experimented with different gameplay systems and created a unique feel for each game.

It's a wonderful game, and I'm happy I got to play it again.

By far one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had the chance to enjoy. 
Great gameplay and incredible world (or galaxy) building. 

There was almost never a dull moment. With the expectation of cheesy, bad-ass character interactions and one-liners, it was easy for me to adjust myself to that setting and not get phased by something that most people may or may not deem as 'bad' writing. 

The role-playing is extremely immersive in my opinion, something that modern RPGs fail to succeed in. 
Even though I was playing as a pre-existing person, BioWare did a fantastic job allowing players to really make Shepard their own. 
Regardless of character appearance, background, and status, at some point it felt like I was no longer playing as Shepard, but I was playing as myself. That is a huge win in my book. 
The fact that the choices you make matter immensely throughout the entirety of the three games is amazing in itself and something I am convinced that other developers will never be able to pull off to this scale, although I wish they would try. 
The only games that have come close are episodic narratives such as Telltale's Walking Dead. 

I'm almost sad to have finished this trilogy because I fear nothing will live up to my experience. 
Given the backlash Andromeda has received, there is more than likely no comparison to the trilogy (at least not yet?) but I'm still eager to give it a try and will do my best to separate the experiences and make sure it does not tarnish the time I have spent as Shepard. 

If you want to experience playing out your own action/adventure movie, I recommend you play this legendary trilogy.

[h1]Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition - An Epic Remastering of Sci-Fi Gaming's Finest[/h1]
[h1]Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)[/h1]

Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition is a masterful remastering of the iconic sci-fi trilogy, offering an unforgettable journey across the galaxy with the original Commander Shepard. With its enhanced visuals, improved gameplay mechanics, and engrossing storytelling, it stands as the definitive edition for both long-time fans and newcomers alike.

[h1]Likes:[/h1]

Unrivaled Narrative and World-Building: The Mass Effect trilogy is renowned for its deep and immersive storytelling, captivating players with its rich lore and memorable characters. The Legendary Edition preserves this brilliance, allowing players to experience the epic saga in its finest form.

Updated Visuals and Graphics: The remastered visuals breathe new life into the trilogy, with enhanced textures, improved character models, and modern graphical effects that make the worlds and characters feel more vibrant and alive.

Seamless Gameplay Improvements: The Legendary Edition streamlines gameplay mechanics across all three games, offering a more consistent and polished experience. Improved combat, smoother controls, and refined UI elements make for a more enjoyable and fluid gameplay experience.

All DLC and Expansions Included: The Legendary Edition includes all previously released DLC and expansions, giving players the complete Mass Effect experience without any content gaps.

Mass Effect 1 Enhancements: The remaster gives Mass Effect 1 a significant facelift, bringing its visuals and gameplay closer to the standards set by its sequels. This improves the overall cohesion and enjoyment of the trilogy.

[h1]Dislikes:[/h1]

Occasional Technical Issues: Some players have reported minor technical issues, such as occasional frame rate drops or audio glitches, although these are infrequent and do not significantly impact the overall experience.

Limited Gameplay Overhaul: While the Legendary Edition enhances the trilogy with updated graphics and streamlined mechanics, some players may have preferred more significant gameplay overhauls to further modernize the trilogy.

In conclusion, Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition stands as a triumphant celebration of one of gaming's most beloved sci-fi trilogies. With its captivating storytelling, improved visuals, and enhanced gameplay mechanics, it provides both nostalgic fans and newcomers with an unparalleled journey across the vast expanse of space. Whether you're a long-time admirer of the trilogy or a newcomer eager to explore the wonders of the Mass Effect universe, the Legendary Edition offers an epic and definitive experience that will leave you enthralled and emotionally invested until the final choice. Embrace your role as Commander Shepard and prepare to forge a legacy that shapes the fate of the galaxy in Mass Effect™ Legendary Edition.

I've poured countless hours into the original trilogy back on the 360, it's one of my all time favourite franchises. I wholeheartedly recommend this franchise to everybody, I truly love Mass Effect.

So, why don't I recommend it on Steam? Why would I go out of my way to throw a red thumbs down onto something I've proclaimed that, I wholeheartedly love?

[b]Because, to put it simply, EA, in their needless, pointless pursuit of shifting from Origin > EA App, have somehow managed to bug out / completely mess up achievement acquisition for ME2 & ME3 on Steam.[/b]

At the end of the day, achievements for me are more like souvenirs from my time with a game, I won't go out of my way to tick off boxes for annoying tasks I find no enjoyment in doing, that said, something worked and now it doesn't and with EA being absolutely, pathetically useless at maintaining and supporting their pathetic excuse for software, I have no idea when a fix will come along.

Regardless of how inconsequential achievements may be, you shouldn't be giving a company your money when they knowingly avoid fixing issues with their games / leave things broken. I don't want to tell people not to buy this absolute masterclass of a space opera, I want to recommend it to people.

If you don't care about achievements, then feel free to ignore this and canon the review in your head as a glowing, thumbs up recommendation.

[b]Edit - Managed to get them to work, will repeat the steps I made here.[/b]

[i]- Go into documents > BioWare > ME:LE > Save > ME2
- Backup a copy of "GamerProfile" somewhere safe just in-case, then delete it.
- Boot up EA App independently alongside Steam.
- Push the EA App into offline mode, boot the game up from Steam.
- You will periodically be kicked out of the EA App and have to sign in again, when it happens, just quit the game after saving, sign back in and boot it all back up into offline mode.[/i]

This won't grant you achievements you've missed retroactively and it won't register any medals you've already acquired, but if you're halfway through a game on ME2 (or ME3? I imagine the above process works for that too) then this should allow you claim achievements going forward.

Sorry for the wall of text, though I do hope it was helpful. Please make backups of anything before you tinker with file structure based on advice from random people online. Despite being a swell guy, I'd rather you not run into headaches because of me if you do read and follow the advice. I personally backed up "TrilogyGamerProfile" and "Launcher_Profile" too, just in case I ran into any headaches myself that may have occurred due to deleting the "GamerProfile"

Yes, I will recommend this, BUT.
HEAVY CAVEAT.
You cannot play this game without also, unfortunately, being forced to download and use the EA launcher. and the EA launcher drags this game down HARD.
You will not be able to play the game through steam if the EA launcher can't connect to the internet unless you manually - through an internet connection - go and put the EA launcher to offline. So you can't play this if you're traveling, or if your internet goes out. You're SOL.
Also, the achievements for both ME2 and ME3 will probably break (mine did after the EA app had an 'unexpected error'), and you'll be unable to actually get any on Steam while the in-game view shows that you've unlocked all of them. The problem has been around since MELE was launched and EA never bothered to fix it. Fortunately, there's a reddit post detailing a fix for this, but it requires you to delete the gamer profile out of your game files, and then every single time you play the game - yes, every single time, forever - you have to start the MELE launcher, then BEFORE entering ME2/ME3, go fiddle with the EA app until it lets you alter it (it might get stuck in overlay mode, in which case you'll have to force quit it and try again), go offline, play your game, and go back into online mode after you've closed out of the game when you're done.
ME1's achievements work fine though. I have no idea how EA did this.
Also, I've been playing MELE for a month and I've ended up having to fix random infinite loading/launch failure issues by reverifying the game files (an hour long process) five times.
Also it's really odd to see some ME3 textures ported backwards into ME1. They look very strange and out of place. But that's getting into nitpicking changes and that's personal opinion territory.
So yeah, this is Mass Effect, if you love it you'll still be pretty happy with this version of it - but EA definitely sours the experience some with their downright awful app that you cannot get out of using. Keep that in mind if you buy/play this. The EA app will make you want to tear your hair out, and you will have to go through some additional steps every time you play if you want your achievements to function.

Tl;dr: The achievements for ME2 & ME3 do not work. 
Be aware of this if you care about that sort of thing.

Edit: As of 25th July 2023, the achievements seem to work again. I have no idea why, but given that it's EA, I presume this is an unintended consequence of a mistake that broke something else. I still don't care and they didn't get any points in my book for fixing it. The achievements were supposed to work the entire time, you don't get praise for bringing me a knife and fork when I already ate the steak with my hands. The comparison is garbage, but so is EA, and so is their launcher, so it fits.

Long version:

I recommend the ME series, though it's dated. It has a lot of charm and even without nostalgia, you should find enjoyment playing them. There's a lot to see, a lot to do and there is substance here.

But what you're really getting your money's worth out of with this title is Mass Effect 2. I've played many games throughout my life, and I can confidently say without a shred of doubt that Mass Effect 2 is one of the best games I have ever played. The story is spectacular, the characters are riveting, and the iconic character of Commander Shepherd is at their best in this title. Both voice actors are great throughout the series, but Jennifer Hale delivers one of the best voice acting performances I've ever seen in a game since I first played through RDR2. I found myself completely enraptured by the character of Shepherd, to the point that Mass Effect 2 is one of the few games I've played that I never wanted to end. 

If you've never played the series before, I can't recommend this series enough. I wish I would have gotten into it sooner.

I've already played the Legendary Edition on my PS5 so I'm just going to drop my review here while I've only recently started it all over again on my PC. 

Mass Effect: Legendary Edition fits the title. Sure, it may just mean it has the first (and as far as most of us are concerned) only three games in the series as well as *most* of the DLC, but it's also LEGENDARY. Prepared to be pulled into a world full of interesting characters, deep lore, some good romance options (and some not so much), and lots and lots of decisions, most of which actually impact different aspects of the game, some big impacts and some little. The game's cast is generally absolutely incredible. The characters most people would agree are the best among the bunch truly are some of the greatest characters in the history of gaming. You may pick this up just expecting a space game with a little story and some shooting, and you'd be on the track, but it's much more than that. Mass Effect is about choosing to be a good guy or a bad guy (not really much in between) but using that and the decisions you make to bolster your team and allies against ever-growing threats. If you ask me, Wrex, Liara, Tali, Garrus, Mordin, Aria, Samara, Captain Anderson, Grunt, Thane, Miranda, Jack, Legion, Javik, EDI, and Joker all left lasting impacts on me where I'll remember them fondly for the rest of my life. A *usually* well written story and characters you can grow bonds with and truly get to know combine together to have you clinging to the game til its conclusion like a new TV show that has you hooked on its cliffhangers. There are some good romance options here as well. I, for one, will stand by the wifey of the series, Liara, til the day I die. She's intelligent, friendly, has an interesting backstory, and has a relationship with Shepard that is sweet and can make it through anything. Best of all, she's available to both male and female Shepard. I hear Tali is a great option, but seeing her end up with (SPOILER ALERT AHEAD) Garrus, who is CLEARLY Shepard's best friend and deservedly so, near the end of Mass Effect 3 was very heartwarming. 

Let's break it down a little bit.

Mass Effect 1 has the story, it introduces us to some of the characters we will get to know and love. It kicks things off establishing the importance of your decisions and is a great start to the series. Unfortunately, it also has the Mako. I'd highly recommend at least getting a mod to fix the Mako downloaded off of Nexus and make sure you install it properly. 

Mass Effect 2 is generally the one people consider the strongest of the series, and for good reason. The story picks up, grows, and so does Shepard and those around him/her. The pressure picks up while you continue your love interest or start a new one (which will also happen in Mass Effect 3 of course). This one introduces us to even more great characters and stories. The gameplay is much better from this point in the series. Where they thankfully took the Mako out, they threw in some annoying lockpicking mini games (they're not too bad, but sometimes seem to just get in the way).

The third and final installment of the trilogy continues the main story like the final chapter of a great book. You meet more great characters and companions. The gameplay improves and so do the graphics. There are some truly great moments in Mass Effect 3, and I feel some people like to leave this factor out because they want to take a dump all over the ending. I didn't think the ending was terrible, but it certainly lacked in some aspects and the story as a whole sometimes was a little off in this round. Regardless, Mass Effect 3 is barely the weakest of a great trilogy of games that I'd recommend to anybody. (ANOTHER SPOILER ALERT) I also should add that Mass Effect 3 gives us one of the hardest decisions when you have Mordin alive but not Wrex. Wrex's brother Wreav is not a good Krogan and will make a terrible leader should you do the "right thing" by assisting Mordin in curing the genophage. Not having enough points toward Paragon or Renegade (whichever it was or both) to talk Wrex down in Mass Effect 1 on Virmire will have him killed, which you'll severely regret. Wreav is a fine character, but not at all a good "person". Wrex has vision. Wrex would actually lead the Krogan in a great direction. Thus, you may have to kill Mordin to keep him from actually curing the genophage, someone who is easily one of the most lovable characters in the franchise. It was heartbreaking.

I didn't pick up Mass Effect because it was a space game or a shooter. I picked it up to get enthralled in an interesting world with great stories and incredible characters while making decisions that matter, and Mass Effect almost always hits the nail on the head with all of these. The fact it was a space game and a shooter actually is what made me disinterested for many years. I finally gave in once I heard it was much more than that, and I'm so glad I did.

It's also worth adding that Mass Effect gave us two of the greatest antagonists in all of gaming- Saren and The Illusive Man. Saren, a powerful and clever rogue Spectre who aligns himself and becomes controlled by the actual overarching antagonist(s) of the series, really shines in Mass Effect 1 whereas we will love and hate The Illusive Man in both Mass Effect 2 and 3 as he provides an extremely deep character who fits in perfectly with the franchise and main story.

After putting 80 hours into the trilogy on my PlayStation 5, it is a truly a collection of three of the greatest games I've ever played.

Mass Effect: Legendary Edition gets a 4.5/5 for me. I don't regret a second of the hours I spent on the three games and you won't either. If you catch it on a good sale, just get it. Buy it so Bioware hurries up and gives us a real Mass Effect 4. Bravo on these three, Bioware. Bravo.

« Entrer dans la légende, risquer de devenir un mirage » :

Dans cette édition « Légendaire », les joueuses et joueurs sont invités à faire l’ensemble des DLC (40 annoncés sur la page Steam !) et la version étendue de ME3, parce qu’il semble que la fin n’était pas assez satisfaisante pour la majorité des joueurs et que les développeurs n’ont pas assumés et ont préférés la retravailler. Pour commencer, je précise que je ne la connais pas cette fin originale, je sais que se montrer à l’écoute des joueurs est souvent plutôt bien perçu, mais je reste très circonspect car là il s’agit d’une trilogie, longue, intelligemment menée et mis à part un travail qui aurait été bâclé au point d’impacter les ventes, je ne vois pas ce qui a pu faire infléchir les choses. Quoiqu’il en soit, la fin proposée est satisfaisante car elle mène à une résolution qu’effectivement je visais dans ma partie, mais je ne suis pas forcément convaincu par le sacrifice messianique final, ni par l’oubli du Leviathan ou des Collectors (qui ne sont pas entièrement éradiqués).

Maintenant, d’un autre point de vue, il s’agit d’une édition présentée comme remasterisée et vendue en 2021 pour 60 euros. Elle a mis beaucoup de temps avant d’arriver dans cet état : 9 années entre ME3 et ME.LE. Et là, c’est nettement plus problématique. D’abord, sur les 3 jeux, ce sont les mêmes moteurs (graphiques, physiques etc.) qui sont employés, normalement, cela permet de mettre à jour et d’uniformiser sensiblement plus facilement les contenus. Ainsi, l’aspect graphique est censé avoir été retravaillé. Mis à part certains effets, ce n’est pas le cas, indéniablement. C’est vrai les jeux ont bien vieilli, mais les écarts entre le premier et le dernier sont majeurs et certaines textures ou autres effets avaient déjà besoin d’amour à la sortie des jeux originaux (par exemple l’eau c’est de l’huile !). Passons, disons que l’investissement pour la partie graphique ne pouvait pas se faire raisonnablement.

Pour commencer doucement, le fait de pouvoir récupérer sa/son Shepard d’un jeu à l’autre est clairement l’un des points forts de la série, c’est indéniable. Mais dans les faits, c’est assez sous-estimé, en particulier dans le deuxième épisode qui a tenté un redémarrage, il n’y a pas vraiment de continuité si ce n’est celle de l’apparence du personnage : à posteriori, il aurait pu être bon d’importer plus du premier épisode, comme son arme fétiche, des cicatrices, des choix de discours qui ont déterminé notre personnalité et qui nous empêcheraient d’être incohérents face à certaines situations… Autrement, j’ai croisé beaucoup de PNJ qui semblaient mieux polygonés que ma Shepard dans le troisième jeu, y compris des humains. Ensuite, il est relativement dommageable de constater que dans le premier jeu, les PNJ se ressemblent vraiment beaucoup au sein d’une même espèce, qu’il n’y a pas d’enfant avant ME3 (oui, un seul mais tout de même), et quasi pas de vieillard.

Mais, et si vous avez survécu à la lecture de cette critique jusque-là, vous me voyez venir, les aspects qui sont dramatiquement mis de côté, c’est le système de jeu, l’ergonomie générale et les menus. Ce n’est pas qu’une uniformisation n’a pas été réussie, c’est qu’elle n’a même pas été essayée en réalité, et mis à part l’interface dans ME1 qui a été vaguement liftée, il n’y a aucune cohérence entre les 3 jeux. Par exemple, ce n’est pas comme la trilogie remasterisée de Mafia où les 3 jeux sont vendus séparément et donc on ne s’attend pas nécessairement à l’uniformité du système. Ici, il faut, pour avoir l’édition légendaire, racheter les 3 jeux et ensuite, il y a vraiment de graves soucis inhérents à des gestions d’inventaires ou d’options, qui sont des choix que les développeurs auraient pu rectifier. Certes, il ne serait pas possible de tout incrémenter d’un jeu à l’autre (par exemple, les QTE, dans ME1 impliquerait beaucoup trop de réécriture etc.), mais se retrouver devant un ensemble sans-cesse perfectible et décousu est très gênant. J’ai beaucoup évoqué les soucis de contrôle et de mapping (le sprint, la touche multifonction) dans les critiques, s’ajoutent les collisions du personnage, les gestions d’inventaire et de manque de logique intra-diégétique permanents au dessus desquels il faut passer, sans oublier l’ergonomie piteuse des menus (ne pas pouvoir regarder le journal de quête sur la carte galactique est vraiment pénible et inexplicable). Il n’y a eu ni réflexion, ni prise en compte que les résolutions des écrans de 2007-2012 ne sont plus celles de 2021 et permettent d’afficher proprement des menus et des interfaces mieux construites.

Mais si l’on évoque ne serait-ce que l’exploration des planètes c’est aussi franchement très triste de constater qu’au fur et à mesure, de moins en moins d’options nous sont accessibles. ME1 c’était tout de même la promesse d’une immensité à explorer ! Déjà dans ME2, ça sent le roussi mais il y a tout de même quelques moments d’exploration. Dans ME3, c’est du hasard, du superficiel, l’envoi d’une sonde sur une planète et c’est plié, on redécolle. Était-il si impossible que ça d’importer le matériel d’un jeu à l’autre ? Comme d’employer la même carte galactique pour l’ensemble des trois jeux ? Imaginez, si les explorations des trois jeux (à la fois les systèmes de jeu et les découvertes réalisées) pouvaient se cumuler à travers les 3 ME, cela résoudrait beaucoup des soucis de mollesse, de répétitivité voire d’inutilité que l’on pouvait ressentir dans ME1 et 2. Ici, tout a été abandonné peu à peu. Pour évoquer les endroits les plus explorables (Citadelle, Thessia, Tuchanka, Omega etc.) il aurait pu être intéressant de cumuler les environnements des trois ME et, même sans les rendre directement utiles, les laisser accessibles en permanence leur donnerait enfin une envergure immense et pas simplement l’impression d’avoir échoué dans une ville aléatoire. Ne serait-ce qu’un panneau pour dire « dans le prochain jeu tu pourras aller là-bas », cela contribuerait encore davantage à la cohérence entre les épisodes.

De fait, à l’évidence j’ai été berné par cette promesse de « Légendaire » et je ne suis pas du tout en phase avec cette philosophie de développement qui consiste à incrémenter un système, se rendre compte que c’est bancale (en pratique il n’y a rien qui ne marche pas du tout non plus), le laisser agoniser tel-quel et le supprimer du jeu suivant au lieu d’avoir cherché à le rectifier. Je m’attendais tout de même à plus d’ambition : soixante euros pour 3 jeux qui ont entre 9 et 14 ans, et qui ...

Fantastic space opera RPG trilogy that is an absolute MUST PLAY for anyone who loves a game with great story, interesting and memorable characters, compelling villains, and CHOICES THAT MATTER and that shape plot and character development outcomes, spanning across the entire trilogy, making the player character and their story feel like it's truly yours.

You're Commander Shepard, a Human Systems Alliance Marine officer, who finds out about an imminent threat and has to rally as many allies as possible to the cause of defeating a mysterious and threatening enemy against seemingly impossible odds.

With highly cinematic presentation and storytelling, excellent sound design, top-notch voice acting, solid writing, epic music, you feel like you're the protagonist of a fantasy sci-fi thriller reminiscent of Blade Runner and Star Trek.  There are enough RPG elements to customize your Shepard and squadmates to your liking, and equip yourself and your squad to fit your combat playstyle as well as decide what skills and gear you need for the next mission.

The remaster treatment has smoothed rough edges, added modern visuals and QoL features, and discarded annoyances from the originals such as the lenthy elevator rides (that hid loading screens).  The package includes 40 DLC, leaving out only the combat arena from ME1, which didn't really fit in narratively with the rest of the game.  There's also no multiplayer in ME3, but the campaign adjusts things so that multiplayer is no longer a necessary grind for getting the best possible campaign endings.

If you haven't played these 3 games, you owe it to yourself to experience this.

Everyone knows this game is amazing. Know what else is also amazing? Churros. Churros are amazing, and here's how to make them:

· Water: This recipe for churros starts with a cup of water.
· Sugar: White sugar goes into the churro dough and into the cinnamon-sugar topping.
· Salt: A pinch of salt enhances the flavors of the other ingredients.
· Oil: You'll need vegetable oil for the dough and to fry the churros.
· Flour: All-purpose flour gives the churro dough structure.
· Cinnamon: The fried churros are rolled in a cinnamon-sugar mixture before serving.

1. Boil water, sugar, salt, and vegetable oil. Remove from the heat, then stir in flour.
2. Transfer the dough to a pastry bag and pipe into strips.
3. Fry the strips in hot oil until they're golden.
4. Drain the churros, then roll in cinnamon-sugar.

I personally really liked that this franchise got completed, even though I wasn't that happy about some decisions regarding story-telling, but the conclusions are acceptable especially after the Extended Cut DLC, which is already indluced in the Legendary Edition.

[h1]BE AWARE![/h1]
You cannot install each game separately, so you always require 100 GB, regardless of which game you want to play.

[h1] Mass Effect 1 [/h1] 

I enjoyed it. I think it makes the mistake of 'starting off generic' which it shouldn't have done but that doesn't last long. It takes the premise of 'humans being new to a inter-species society' and explores it well with a lot of the plot starting because of humanity wanting a larger role in that society. The other species we see are also very interesting from the exiled quarians, the dying yet violent krogen and many more. They have unique backgrounds to them and interactions that we usually don't see in sci fi works. The combat is simplistic but its fun enough. I liked the skill tree and use of companions in combat tho I think the game throws xp and points at the player.



[h1] Mass Effect 2 [/h1] 

Mass Effect 2 is an improvement over Mass Effect 1 in pretty much every way that matters. The set up from the start is a lot more engaging compared to ME1. The main quest feels a lot more **proactive** than most stories in these kinds of games. It expands on the lore with more interesting things. Companions are a lot more interesting here with proper companion quests with a good incentive for the player to actually do them. Combat encounters and sidequests are also much more varied than the first game. Exploring planets leads to more unique situations instead of just moving around in a shitty rover. The replacement rover is much better too. The situations the player is thrust into also feel a lot more unique and interesting. The Illusive Man was a very interesting character. Combat itself is _much_ better. I think this is the most I've enjoyed a shooter tho tbf I have not played a lot of shooters. Special moves are a lot faster and give more uses. Guns are far more responsive(except for shotgun). My one complaint is levelling up being very simplified and with less possible variety.

Mass effect 1 felt like the beginnings of the idea of making an action sci fi movie shooter with actually good RPG elements and characters but mass effect 2 is where it is properly realized.


[h1] Mass Effect 3 [/h1] 

I've heard some people say that 'mass effect 3 is good except than the ending' but I disagree with that statement. I had tempered my expectations after hearing about this being a polarizing game but they managed to disappoint. It starts of very strong with the first few missions in general being very good. However, after finishing [spoiler]Moridin's[/spoiler] quest, the game just fell apart in my eyes.
The choices given did not feel as varied or interesting compared to ME2 and there was this pervasive sense of 'genericness' to everything which is surprising considering how unique the setting is in general. The [spoiler]Geth-Quarian questline showcased this the most as the Geth are reduced from one of the most unique races in the setting to some of the most generic one by going back to the often-repeated idea of 'individuality = life' even tho ME1 and 2 had a more unique take on their collective intelligence and life.[/spoiler] The game builds up Kai Lang but just no. He is dumb, edgy and stupid. They made the [spoiler]illusive man[/spoiler] stupider and more boring. I do not like the choice of squadmates at all. [spoiler]Garrus and Tali[/spoiler] are really the only ones I was happy to see return. Ede should not be a squad mate. [spoiler]Liara[/spoiler] is eh. I already forgor who else was available.  The entire end sequence is very dull and the way endings are decided just broke for me so I just had to watch the endings on YouTube
 
On the gameplay side it is easily an upgrade. Gunplay is better, skills are better, skill tree is better, etc. I like the shotguns.


[h1] Final thoughts [/h1] 

Overall its a very interesting trilogy with its strengths being how decisions you make carry on to the next game. I wish it could have had a better concluding game but that doesn't lessen how much I enjoyed the first two games

1.[b]EA App[/b] - Brand new cancer for your computer, its required to run the game. It doesnt work half of the time, doesnt run the other half, crashes all the time. Not to mention all kinds of issues like your game automatically assigning to wrong account, garbage EA customer support etc ..

2.[b]Steam achievements DONT WORK[/b] -  If you like collecting achievements avoid this game for unspecified amount of time until EA fixes their garbage launcher. Due to EA being bunch of schmucks this new Origin will mess up your save and automatically unlock all achievements.

ME1:
This really feels like an experiment for the devs and only like a setup for the other games in the series. It is good, but not great overall. 

The gameplay is a bit clunky, combat is kind of boring due to how dumb the AI is (both friendly and enemy) but the gunplay was surprisingly good due to nice gunsounds. The Mako is just horrendous and I dreaded each time I had to use it in side and main quests. Really floaty and unresponsive. Side quests are veeery repetative and not very good either. The different planets and locations go from ok to pretty bad and barren (at least side quests, most main quest have varied and nice locations.  

But where the game truly shines is in the story, lore and characters department. Characters have alot of personality and nice backstories. The story (and lore as they are quite intertwined) is super engaging and just really well told, and I especially like how it feels like you truly make an impact. The whole series feels like it was designed with the main intention of choices having consequenses that carry over which is really nice. But I do kind of find it a shame that the choices are so telegraphed in if they are "evil" or "good", but I like it either way.

If looking at only the gameplay it is hard to recommend, but the story, lore, characters and how it all carries over to the sequels more than make up for it imo.

Mass Effect 1 is the game that, back in 2006, changed what games were to me. It re-shaped my perception of games as simply an entertainment vehicle, into that of a storytelling medium. What followed is perhaps one of the most brilliantly written trilogies in video game history. The Legendary Edition brings it all back under one umbrella, ready to be experienced all over again. Are there faults? Yes. Has it aged well? I would argue the case for a very strong 'yes', but even with a refresh these games are still a product of their time - albeit a very polished one. To me this just adds to the nostalgia of the series; your mileage may vary. To this day, I have never since played a game or series of games which invests me so deeply into the characters around me in such a powerful way. Of all the games I've ever played, these are the three I wish I could erase my memory of to experience them for the first time all over again. They are simply that good.

As an icy-hearted Wolf hailing from a wintry world, gaming has always been my sole refuge, my escape from the relentless blizzards of loneliness, depression, and the unending loop of caretaking and labor. Through the haze of these frosty realities, Mass Effect Legendary Edition was a beacon of hope, an unexpected savior that melted my frozen heart, and stoked a flame that I thought had long been extinguished. 🕯️❄️

Now, I'm not usually one for remakes, but Bioware's Mass Effect Legendary Edition, a remastered version of the original Mass Effect trilogy, was something else. It was like the comforting warmth of a hot chocolate on a cold, winter's day, sipped slowly while watching the snowflakes dance outside your window. 🌨️🍫

In essence, the Legendary Edition weaves the journey of Commander Shepard, who, whether donning the mantle of a male or a female, fights gallantly against the ominous threats lurking in the farthest corners of the universe. Joining Shepard are colorful characters like the mysterious Liara T'Soni, the ever-so-loyal Garrus Vakarian, the technology prodigy Tali'Zorah, and the ferocious Wrex. The narrative propels itself across a variety of planets, star systems, spaceships, and space stations, all unified by a single purpose - the survival of all organic life forms against the relentless onslaught of the Reapers.

Now, let's cut to the chase. 🐾🎮

#Graphics: The graphics have been lifted from the original to a level I never thought possible. Each character, each texture, each planet, it's all crisp, clear, and beautifully rendered. The polish on the graphics alone justifies the price tag, in my opinion. From the way the armor glistens in the sun to the detailed alien worlds, each element is stunning, a visual feast for the senses. 🌌🌠

#Gameplay: The Legendary Edition includes all three games with revamped mechanics. The shooting, the exploration, the RPG elements, everything feels more streamlined and modernized. And the best part? All the DLCs are included! That alone had me salivating, my tail wagging uncontrollably. 🐾

#Story: The story in Mass Effect has always been its strongest asset. In the Legendary Edition, it's no different. The same compelling narrative, now presented in a more immersive setting, further amplifies the emotional stakes. But be warned, the choices you make, the lives you decide to save, or the ones you sacrifice, will determine the fate of entire civilizations. 🌌

#Impact: The Legendary Edition stands as a towering testament to the enduring legacy of the Mass Effect series. With this remastered version, Bioware has rejuvenated interest in the franchise, prompting both veterans and newcomers to embark on this epic journey. It is, without a shadow of a doubt, one of the best video game remakes to date. 🎮💎

#Evaluation: As an old hand at gaming, supporting indie developers, kickstarting projects, and avidly consuming all forms of entertainment, from manga to anime to movies, I've seen the gaming industry evolve. Yet, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition holds a special place in my heart. It is an unforgettable journey that every gamer must experience. ⭐️🎮

There are two things that come to mind when I think about the legendary edition.  The first being a bit of a Skyrim re-release with some really nice extras to it.  Second is, unusually, like how I would describe Saints Row 4 "a love letter to a franchise" and that's what it does, faithfully.  Albeit, almost anyway with a few discrepancies, mainly bugs sadly, holding it back.  In this review, I will primarily being covering the various alterations alongside with it's issues as elements like the story serve no relevance here.  Fear not to those who might be new to the series as there are more than plenty of other reviews out there that cover these topics in particular.  If it's not already obvious then yes, I do recommend this title at full price which, from my point of view, at £60 is a steal (more so if it's on sale) seen as your given a whole collection of games plus their additional dlc's into one bundle.

We begin with the big topic regarding to the first entry in the series which has been remastered and I have to be honest with you, my fellow reader.  It's awesome!  Astonishing really the effort put into it from it's gorgeous visual aspects (better if they had a Halo style system of switching graphics) to areas you wouldn't normally think of like sound design and even the user interface has been overhauled.  Not only that, it also has made a few nice tweaks to both it's combat as well as vehicle handling, notably it's physics I'm referring to with the list of changes still going on and on.  Because of this, it's almost kicked the second title of it's throne as my favourite Mass Effect game of all time.  There are a few drawbacks though, a few locations do feel as if they need a bit more brushing up for visual improvement plus the lack of any changes to side missions is a huge missed opportunity.  namely with things such as placing in cutscenes or additional dialogue playing in the background for extra immersion.  In a twist of irony, the worse thing the remaster has done is appear nigh on graphically superior to the other two games, Mass Effect 2 being the unfortunate victim here.  I say this because you barely notice much different with the other two title's other than the odd adjustment.  An example of this is the controversial camera angles that I personally feel much more comfortable with now than what I had on screen before in their previous adaptations.  At the time of writing this, I in fact nearly forgot the newly added photo mode that you can use for all three games at any given available time however, I do wish there were extra options such as being able to pose your character or even squad members.

Now, count this edition lucky in terms of the bugs because it was very rare for me to find however, to my knowledge there are tons of reported issues from other people so that might be worth keeping in mind when thinking about your purchase.  Mass Effect 1, couldn't see a bug in sight from what I could tell apart from the frame complication that you would expect to perform on a Windows XP.  If your one of those that has a relatively good pc then just run the program on high performance in the graphics settings and hopefully it's solved the problem.  Mass Effect 2 plus a little bit in number 3 has a strange dialogue delay where characters won't say anything for short period of time and the subtitles will continue, often skipping the audio at the very end of their speech.  On the subject of the second entry, absolutely nothing has been done to the way Shepard clips with objects.  It's a literal joke when your walking perfectly on the ground one second only to then notice yourself suspending on top of a load of equipment as evident from the Krogan triage/research area in Tuchanka.  Lastly, be careful on the Citadel party in third instalment as there is what I believe to be strange error when clicking the invite button, mainly the invite all button that I only tried using.  What it does is it triggers a conversation regarding the party that you can easily back out off whenever you please to which your probably asking yourself "well, what's so bad about that then?".  Unfortunately, after selecting it once, it happens to always initiate and effect other options in that terminal like the casual hangout choice thus resulting in scenes that are hilariously crashed with people just standing around like a complete pair of planks.

For this last section, this has no real impact on this review but I just want to briefly talk about Mass Effect 3 which no doubt a lot of you will know what I'm on about here.  Originally I was going to say that if there was one thing I would of liked to see altered in the third game then it would be the ending, particularly the first option your presented with as that was what the main plot encouraged throughout the story, let alone the entire trilogy.  However, there is a mod, thankfully, that does the job for that so that defeats that argument.  Either way, I'd be lying to myself because there are a lot areas in this title that have some rough edges around them that can stick out like a sore thumb at times.  My point is, as much of a mountain of a task it sounds, the idea of a remake is always on the table for me or, in this case, just the odd few reworks would work to make this feel unquestionably "legendary".

~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Orig review

+ decent story
+ characters that actually have character
+ decisions you make in each game can carry over to next game

- 80% walking simulator
- plot railroads you some times, regardless of choices
- annoying, time-wasting "mini games" to mine resources and other junk
- some character classes have boring skills
- tries to cram romances down your throat every step of the way (this might be a positive if you're into that sort of thing)

- ME1 has boring side quests
- ME2 has you gather a team, then forgets most of them for ME3
- ME3 doubles-down on annoying "fetch / scavenger hunt" side quests
- ME3 still has game-breaking bugs for some folks (like me)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Mass Effect is a product of its time, where RPG dev studios would say their games had "50+ hrs of game play!", but that really meant the player was forced to trudge back-n-forth through environments 80% of the time without any real plot or action going on. Just you getting from point A to point B, and probably back to point A again, over and over, in an effort to chase the next plot point.

There's maybe only 10 hrs of real plot spread out over the 3 games. But, you'll spend countless hours flying, driving, walking to get where you need to go. (I've got 120 hrs on Steam so far, and that's ME1 + ME2 + 1/2 of ME3.. woof)

The game is a bit insulting at times, b/c there's often a galaxy-wide threat going on, but you're off messing around with some side quest to survey minerals on planets, or find some rando that's in trouble, or whatever. You're the galaxy's only hope, but go ahead and go mess around for a bit.. the plot will still be here when you get done with that. (This is true for open-world RPG's, but it's just odd how you can go faff about all you want without any consequences in most cases. I think in ME3 they started putting timers on certain events to entice urgency. But, I still went faffing about, and didn't suffer any repercussions for it.)

As you progress, you start to get immersed in the game world. You notice your actions shape outcomes, not just in the game you're playing, but in the next as well. And, you'll meet some entertaining characters you'll form bonds with, some of which you might actually feel an emotional attachment to if they end up dying or having to leave you.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Mass Effect 1
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

ME1 has you wandering around places, and many places just don't have much going on. It's the first game, they do a lot of world building, etc. But, it's pretty sparse.

Then you fly to planets, and land, leaving you to drive the galaxy's most janky, wobbly vehicle ever created: the mako. Apparently ME fans have a "love it or hate it" relationship with it. Personally, I hate it.

Planets are a scavenger hunt of stuff, and often have outlandishly high mountain terrain. So, you're stuck trying to drive up 80 degree slopes, or work your way around to see if something's interesting in some corner of the map. The only "interesting" stuff you find are mineral deposits (for money) or some piece of space junk that has a little blurb of text about something that doesn't really impact you. So, it never feels worth it.

Eventually, you gather a team, kill a "big bad", and move on.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Mass Effect 2
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

ME2 takes place a couple of years after events of ME1, so all your old buddies have gone off to start new lives.

So, ME2 spends 80% of it's time revolving around "putting together a team". It feels like a heist movie, except, once you actually get the team together, you don't commit a heist.

ME2 has better side quests, many of which involve solving a problem to recruit someone, then solving another side quest for them to gain their full loyalty.

But, there's so many team members, it feels awkward only being able to bring along 2 folks on missions. You've got Ocean's 11 sitting back on your ship, while only 3 of you are off taking care of business. Seems like a drastic waste of several peoples' time and talent to just sit on a ship waiting for 3 folks to get back. But, I digress.

The game ends with, once again, killing a "big bad" and watching some of your team possibly die. Hopefully the ones you don't care about. "Team A will consist of everyone I give a d**n about, who will sit around drinking hot cocoa by the fire. Meanwhile, Team B will consist of this team member I can't stand, who I hope goes and dies in a fire. Any questions?"

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Mass Effect 3
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

ME3 starts 6 months after events in ME2 with your character railroaded as a "scaremonger" for warning everyone about the very real threats s/he's already stopped TWICE (in ME1 and ME2), b/c "politics". So, feels a bit ham-fisted.

What also feels ham-fisted is within 6 mo's time, your entire squad you spent all that time putting together in ME2 promptly faffed-off to go do something else with their lives, many of which are never heard nor seen from again in the series. It really makes the player feel special when a majority of their time in a previous game is promptly swept under the rug.

ME3 has even more entertaining side quests, and you're putting together a team again (albeit a smaller one). And, the Reaper threat is now very real and very present in the galaxy.

Unfortuantely, I wasn't able to finish ME3, b/c there's a game-breaking bug that only I seem to be experiencing. On a few terminals/ computers, the UI auto-scrolls the cursor down as if some phantom is pressing the "down" arrow key on my keyboard. There is a mission where you absolutely need to select the top message on the email terminal long enough for it to gray-out as "read". Since I can't keep the cursor on that email long enough due to the cursor constantly down-arrowing on me, I'm stuck. I can't activate the exit to that level, and there's no way for me to get out of that mission. My saves either put me right back in that level, or way WAY back where I'd have to slog hours through the game again.

So, I'm basically done.

I was into party-based RPG's when I was younger, but not really any more. I played ME 1 and ME 2 long ago when they came out. Then EA made ME 3 an EA store exclusive. I swore I'd never get it as long as it was EA store-only. So, when Legendary Edition came to Steam, I finally bought it. Whole point was to play ME 3, and finish the story. But, now I'm stuck on a game-breaking bug, and my "give a s***" factor has worn off.

So, I'd recommend the game for the story and characters. But, huge caveats about "it's a product of its times" and "buyer beware"; not all bugs are fixed.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition, developed by BioWare, is a remarkable compilation that revitalizes one of the greatest sci-fi RPG franchises of all time. With its enhanced visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and comprehensive package, the Legendary Edition stands as a testament to the epic storytelling and immersive world-building that made the Mass Effect series so iconic.

One of the standout features of Mass Effect Legendary Edition is the comprehensive remastering of the original trilogy. The game faithfully brings together the three main installments - Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2, and Mass Effect 3 - along with their respective DLCs, providing players with an opportunity to experience the entire saga seamlessly. The enhanced visuals, including improved character models, textures, and lighting, breathe new life into the already captivating universe, immersing players in a visually stunning and cohesive experience.

The gameplay in the Legendary Edition offers a refined and balanced experience across the trilogy. From the intense tactical combat encounters to the intricate dialogue choices that shape the narrative, every aspect has been fine-tuned to ensure a cohesive and engaging gameplay experience. The combat mechanics have been improved, providing a smoother and more responsive feel, while still retaining the tactical depth that made the original games so captivating. The ability to import saved games across the trilogy allows players to carry their choices and consequences from one game to the next, creating a sense of continuity and personal investment in the narrative.

Visually, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a feast for the eyes. The updated graphics and improved effects breathe new life into the expansive universe, showcasing the unique and detailed environments, alien races, and iconic characters. The cinematic cutscenes are beautifully remastered, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments throughout the trilogy. The sound design is equally exceptional, featuring a rich and immersive audio landscape that complements the visuals, from the powerful soundtrack to the memorable voice acting performances.

The Legendary Edition also addresses certain gameplay and technical issues that were present in the original releases, providing a more polished and streamlined experience. From improved controls and character customization options to reduced load times and stability enhancements, the remastered trilogy offers a more seamless and enjoyable gameplay journey.

Furthermore, Mass Effect Legendary Edition's value is further enhanced by its inclusion of all previously released DLC content, allowing players to experience the complete story arcs and additional missions that expand the rich universe of Mass Effect. The sheer amount of content and the ability to make new choices and experience different outcomes make the Legendary Edition a definitive and comprehensive package for both returning players and newcomers to the series.

In conclusion, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a triumph in game remastering that revitalizes one of the greatest sci-fi RPG trilogies of all time. Its enhanced visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and comprehensive content make it a must-play experience for fans and newcomers alike. Whether you're revisiting the series or embarking on a new adventure, the Legendary Edition offers an epic journey of exploration, choice, and unforgettable characters. Prepare to dive into the immersive world of Mass Effect and forge your own path as Commander Shepard, shaping the galaxy's fate in a saga that will leave a lasting impact.

The narrative depth and emotional impact of the original trilogy remain intact, allowing players to forge meaningful connections with the diverse cast of characters. The updated character creator offers more options to customize your Shepard, ensuring that your protagonist feels truly unique. I've wanted to write a review of this game for a while. I've played it since 2010., when I first played Mass Effect 1, then I played 2 and 3 as they were released. Finally, I bought Legendary Edition and the changes they've made, while impressive, have broken few things but I will get into this soon.

All three games have good and bad sides. Mass Effect 1 is amazing in its storytelling. We get Saren, who is among the most interesting villains I've seen in videogames. He does not believe he's evil, rather, he believes ends justify the means. Still, the matter of opinion regarding his morality is left to player. Do you believe Saren was ruthless and only wanted power? Or do you believe he's brainwashed by the Reapers? Game allows you to choose, and ultimately in the end, the game is about Shepard you're roleplaying, not about predetermined setting which, while there, only serves as a frame for your own choices. Of all three games, ME1 is shortest, and this is where the gripe I have with the game comes in.
If you're the completionist like me, you'll want to finish every sidequest before the game ends. Alas, most sidequests in this game require you to travel around whole galaxy, landing on planets, endlessly climbing rocks in the clunkiest vehicle of all time: Mako. While some quests on these planets are interesting, most of the time you'll be frustrated because none of these planets are ultimately original or interesting. I experienced frustrating bugs and glitches, like Shepard's hands staying in weapon-holding pose even after I sheathe the weapon, or glitching through the ground, as well as freezes and crashes and abysmal FPS drops while exploring planets with Mako. Still, game is great. It has this old-school feeling, amazing soundtrack, no pandering to any groups or ethnicity. It goes as far as to involve a racist character: something that would never fly nowadays, but gives your crew a much needed difference of opinions and realism. 

Mass Effect 2 is, in my opinion, best of all three games. Unlike ME1, in 2 you didn't have thousand different armors and weapons. Decluttering of inventory allows player to focus on raising their abilities and skills, and moves focus from micromanagement to action.  This creates a fast-paced, interesting game where the action actually feels alive. Graphics are improvement over ME1, textures are vastly better, and the game reaches the another level of maturity. 
Story is interesting, to say the least. Without many spoilers, a huge event takes places right at the beginning of the game. This immediately gets you hooked, and the game is so interesting you really can't stop playing once you start. There are not many things I could really write off as bad about this game. I'm one of rare people who applaud devs for not making Jack lesbian pansexual. She's one of the most interesting characters in the game, and pandering would have destroyed her personality and character. The only thing I could count as bad is the planet scanning system.
My wrist would literally hurt from all the slow scrolling around planet to find a miniscule amount of minerals I needed to upgrade my weapons and armor. In the end, I downloaded the mod to take all minerals from the planet with a single probe, and it was a life saver. Without mods, this is the only gripe I have with this game. That, and the fact so many of these upgrades are easily missed, yet absolutely necessary (because the game gets harder and harder as you go). In the end I played every major mission with the phone in my lap, desperately checking for upgrade locations so I don't miss out on any.

Now, ME3 was mired in controversy and I understand why. The game, when you play it, sounds like a masterpiece. Music is amazing, sound is great, graphics are major step-up from first two games. Soundtrack serves to set up a setting in a way that gives you goosebumps anytime something major happens. Every moment of this game is emotional. It's somber tone is further accentuated by the fact everything in the game reminds you the end is near. Every person you meet has a sad story, every fugitive you see lost somebody important, and even Shepard suffers from nightmares. 
This is not the controversial part. I could go on about the fact game introduced two openly gay characters, finally buckling down under the heel of propaganda, but Cortez and Traynor are amazingly well written characters I really liked, and neither this is a bad part. Controversial part is an ending. After all the game, everything you do boils down to three choices. Unlike some Bioware's games where ending was so multi-faceted you could play game for ten years and still see different outcomes when you finish, this game will finish the same no matter what you do. After a huge backlash from fans, Bioware expanded these endings but the damage was already done. Personally, I don't mind these endings. To me, it was always more about the road I've taken to get to the end, than the ending itself, but it's objectively one thing I could count as bad.

Ultimately, all three games are masterpieces, and Mass Effect is one of my favorite franchises.

Making this remastered trilogy with all the DLCs and a dedicated launcher was a great move for the Mass Effect IP. It was a pleasure to enjoy ME1 with updated graphics and UI, an improvement I wish I had back when I first played it.

So, why buy this? Some complain that mods can achieve better graphics for free, and that is possibly true. The real selling point however, is the convenience to access all three games in an updated state with one download. All the additional content was integrated to the story in a much more organic way than it used to be: you are no longer bombarded with messages at the start of ME2 notifying you that some dude sent you his experimental weapon, instead you'll find it like you would any other piece of gear playing the game. No longer having to download all the DLCs from ME2 from another website is also a plus.

You get my point: the Legendary Edition is not just a graphics improvement, it is a thorough polishing of the experience as a whole, something that would help old fans and newcomers alike to (re)experience Mass Effect as easily as possible.As far as I'm concerned, it worked.

Get it on sale and you've got a serious package for the money.
