I’m a bit daunted by the task of reviewing the Mass Effect Trilogy. A three game, 150+ hour journey spread out over 5 years of releases isn’t easy to talk about in a succinct fashion. But I loved it, so I have to talk about it. This Trilogy now holds a special place in my heart. I’m a huge sci-fi fan, and Mass Effect delivers an engaging world with inventive alien, ship, and tech designs that rival Star Trek’s. 

The choices that follow you through the Trilogy are impactful and unrivaled in today’s gaming landscape. The amount of branching story honestly makes my head spin at times, but also makes the journey that much more personal. So much of the writing across these games feels tailored to your character, with entire scenarios playing out differently if you’re a female Commander. My Commander Shepard was Female, mostly Renegade, Infiltrator class, no romance, and Insanity difficulty, and my experience of the series is colored by that fact. The voice actor Jennifer Hale is a big reason why I enjoyed these games so much, and I’m not sure if male Shepard’s voice actor delivers the same performance. 

[h1]Legendary Edition[/h1]

First off, the collection itself is the perfect way to experience this Trilogy. I played entirely on Steam Deck, so I had some problems that were mostly Origin’s fault. There were some occasional failures to launch, and achievements in ME2 and ME3 just don’t work. Besides these minor hiccups, Legendary Edition runs great, looks great, and has a bunch of minor improvements (like photo mode) that I didn’t notice because this is my first experience with the Trilogy. The transitions between titles were extremely smooth as a result. 

[h1]Mass Effect 1[/h1]

Mass Effect 1 is, without a doubt, the roughest of the trilogy. It has frustrating level scaling (which Legendary Edition attempts to fix), very dry gunplay, and lots of filler missions. There are some pretty bad autosaves that almost bricked my save, and some awkward animations that took me out of the moment. Abilities are also pretty weak when compared to the power of guns. To its credit, though, it has fantastic world building, impressive visuals, solid voice acting, good characterization of your companions/crew, and some really solid morality choices that echo across the Trilogy. I disliked some of the Renegade characterization, but most of it felt really cohesive, building up Shepard as a hard-ass soldier who does whatever it takes to get the job done, while not being completely unsympathetic and emotionless. The RPG aspects are definitely the worst of the series and more complex than they're worth.

[h1]Mass Effect 2[/h1] 

Mass Effect 2 is improved in all aspects. Better gunplay, better abilities, more meaningful side content, better animations, stronger story, and a more in-depth look at the galaxy. Mass Effect 2 has the largest cast of the Trilogy, with a nice mix of returning and new characters. Each individual crew member has a strong story with convincing characterization, and the crew regularly interacts with each other, their environment, and scenarios. Player choices from Mass Effect 1 have pretty big effects on the state of the galaxy, and lots of references to the smaller choices are sprinkled throughout. The Renegade characterization in this game is my favorite of the series, elevating Shepard to something more than just “evil”. I particularly liked Shepard’s appearance changes as she became more and more Renegade/Paragon. There are some rough spots, though. The “Suicide Mission” is forced on you early if you don’t metagame and lookup the story progression, potentially locking you out of content. Fortunately, you can continue playing in the post-game, finishing up any companion missions you missed (or collecting some model ships for your cabin). The game features a resource gathering minigame where you shoot probes at planets. It gets old fast, but you have to complete it to get you, your ship, and your crew upgraded. Ammo scarcity is also a problem throughout the game. Bioware was clearly adjusting to level designing with ammo in mind, and slightly missed the mark on a few missions. The skill system is streamlined, and while you lose a bit of player choice, it comes with the benefit of a much more focused set of player abilities. 

The DLC for Mass Effect 2 is hit or miss. Firewalker introduces a new vehicle, but the novelty wears off after the first of five new missions. Normandy Crash Site is a single mission that involved walking around a lot. Overlord presented some interesting morality decisions. Genesis provides a nice summary of ME1’s exploits in comic-book form, courtesy of Dark Horse Comics. Kasumi and Zaeed both add companions, of which Zaeed is the stronger addition. Kasumi’s heist mission is boring and FemShep’s dress is too uncanny looking. Zaeed’s missions tell a lot about the character and give some good morality choices. Arrival does setup for Mass Effect 3, best played [i]after[/i] the Suicide Mission. Lair of the Shadow Broker is the best of the bunch, with a solid action-packed mission that gives Liara the much-needed spotlight and creates implications for Mass Effect 3. 

Full warning, I couldn’t review the third entry without spoiling aspects of Mass Effect 2. So don’t read below this point if you care about that. 

[h1]Mass Effect 3[/h1]

Mass Effect 3 takes a somber shift from ME2’s 90’s heist movie feel. The galaxy is now in a full-blown war with the Reapers, and the tone of the game reflects that. Things are serious, and Earth needs the galaxy’s support. The main improvements to ME3 are in the mission design, economy, and combat balance. Powers are significantly stronger than ME2, dealing more damage and having faster cooldowns. Ammo-placement, credit-balance, shops, weapon choices, mods, and ability choices are all much improved as well. I did have some problems with getting Kasumi’s companion mission to properly progress and had to resort to using a save-editor.

Things shift on the Normandy and in the galaxy as a whole as the battle with the Reapers rages on; crew members appear in various places, people talk, diplomats come and go. Your crew is smaller, but each character gets more attention as a result. The crew interacts constantly, and the interactivity present in ME2 is turned up to 11. The amount of voicework for all these diverging conversations is insane. There’s meaningful impact from the previous games, with constant references to past player decisions. The new “War Assets” you can acquire are the culmination of your journey through the galaxy. 

The DLC for Mass Effect 3 is mostly great. From Ashes adds in Javik and his missions, which are integrated so well into the main game I didn’t even know they were DLC until writing this review. The Extended Cut refines the ending, which I thoroughly enjoyed. There’s a lot of negative critique surrounding ME3’s ending, but I was really satisfied with how my [spoiler]Synthesis[/spoiler] ending turned out, which is due in part to this DLC. Leviathan adds several missions that expand on Mass Effect’s lore in really exciting ways. Omega puts you in cahoots with Aria T’Loak and another new companion for some pure shoot-em-up action  while taking back Omega. Aria in action is pure bad-assery. Citadel is a fan-favorite, but I actually hated it. It has a very lighthearted tone, with characters constantly making quips in what is essentially one giant fan-service send-off of Shepard and the crew. The tone is completely at odds with the rest of the game, so I’d recommend skipping it until you’ve beaten the game (you’ll have a chance to go do it after you’re done with the final mission).

[h1]Final Remarks[/h1]

I’m a bit sad to say goodbye to the Mass Effect universe. There’s so much to love about its world and characters that I could spend hours more than I already have writing about it. Here’s to a bygone era of storytelling, and I hope many more enjoy it as much as I have.

[h1] Mass Effect 1 [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Amazing main storyline
- Great cast of characters
- Strong writing
- Incredibly engaging worldbuilding
- Decent RPG mechanics and progression
- Pretty good soundtrack

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Very lackluster combat that doesn't feel very good
- Tedious hacking minigame
- Tedious collectahon side quests
- Incredibly dull level design. Very repetitive, often baren and copy + paste
- Too many interiors look like obvious combat arenas which feel out of place and breaks immersion
- Lackluster exploration and Mako (vehicle) gameplay feels very sloppy and sluggish
- Paragon and Renegade system feels a bit restrictive, in that it rewards you for sticking to one throughout an entire playthrough, limiting player freedom

[b] Final Verdict [/b]
- A solid 8/10 game. Great introduction to the Mass Effect universe and some of its central themes and characters.

[h1] Mass Effect 2 [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Incredibly compelling characters and character storylines
- Some of the best writing in any RPG ever
- Highly improved combat compared to ME1. Actually feels good to play now
- One of the best if not THE BEST final mission/level in any roleplaying game ever made
- Companions Companions Companions
- Fleshed out worldbuilding, with more variety in aliens, politics, religion, philosophy, art, world design and locations
- Incredible soundtrack with many memorable tracks as well as returning favorites from ME1
- Actual consequences for a variety of your decisions throughout the game
- Paragon and Renegade conversation interupts are a great addition that keeps conversations engaging and interactive

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Next to no exploration this time around. Limited to exploring hub zones
- Streamlined ability trees and progression which makes balancing easier but limits the amount of choice and variety
- Paragon and Renegade system suffers from the same problems as in ME1
- The new hacking minigames offer some variety from ME1, however they quickly turn just as tedious and boring
- Weapon restrictions on classes once again limits player choice
- Probing planets for essential resources is one of the most dull and mind numbing activities in the entire trilogy

[b] Final Verdict [/b]
- An easy 9.5/10. One of the best RPGs ever made and a huge improvement on almost all aspects over ME1. Some elements like exploration and deeper gear/character progression being scrapped doesn't hurt the overall experience, but it does limit the game's actual potential of hitting a 10/10.

[h1] Mass Effect 3 [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]
- The best combat gameplay in the trilogy. Feels incredibly smooth and fun to play
- Lots of weapons, abilities and builds to experiment with. Easily the best in the trilogy
- Has some of best story moments in the entire trilogy. Ironically also has some of the lowest
- Is able to reap what has been sowed in the previous two games for MASSIVE benefits
- Relationships, character bonding and moments are as strong as they have ever been
- Paragon and Renegade system has finally been fixed, with both styles contributing to one reputation bar that will unlock more dialogue options for both styles instead of forcing you to stick with only one
- Characters move around the Normandy in-between missions which opens up for a huge variety of character interactions. Unfortunately, they are also easily missable
- Comes with a new map for tracking companions, important NPCs and the like
- The Shoreleave Citadel content is some of the funniest stuff I have ever played. Pure fanservice, but done in an intelligent and respectable manner that doesn't take away from the core experience
- Once again an amazing soundtrack that sounds quite different than the music in the previous two games, however it fits just as well because of the circumstances

[b] Cons: [/b]
- The removal of the neutral dialogue option is a baffling choice that severely hurts dialogue
- Again almost no exploration whatsoever
- Kai Leng
- The story gets quite convoluted with some its explanations towards the end and things become hard to believe
- The "nightmare" sequences that Shepard has feel forced because of what they focus on. Had they focused on prior decisions made in the previous games, they would have been more effective and dynamic
- War Assets are unfortunately not as impactful as upgrades and squad loyalty were in ME2 and ultimately only boils down to what endings are available rather than a plethora of different outcomes and scenes/interactions
- The ending itself can feel very contrived and ultimately not at all satisfactory regardless of the Galaxy or Shepard's fate

[b] Final Verdict [/b]
- Still a solid 9/10 game. The game does fall flat on its face here and there, but with the improvements to the gameplay, the character interactions while also having some of the best moments in the entire trilogy still makes this a worthwhile game to play through.

Before I begin, I just wanted to mention that I've played Mass Effect 1 and 2 (not modded) in their Non-Legendary Edition form last summer (via EA Play), and I've been through Mass Effect Legendary Edition twice thus far (one time un-modded via EA Play, and one time modded after I bought it on Steam)...

Is Mass Effect Legendary Edition a fun game? Yes it is... It is chopped full of story, fun combat, and lots of RPG fun... Choices do make a difference most of the time, which includes flavor choices regarding how you decide to portray your Commander Sheppard... Now, that being said, I want to warn you, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is technically a slightly updated, and slightly altered version of the original Mass Effect 1, 2, and 3 games, using the same loader for all three titles, and allowing your character to more easily transfer from one title to the other... It also includes all prior DLC Content for all three titles... Be warned, possible SPOILERS ahead...

When it comes to graphics, they will differ from one title to another, as the game sequence plays out... The graphics of these older titles were not really updated much, if at all... That means ME1 will look more dated then ME2, which in turn both of them will look more dated then ME3's graphics... The UI's will also not entirely be the same from one game to the other, even though they look and feel decent... It will just take some getting used to, as you go from one to the other... That being said, I had no real issue with the graphics... The UI does improve as things progress from ME1 to ME2 and eventually to ME3... Please note, there are Mods you can install for all 3 that improve some graphics aspects... Such as: Using ME3 faces/heads for some of the companions that are in ME1 and ME2 as well (for more consistency), or higher resolution video sequences, more hair cuts, and the list goes on... But modding the game can be a bit tricky, even more so when it comes to some graphics based modded updates, so be forewarned...

Game play is fun... Combat is played in a cover based form of First Person Shooter (FPS)... You use a mix of ranged weapons along with various types of abilities/skills... As your character gains levels, they gain points to spend towards improving abilities/skills, along with passive improvements... Although the progression system is not entirely the same from one game to the other, it is easy enough to understand and use... This allows for you to play your character how you want to, with the only restriction being your chosen character class/skill set... You can change your class, each time, from game to game as you progress from ME1 into ME2 and then eventually into ME3... Or you can leave it the same (points spent on progression from one title to the other do not move over as each game does have a slightly unique take on each class)... Even your characters visuals can either be moved over, or you can completely alter them... Key Choices are imported into the next title as you progress as well... Technically, you can start completely from scratch in each title as well, if you so choose...

Story/Dialogue is well done and chopped full of meaningful choices as well as flavor choices... The game uses a Dialogue Wheel which follows a particular pattern of investigation and responses... Depending on responses you choose, you can be nice or be mean or take the middle ground... And in some cases, you may also be presented with story altering choices (typically colored blue or red), similarly flavored, that build up different scores... And depending on those scores, sometimes the story will be altered later on... And most choices are remembered, regardless, especially when it comes to your characters Companions...

Companions make up your characters team, and not only do they help in combat, but they each can be influenced by your decisions, regardless if it has to do with their individual Story Lines or the Main Story Line... Some companions can be romanced (usually depending on your chosen sex - not all are heterosexual) and/or even be killed, all depending on your choices as you play each game... Not all companions follow you through all 3 games, but many do, sometimes depending on prior choices (i.e. they died, etc)... You can also spend points on companions skills/abilities or just let them auto-level, your choice... You can even equip them, depending on their class...

As far as story progression goes, here is the tricky part... Each Mass Effect game has both Main and Side stories/missions you can go through, along side some exploring, and resource gathering (yes, there is crafting)... Not all side missions are necessary for the main story to progress, but you would be missing out on some fun content (especially companion missions which can be pivotal to either their survival or how the story works out at the end of each game, so be warned)... There comes a time in all three titles, where you get to a mission or series of missions which are points of no return... Which can, depending on the title, keep you from going back and completing some side content prior to those points... You could wing it, or as I suggest, go look up a Mission Progression Guide for each game in order to save you the heart ache of missing out of some fun content... Or just wing it, and see how things turn out... This series of games easily allows for multiple playthrough's, making different decisions... Replay ability is a key bonus of this series of games...

Music and Sound in this game is good... Every character and dialogue is voiced over, and there is lots of ambient sounds and conversations going on as you play... Companions will sporadically have conversations, NPC's will talk to you as you walk by sometimes, with evolving dialogue... And the list goes on...

Overall, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is an awesome RPG experience, that I wish more Story Rich RPG's would aspire to... The game is a blast either modded or un-modded (even though I think it was an even richer experience modded - depending on the mods selected)... You could purchase the original ME1, ME2, and ME3 games but I think there is enough fixes and what not to make purchasing the Legendary Edition worth paying for instead... Would I pay full price? Sure, even though I bought it on-sale...

P.S. - This version of the game takes up a lot of drive space, much more so if you decide to go with certain mods, so take that into account when deciding where to install the game...

Venture into the unknown. I've heard wonderful things about the Mass Effect Trilogy, so I tried it out. The trilogy is amazing, especially if you're a fan of sci-fi games. There's a ton of content between the three games to last you a while. Although it starts slow, it picks up quickly and is always entertaining. Decisions you don't think twice about may come back to haunt or reward you in the later games, which, in my opinion, only enhances the experience.

As for the gameplay, it starts rough, but it's important to keep in mind that these games are somewhat old now. Plus, it gets better throughout the trilogy, and it's nice to see the improvements as you move from game to game. The biggest con is the organization of every game. Most of the gameplay aspects improve with every game, but the organization (map, quests/skills menu) is an aspect that I thought was always clunky and hard to work with. The difficulty of the trilogies organization made doing side quests confusing to do at times. Yet, although it was frustrating at times, the gameplay and story were entertaining, so I didn't mind.

Overall, if you're into sci-fi RPGs, I wholeheartedly recommend this game, especially if you can get it for sale at the price of $15 (that's what I paid). There may be some clutter with each game, but in the end, they're great experiences that I believe everyone can enjoy.

Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4

STEP 2
Beat together the butter and caster sugar until pale and creamy, then add the eggs, one at a time, slowly mixing through

STEP 3
Sift in the self-raising flour, then add the lemon zest and mix until well combined

STEP 4
Line a loaf tin (8 x 21cm) with greaseproof paper, then spoon in the mixture and level the top with a spoon

STEP 5
Bake for 45-50 mins until a thin skewer inserted into the centre of the cake comes out clean

STEP 6
While the cake is cooling in its tin, mix together the lemon juice and caster sugar to make the drizzle

STEP 7
Prick the warm cake all over with a skewer or fork, then pour over the drizzle – the juice will sink in and the sugar will form a lovely, crisp topping

STEP 8
Leave in the tin until completely cool, then remove and serve. Will keep in an airtight container for 3-4 days, or freeze for up to 1 month

Yes, yes, and YES!! I do recommend the Mass Effect trilogy. To all of you.

(Any technical aspect of this review for the legendary edition is going to be only about Mass Effect 2 and 3 on Steam Deck, as I played Mass Effect 1 in its original 2007 version. Otherwise, the review would mostly concern the trilogy as a whole. Will try to avoid spoilers as much as possible.)

Having just finished Mass Effect 3, I can honestly say that this series has been nothing short of a "rollercoaster of emotions". I laughed out loud way too many times, teared up on multiple occasions, felt plenty of goosebumps, and in general cared for the characters (and the world) more than I probably care about some real-life people. 

And let me tell you about the characters. I think the characters in this game, particularly the squad mates, are one of, if not the best, I've seen in any game. And boy do they develop throughout the trilogy! They have the best lines, and are extremely well-written; consistently so throughout all 3 games. You will have terrific teammates in ME1, then the roster expands into a bigger ensemble in 2, with 3 playing around with your feelings (mostly in good ways) by shaking things up a bit.

The story also has very high quality writing backing it. As a whole the premise is simple: you are the commander of a spaceship and it's your job to build up your crew and take down some galactic baddies. But the development of the individual plots in each game and the weaving of the bigger narrative of the series is filled with many nuances and twists, whilealso being paced with care. I was engaged the whole time, from the beginning moments of the first game to the end credits of the last, while also thinking about the games in-between sessions. 

Even though I "played" the last 2 games collectively for about 99 hours, the gameplay is my least favorite aspect of the series. Though to be fair, this is coming from someone who doesn't much care for shooter games. I'm pretty sure I would've been annoyed at all the shooting if it was any other game; instead I was only midly frustrated and mostly entertained. In terms of individual games, I think ME1 had too much weapon customizations for my taste, with 2 hitting a sweet spot, while 3 makes some quality of life changes along with bringing back some of the customizations from 1.

I also really liked the music in the trilogy, which keeps getting better with each sequel. ME1 is mostly electronic but also has some emotional tracks, whereas 2 and 3's music is more orchestral and bombastic. The songs toward the end are especially hard-hitting, for obvious reasons, with a certain final mission theme being a certified banger.

As for the technical stuff, I played on my Steam Deck through both ME2 and ME3 with little issues. I came across a negligible amount of visual glitches of the funny variety here and there but the games are otherwise solid with consistent performance. The only thing that did occasionally test my patience is the EA app, which would crash at game startup from time to time. I was able to get past that by backing up my save files, clearing the proton files on Steam Deck, then restarting the game. Oh, and, the game does indeed require that you're online the whole time you're playing. Also, the achievements don't work for ME2 and ME3 apparently, but it was a non-issue for me as I don't really care for achievements.

In summary, I believe this trilogy is such a fine example of video games as art forms that I can't help but wish that everyone would get to experience it. So much emotion and humor is richly mixed so that the Mass Effect games now will be one of my favorites of all time. 

Thank you for reading if you made it this far, and please drop a comment to share about your experience aboard the SSV Normandy.

It's an incredibly faithful remaster of the original works. The visual design and gameplay of the games, especially Mass Effect 1 and 2, is significantly enhanced but not fundamentally altered; the original BioWare vision was clearly a priority for this development team. I believe some from the original team even worked on MELE. On the tech enthusiast side of things, check out the "Visual Improvements" and "Gameplay Calibrations" articles on EA.com. Those articles will explain the details and nature of the actual remastering far better than I could here. 

On the gamer side of things, the reason I bought this title two years post-release is because manually modding the first two games and sacrificing content/save integration and some visual quality just got too much to deal with. BDtS and MEUITM 2021 were enough to get me from 2016-2019, but when I set it back up this year things had clearly changed for the worse. The ALOT mod (which includes MEUITM, MERLIN, Improved Static Lighting, ALOV, and options in each for HD/4K resolutions). is a comparable community remaster to the official BioWare/EA remaster - the installer is easy enough to manage, but there's a lot of things to be aware of and do correctly. And it still doesn't solve the content/save integration problem (namely, DLCs and save imports). 

So, I bought MELE and loved every minute of playing through Mass Effect 1-2. They did a phenomenal job on all fronts, included every DLC from each game except Pinnacle Station (I think the source code was corrupted?), and created a unified launcher for the trilogy. Cannot recommend enough, and know that MELE is on par with other remastered titles, such as Halo CEA, Gears of War: Ultimate Edition, Fable Anniversary, and StarCraft Remastered. Play it, love it, and mourn the ending to Mass Effect 3. 

Edit: there is one change I noticed that has not been mentioned anywhere: in the first cutscene of ME2, Miranda originally said "Shepard did everything right - saving the Citadel, even saving the Council" (depending on choices). Now, that part is simply excluded and the Illusive Man's response is altered. It's very odd and jarring, but everything else remains unchanged. Parts of Omega and the Collector Ship mission suffer from over-saturated black colors on-screen as well, sometimes with mild flickering.

Mass Effect: Legendary Edition does an outstanding job as far as a remaster/extended cut goes. All games have been upgraded with quality of life improvements, better graphics, and in some cases, new dialogue. None of it takes away from the original games, though; through endless wit, charm, and fantastic storytelling, the trilogy proves itself to be one of the best pieces of science fiction media ever made. Star Wars ain't got shit on this.

Because the original games have been preserved so well, I think it would be best to examine each game individually.

[b]Mass Effect:[/b] [u]7.8/10[/u]

Mass Effect 1 introduced us to the world of Mass Effect, and its through this game that we can find ourselves immersed in the lore of later titles. It started it all, though it was inevitable that there would be some missteps. The story is as robust as the other games, if a bit lacking in side missions. Exploring planets with the Mako was annoying, but you've probably heard that a million times by now. Lots of repeated assets between different levels made the game feel a bit samey, though it comes off as a product of its time more than anything. Despite all of this, it is a great introduction to the franchise, and it sets up the rest of the games well through fantastic world-building. The last couple hours of the game make up for a lot of the mistakes in my book. Saving the Citadel from Saren and the Geth will never not be sick as fuck.

[b]Mass Effect 2:[/b] [u]9.5/10[/u]

Yeah, I know everyone rates this game highly, but it's for good reason. Mass Effect 2 is inarguably the best entry in the entire series. It innovated not only the franchise, but also the entire gaming industry as a whole. Top-tier complex storytelling, worthwhile and exciting side missions, and a plethora of riveting characters made this entry endlessly enjoyable. 

It pioneered the dialogue wheel and set precedents for what modern, AAA RPGs could look like. The gunplay was vastly improved from Mass Effect 1, with useful powers that weren't just crutches. You could actually roleplay based on the class you chose, allowing you to specialize into certain playstyles. The Citadel, Omega, and Illium were all unique worlds to sink your teeth into. So many companions were added to this game, and none of them are boring or feel like filler (except for maybe Kasumi and Zaeed, but they're DLC characters, so they get a pass imo). The story itself was great-- "enemy of my enemy is my friend" times eleven-- with it culminating in a suicide mission that rewarded careful playthroughs.

One of my only hangups is that certain characters from ME1 weren't brought back as companions in ME2: Kaidan/Ashley, Liara, and Wrex. It made things pretty bittersweet when you inevitably visited them later in the game, especially if you romanced one of them in the previous game. Not only this, but these interactions were pretty thin, with Liara being the only one to get a real, dedicated mission. It wasn't earth-shattering, but definitely a nitpick, even if it would be fan-service-y.

Overall, this is the best Mass Effect title. If you even remotely like gaming, this is a must-play.

[b]Mass Effect 3:[/b] [u]8/10[/u]

Mass Effect 3 continued a lot of the same strengths of Mass Effect 2 with new innovations. Allowing players to pick whatever weapons they wanted was a solid quality of life improvement, opening up new opportunities for roleplaying. The powers felt less substantial in this game, and I often found myself opting for my weapons instead of my powers in firefights (even with maxxed-out Sticky Grenades and Incinerate). From what I hear, the multiplayer was actually pretty fun back in the day too, so I'm disappointed that it wasn't remastered in the Legendary Edition. 

The side missions took a noticeable dip in quality, however, with many of them being fetch quests. It was pretty damn annoying to have to spend an hour or two collecting obscure artifacts on random planets just to squeeze out some extra war assets. The overall story felt pretty compact and linear, with there being less main story missions compared to ME2. The missions were just as high-quality as the ME2 ones, though, if not higher-quality in some cases. There was also less of an ability to impact the story with your actions; at this point, you are pretty much set to defeat the Reapers somehow, Paragon or Renegade.

The companions were great if a bit sparse in this game. I missed having an actual team like in ME2. Here, you get a squad of about half as many people, though most of them are familiar faces. You can also revisit most of the survivors from ME2 through the Citadel DLC, which was a huge highlight for me. Reconnecting with all of your companions throughout the series in missions, dialogue, and a party was a very thoughtful and creative way to utilize fan-service, and it paid off. Romantic partners from the previous games were given the right amount of time and consideration, concluding their relationships with Shepard fittingly.

One of my biggest gripes with this game is one that is shared by most fans. Yes, it's the ending. Spoilers ahead. [spoiler]I hate how the only options that you're given are to control the reapers, synthesize all organic and inorganic life without their consent, destroy all inorganic life (including the Geth and EDI, despite the effort you just went through to save the Geth), or walking away, letting the world end again. I feel like this is just a really bad trolley problem between the destroy ending and the synthesize ending, which are the only two sensible ones in my mind. It comes down to this: save Shepard (destroy) or save inorganic life (synthesis)? I don't feel like it lines up with the rest of the series very well, as it tries too hard to push the message of life being about hard choices. The idea that synthetics and organics can only coexist by synthesis is also suspect: how, then, were the Quarians and the Geth able to resolve their differences? What about EDI and Joker being partners? I chose the destroy ending since I didn't trust the child and I knew beforehand that it was the only one that let Shepard live, but the thought of losing the entirety of the Geth and EDI after everything was pretty stupid. The synthesis ending was also too neat of an ending imo; the only consequence was Shepard's death, and in return, galactic peace. If the Reapers did this before and it failed, as the child says, why should it work this time?[/spoiler] There's a lot more to be said about the ME3 endings that I will be surely reading after this post, but just know that it's pretty disappointing.

As a whole, Mass Effect 3 is a great game with some minor flaws and a bad ending. It's a fitting conclusion to the series despite everything. 

[b]Overall:[/b] [u]9/10[/u]

Mass Effect: Legendary Edition has been a blast for me. It took me well over a month, over 125 hours, and two playthroughs of ME3 ([spoiler]DAMN YOU ILLUSIVE MAN[/spoiler]), but I can safely say that I enjoyed almost every moment of it. Again, Mass Effect is one of the best pieces of science fiction ever made, and I'm glad to have had the opportunity to play it while it's still pretty fresh. With another game in development, I'm cautiously optimistic to see how BioWare will continue to innovate with Mass Effect (despite the failure that was Andromeda). So far, it looks like it's got a lot going for it, with many familiar faces from the original team returning to work on it. But as far as it goes for this game, I'd recommend it in a heartbeat.

Recommendation is made on the assumption you pick this up on sale, as the RRP is high even for 3 games. They are all 2 generations old at this point.

Combat is much improved in the first instalment, and the relative unification of the combat systems across the titles is much appreciated in the pack.
Visuals are much improved in ME1, not as much in 2 & 3. Recommend using ALOT from the Nexus to fix texture problems that remain unfixed, especially above 1080p.
Performance is quite good, as you would expect for such old games. My 1070ti rig can run these comfortably at 4k60 without sacrificing settings.
The modding scene is relatively well-populated already, which means there are many ways to customise and improve the game to your liking.

The RRP is laughably high on this pack, but on a 20% off sale of more I can comfortably recommend it to sci-fi & RPG fans. Remember, the visuals are, by and large, NOT a step up from the original releases as Bioware just ignored all blurry, muddy 360-era textures.

The largest benefit of this remaster is bringing ME1 up to a level where it has replay value. The previous edition of ME1 wouldn't run well on newer PCs, with a ton of graphic and sound issues. Those are gone for the most part. 

I haven't finished ME3, so this will just be about parts 1 and 2. 

ME1

PROS: The overhaul on the gameplay and graphics is pretty noticeable. 
Combat is a bit more like parts 2 and 3, but still wonky, as it's based off of RNG, which parts 2 and 3 are not.
Performance on the PC is a huge improvement. I was getting some weird stuttering, but I disabled the EA overlay, and that fixed the problem.
The environments look much better, not nearly as dated. Lighting and textures really make a difference. 
The Mako is now tolerable. 

CONS: 

Despite the overhaul, it still is an older game, and that comes through. Since this is a remaster, and not a remake, that was to be expected. But sometimes you'll really feel the age of the game come through. 

Mako and Side Missions. Ok, this was a carryover problem from the original. The side missions in this game are mostly garbage. It's not that they're written poorly, it's that they are miserable to play, and that hasn't changed.

I mentioned the Mako is tolerable, but on the side missions, it isn't. That's because the planet design is god awful. So not only do you have terrible controls, but you have a planet design that actively exploits the worst part of the controls. There are several planets where map markers are virtually inaccessible due to the mountains they are on, or behind. And, the map checkpoints are usually just question marks, so you can spend 10 minutes trying to get to an object, only to find out you don't have the skill to open/examine it. 

I HIGHLY recommend either skipping some side content, or spreading it out, so you don't do too much of it at once. The story missions are great, and the usage of the Mako in them works, because you're going down paths. 

That is really my biggest gripe. 

I'll get to ME2 later maybe. ME2 didn't change much, but didn't need to. Still the best in the series.

It singlehandedly slaughtered my FPS from 240 to the values mentioned above.

To fix that, you can go to C:\Program Files\Electronic Arts\EA Desktop\EA Desktop and rename the file "IGO64.dll" to something else so that Origin doesn't launch its overlay ever again.

An epic masterpiece - Mass Effect Legendary Edition

Rating: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5 stars)

As an avid gamer and fan of the original Mass Effect trilogy, I couldn't wait to get my hands on the Mass Effect Legendary Edition. And what can I say? This remaster has far exceeded my expectations and is a truly epic masterpiece.

The graphical improvements are breathtaking. Every world, character, and battle looks so detailed and vibrant that you literally feel drawn into the Mass Effect galaxy. The game runs buttery smooth and the visual enhancements add a new intensity to the already compelling story.

But it's not just about the graphics. The revamped gameplay mechanics make combat more engaging and fluid. Character development and the skill system have been improved, which has allowed me to customize my squad members and adjust my play style. There are a variety of side missions and discoveries that bring the Mass Effect universe even more alive and make you feel like you're part of an epic odyssey.

The emotional depth of the characters is still impressive. The dialogue is believable and engaging, and the choices you make have an impact on the rest of the story. The bond I formed with my squad members felt so real that I really wanted to fight for them.

The Mass Effect Legendary Edition features not only the three main games, but all of the DLCs as well, making the overall experience even more comprehensive and rewarding. I was able to relive the trilogy and discovered additional content that I had previously missed.

Overall, I can wholeheartedly recommend the Mass Effect Legendary Edition. It's a must-have for any fan of the series and also a great way for newcomers to immerse themselves in the fascinating world of Mass Effect. Bioware has done a fantastic job with this remaster, proving that the fascination for the Mass Effect trilogy is timeless.

Prepare to be immersed in an epic space odyssey where you make decisions that affect the fate of the galaxy. Mass Effect Legendary Edition is an absolute masterpiece and a game not to be missed!

I've never played any of the Mass Effect games until recently picking up Legendary Edition. Here are my thoughts:

Mass Effect 1:
Pros: 
-great story, great characters, cool environments 
-amazing soundtrack
Cons:
-game play is dated, shooting is unengaging, largely from having to waste time hiding for your guns to cool down. Just messes up the flow. 
-Inventory system is cumbersome and unnecessary. 
-Vehicle sections would be good if they were fewer and farther between but get repetitive and boring with how much they are used. 
-The same 3 interior environments are also used over and over just with crates moved around. 
-Large number of side missions feel like filler in between the few story missions. 
- hacking mini games are just button mashing
Overall: a good game only for the story, game play is a relic of a less refined time.

Mass Effect 2:
Pros: 
-shooting feels much better with reloading rather than having to hide until your gun cools down. Combat overall is tighter and more engaging. 
- limited vehicle sections with added platforming so you're not just driving across empty landscape
- characters and story are still a highlight
- inventory system replaced by well balanced upgrade system. 
- hacking mini games are more varied and aren't beatable just by button mashing anymore. 
- side missions are more integrated in the story and feel less like filler...mostly
Cons: 
-achievements are broken. There is a fix for windows if you mess around in the files but I play on Linux and can't be bothered
-soundtrack is still good but not as good as first game. 
Overall: big improvement over the first game in almost every way. Very fun. 

Mass Effect 3:
Pros: 
-Once again, great story and characters
-best gameplay in the series. Very tactical.

Cons:
-like in 2, achievements are broken
-more like mixed than con, but the ending. I don't think anybody really likes the endings, and  I think the reason the endings were so controversial is because the game tries so hard to push Synthesis as the Golden Ending that fixes all of the galaxy's problems when its so easy to poke so many holes in it with minimal thought and effort. The one thing positive that I will say about the endings is that a main theme of the series is victory through sacrifice. In the first 10 minutes of ME3 it is made very clear to the player that it is a war and in war you can't save everyone no matter how hard you try. This is something that is captured very well in the endings overall.

Ending discussion SPOILERS

- **Synthesis** : Galaxy wide peace and very quick rebuilding from the damage of the war. Everyone seems happiest in this. The problems are the philosophical and ethical implications. Are everyone still themselves, with their glowing eyes and circuits, holding hands and signing kumbaya with the Reapers who up until moments ago were harvesting them and their families? Is it right for Shepard to unilaterally alter all life in the galaxy on a molecular level to be cyborgs, and isn't this fundamentally what the Reapers were doing anyway? This ending could have used much more explanation and buildup. It comes off as meaning to be the "Golden Ending" by the developers, but comes out of nowhere and is very superficial. It seems like a problem that the Golden Ending involves making the galaxy into a hivemind. 

This also seems to go against another theme of the series of technology being "gifted" to a species before its culturally ready to handle it causing more problems than it solves, see the Krogan and Asari. Maybe synthesis is the next stage of evolution, but is it right for one person to just force it on everyone with the push of a button? Why does the starchild promise there WILL be peace with Synthesis, is everyone mind controlled? If everyone isn't mind controlled, won't it just be a matter of time before people find more reasons to fight? The Geth were fighting the Reapers and they're both synthetic, shouldn't they get along by the org vs synth logic? What if another enemy comes from outside the Milky Way and hacks the new hive mind? It happened to the Rachni. Javik admits part of the reason the Protheans lost to the Reapers is that they were too homogenous. How is homogenizing everyone into cyborgs to force "peace" really beneficial? 

What if the starchild is lying and you just indoctrinated the whole galaxy? I know that the developers have said since that he isn't lying, each of the options are what they say on the tin, but Synthesis is so poorly explained its really a problem.

- **Control** : Assuming Shepard is Paragon, this is the best for the galaxy Short and Medium term. The Shepard-AI controls an intergalactic peace keeping force that can rebuild all the damage quickly and then stick around to protect the universe from any potentially unruly species, like the Krogan, Leviathans, or future synthetic uprisings. However, the extreme long term is questionable. After a few 100k or millions of years who is to say Shepard AI doesn't go crazy and become a new starchild? Power corrupts and Shepard AI is a god in all but name now.  How many millions of years before he starts seeing people only as numbers?

- **Destroy** - Short term bad, long term good as things mostly return to pre-Reaper status quo. Extreme long term questionable as the future generations might make synthetics that go and kill them all. However I like to think that organics will have learnt enough from the Reaper Wars to prevent this. Downside is exterminating all current synthetic life, but "the needs of the many..." and such.

My Thoughts: I don't buy that organic vs synthetic conflict where synthetics wipe out organics is inevitable. Organics are going to war with other organics and driving each other to extinction all the time in the backstory of the game, why are synthetics being involved so beyond the pale? We see in the game its possible for the Geth and Quarians to make peace. We also see its possible for the organic Quarians to wipe out the synthetic Geth, depending on how things go. The Protheans were also winning their own war against their synthetics until the Reapers showed up to "save" them. There was another background species living at the same time of the Protheans, the Zha'til, who lived in symbiosis with their AI until the Reapers showed up and forced the AI to rebel. 

I think the real lesson is CONFLICT is inevitable, organic vs synthetic is irrelevant.  The Reapers have been running off of a questionable conclusion that is difficult to verify or disprove because they have been interfering with the data for so long. The Reapers wipe the slate clean every 50k years or so forcing organics to start over in order to "save" them from synthetics. The side effect of this is organics can never learn from the mistakes of the past and are forced to repeat the same mistakes again and again. This is then used by the Reapers as evidence of the inevitability of these problems and the need for a solution. The solution might be to let life run its course, come what may. Unity through diversity, another theme of the series. 

The best option is Destroy, as it wipes the slate clean of the Reapers allowing both current organic life and future synthetic life to forge its own destiny for the first time in over a billion years.

Still one of my favorite role playing stories. Well worth doing everything you can find to accomplish during each campaign. The games together are so well fleshed out that I plan to play it for the 17th time after a short break. Despite not being perfect, this trilogy made me laugh out loud, cry and genuinely play with a sense of urgency towards saving the universe. Immensely satisfying.

I never played the ME series when they were first released, which is insane because I love space. However, in preparation for Starfield's release, I was looking for games with a similar idea to calm my excitement for a new Bethesda IP, and decided to bite the bullet and buy and play MELE.
A little over 400 hours in and just started a 3rd playthrough. I'm not a fan of ME1, because the controls and maps are janky compared to ME2 and 3, but it's also a game that was released in 2007 for Xbox 360, so, makes sense. For that, I can't hate on it.
That all being said, 2 and 3 are definitely the best, the characters and story is much more fleshed out, albeit the third game was clearly rushed (though still well made) and, even with the extended cut scenes that are within MELE, personally, I still find the alternate endings lack luster. Regardless, the games have replayability, even though ME1 is much like trying to survive through tedious things - unless you skip the small things and only play the story - and I'm incredibly excited to see what BioWare does for Mass Effect 5 (4 to those who would rather forget Andromeda), and have been hanging on to every bread crumb they drop.

Overall, 10/10, would recommend at least one solid playthrough of all three games, even in 2023 when most games have phenomenal graphics and the bar is incredibly high.

A very good modernization of a a game that was never really dated in the first place! Mass Effect always looked strikingly good, for its age. It aged well. I remember being impressed of ME1's graphics, for years after it had released. Toward the end of the 360 generation I revisited it and it still looked nearly as it did in 2007. 

It plays and feels much like it did in the past. Yes, they removed some of the the sexy shots of characters, like Miranda. I disagree with it in light of her explanation of being pretty confident about having been "genetically engineered to be perfect." Anyway...it was great to relive the stories again. Though, just like in 2013, you will be disappointed by Mass Effect 3's different colored ending. That was the ending that took all of my love out of the previous games. All that time, perfecting my play throughs, in an effort to have the (hopefully) ultimate ending for Mass Effect 3 and flushed it down the drain. 

The only issue, however, always was the open ended nature. Once you beat each game? That's it. Depending on which title you play, if you hadn't done many of the side quests, prior to beating the story, you won't have much to do afterward, since some of the side quests need to be done, before the story ends. This means that replayability is dependent upon how often you are willing to beat each title. You can't replay missions and, so, there's really nothing to do afterward. It's not The Elder Scrolls...and I hope that changes, come ME4. I would like to see an open world version of this title. 

If you haven't played the series? Then you absolutely must! I mean, you just have to!  I mean, at least 1-2.
I still question the graphics superiority of this game, versus, the graphics of the modded version of the game, as those textures were ground-up recreated and this remaster uses upscaling. They are pretty close, with the modded version of the original titles sometimes having the upper hand. So, not much changes if you've already played the PC versions with high rest texture packs. Plus, you get to see Miranda booty (lol) in those.

My only wish? A Halo Master Chief Collection approach at allowing your favorite missions be replayable. Many of you will just want to jump in and play your favorite moments. They should implement a mode where you can just choose your crew (alive or dead in your play through) and just roll through that mission. I'll bet the most played mission will be the Collector Ship in ME2. Either this? Or implementing a whole new survival/ game mode might be fun too. You could one-up the latter by letting friends join your game and taking control of MIranda, Edi, Liara, or any of the known allies. Even Ashley and Kaiden.

Bought this franchise as a game to play on the side, something to do while I wait for the next big thing,
After an hour into the first game I was hooked, the story, the characters, the setting and world building was impeccable - The first game uses dialog and the scenario of the game to really pull you into the mass effect world, I found myself watching youtube videos on the First Conctact Wars and The History that same night after jumping off the game. 

The 2nd Game, Now enveloped into the story, the reaper threat confirmed, and my cast of characters that I had built a relationship with throughout, it was the games peak I believe, easily my favourite. A twist in working with Cerberus, the characters developing throughout, Garrus and Tali easily became my go two picks, Tali is an amazing character, and nobodys beating my boy Garrus! - The climax of the 2nd Game was intense and enthralling, and I generally felt scared to lose anybody, although I did on my first playthrough. 

3rd Game - The story was set in stone, all character developed, fully invested into finishing the fight, a great game in it's rights, till the ending. The ending unfortunantely just "lacks" - I felt as though all my time with these characters to spend my last few moments alone was a diservice, I felt like I had made a lot of relationships with these NPCs and to have them not there in the final moment was upsetting to say the least. Overall a very good game still, gameplay was better, so many weapons and armours, nicknacks, loads, The DLC was amazing for ME3 too, aswell as ME2s DLC. 

Overall this franchise changed me, it's easily become my favourite and I can't stop thinking about it, I generally really enjoy this franchise, and I hope ME4 (Not Andromeda) Brings us back to the timeline and we see our beloved characters again. - Till ME4.

What's another playthrough-- am I right? I'm always amazed at how distinct and different each one of them are; based on teammates accompanying you, romances, and choices-- I'm always left feeling like I'm still unpeeling layers from an onion that has just another corner I've neglected to pay attention to.

  The LE is fantastic, improving and streamlining so many features that came directly from suggestions made from the fans of this series. Despite it's close association with EA, it still feels like a love letter to fans, the whole experience feels "like the first time" in so many ways.

  I've tweaked a few streamlining issues with mods(most of which are applied earlier in the series-- If I don't specialize in a weapon, why am I carrying it?), but overall, the improvements are impactful and increase the longevity of my love for this series.

  I would say that the only downside is that one your playthrough is complete, is that you don't have anywhere to go. Andromeda is a shitshow, unable to load through Steam, and despite that, is a lackluster comparison-- merely a fart in the wind in comparison.

Mass Effect is the best gaming franchise I've ever played and is barley above the Metal Gear Solid series. So when I heard there was going to be a remastered collection on the 3 games I decided to make this collection my first ever pre order on steam. $60 is such a generous offer since it includes every dlc for all 3 games that provide 20+ more hours of gameplay. Mass Effect 1 has been remade entirely but 2 and 3 don't have much remade to them other than some better shadows and textures. All in all, 10/10. Mass Effect 2 still the best game ever made.

I do recommend the game based on the good elements of the game and how long you can play the game but be aware of the rough edges. The good, the bad and the ugly. 

The good
3 games with almost all the DLC's included, for ME2 and ME3 all the DLC's. Extensiive story-lines with many options which give a strong replay-value, character which you can tweak to fit your playstyle and which also gives a strong replay-value. Great music, great story-buildup, good cinematography in especially Mass Effect 2, good action in especially ME3 and some DLC's which have an interesting storyline, lot of humor, good action and world-building. 

The bad. 
ME3 could have been even better if EA wouldn't have pulled some of the best people off the project in favor of their serial-games (sport and BattleField). Such a shame! As a result the cinematography and story are less good in Mass Effect 3 (they tried to solve it by patching it later) and the music is still good but less coheren due the absence of the lead composer of Mass Effect 2. 

The ugly. 
EA's launcher is dreadful. I recorded the launching process, it took an entire minute to get in the game, this on a PCIe4 SSD and with a Ryzen 3700X, DDR4 @3533 MT/s (16-18-16-16) and a 5700 XT. You click on launch, 10-15 seconds later you finally see Origin pop up, then after around 30-35 seconds finally the introscreen shows up and after around 41 seconds you get the main-menu, then it takes another 20'ish seconds to load the game itself. Come on! The game should be playable within 10 seconds, there is not that much data to be loaded in the RAM and videocard-memory. EA requires you for this game to always have an internet connection. Come on EA! This is why people pirate games. Dumb move! Don't punish paying customers. I don't know the current minimumprice of this game (so what the regular discount-% is)  but people are not going to pirate the game to not spend $15 or whatever on this bundle of 3 games. The ease of use (download it whenever you want, not needing that space on your SSD all the time, the game reliably working for many years) makes it worth it for gamers to just buy the game. But bully gamers with this internet-requirement crap and gamers get rewarded for pirating. Many developers are more flexible with this internet connection requirement, for example by 'only' requiring it once a week or whatever. Also consider those people who just don't have the ability to always be online, like people who work on see. EA does not limit piracy with this always online nonsense, it encourages it this way.

[h1]Game Impressions[/h1]

[b]+ Choice acknowledgement:[/b] The decisions you make in each of the first two games have ramifications in the latter entries. These can range from short e-mails from people you helped in the past, just keeping in touch, to the (in)ability to prevent a genocide and [spoiler]subsequent suicide of probably the most likable companion[/spoiler]. This is probably the most impressive aspect of the games; few developers have the foresight and guts to soft lock game-altering decisions based on a prequel save file import.

[b]+ Companions:[/b] Most of them are well written, with amusing interactions during missions. ME2 had the largest cast and some ended up being forgettable. Regardless, the companion quests from ME2 forward are good across the board. I enjoyed seeing one specific heist-themed quest that was intriguing but too simplistic serve as a template for a much improved version in ME3. Here, I have to give props to the writers for being able to create quality gag companion quests in ME3; today, I don't think the studio would be able to do such a consistently good job in this regard.

[b]+ Set pieces:[/b] I simply enjoy the expansive sceneries (mostly skyboxes) and imposing vistas that Bioware are able to create in their games. These really help set the scale for the game world and put the decisions you make into perspective. That is not to say that the level design leaves to be desired; in fact, the [spoiler]march across the Shadow Broker's ship in ME2[/spoiler] ended up being one of my favorite levels in any game. Also, it's worth mentioning that ME3 had significantly better produced cut-scenes (camerawork, music, etc.), at lest during its first few hours.

[b]+ Mini games:[/b] It amazes me how ME3 can have so many mini games (most of them simplistic, to be fair) when CDPR weren't able to include [i]anything[/i] of the sort in Cyberpunk 2077. I was not expecting any of them to be in the game, and I don't think most people will find much worth engaging with them regularly. However, they serve as great recreational activities to do with companions when on shore leave. Would have wished that these were not just scripted events and you'd have been able to invite them at any time.

[b]+ World exploration with Mako:[/b] A very enjoyable aspect of the first game that didn't make the cut in either of the sequels. The vehicle controls in low gravity made it fun to just wonder across planet surfaces. Would have liked to see a bit more biome diversity, but what's there could be considered a prototype for Death Stranding's main game loop.

[b]+ Voice acting:[/b] Was pleasantly surprised to hear Martin Sheen and Shohreh Aghdashloo in ME3 and ME2 respectively.

[b]- Steam port:[/b] Yet another example of the abhorrent practice of integrating third party launchers into Steam releases. In this case, it wasn't just a problem of boot time. I actually had to patch the Origin executable in order to prevent framerate dips due to its overlay (that you can't disable from the client's settings menu). In ME1, the game literally became unplayable while on the Normandy, with 5-15 fps. Moreover, EA's done a shoddy job integrating all three games into one application, at times having to go through 5-6 menus / loading screens just to resume a game.

[b]- Useless loot:[/b] This was most problematic in ME1 where you have a 300 item inventory capacity. The inventory management problem becomes less grating but the quality of the loot does not improve at all. There's no point during any of the games when you get excited for a drop. It's a shame that ME3 has so many weapons because during the first 2-3 missions you can just get a rechargeable laser rifle (akin to the weapons of ME1 - ME2 introduced ammo for all weapons) and it's so good that you don't have to even try out anything else for the remainder of the game.

[b]- Obvious console port:[/b] This is not an issue with the Legendary Edition, but with the original releases. Too many game functions are linked to the Space bar (i.e.: running, take / switch cover, interact) and you can't even directly vault over an obstacle; you first have to take cover behind it, then jump over. Starting with ME2, the UI also became unbearably large, covering most of the screen with useless fluff. Moreover, during the ME2 tutorial you even get an [i]in-game achievement[/i] for hitting a headshot... yet somehow, the Steam achievements have been broken since Origin got replaced by the EA Launcher...

[b]- ME1 shows it's age:[/b] Or rather, the lack of resources available to the developers at the time. It's a bit annoying, knowing that whatever dialogue option you choose, the same voice line is used. Moreover, the dialogue trees haven't been properly checked (e.g.: high charisma lets me spare some guards and the enemies later accuse me of murdering them). Then there are some design decisions that are simply moronic, like giving a [i]trained soldier[/i] just enough stamina to sprint for 10m before running out of breath. Not to mention that the recharging stamina bar is hidden while your weapon is stowed, which is preferable while out of combat since it increases your field of view. It's like the developers didn't even play test their own game before release...

[b]- Degradation of RPG elements:[/b] In my opinion, ME1 has more charm than the latter two games due to how it approaches quest design. If in ME2-3 you land on a planet, shoot your way through enemies and reach an objective, in ME1 you have an overarching goal but you need to discover and execute intermediary steps towards it. This doesn't just involve shooting your way out of an arena, but also uncovering clues and talking with NPCs. Even if there's usually a single solution to a problem, this design is much more rewarding, and the latter entries lost sight of that.

[b]- Resource probing in ME2:[/b] Probably one of the most idiotic systems I've encountered in a game. This activity is mind-numbingly boring and has no real impact on the game. Most upgrades are unattractive anyway and those that you'd want to purchase can be obtained with mission rewards. [i]However[/i], these activities become required if you wish to upgrade your ship. The ship upgrades have no visible gameplay impact (not like you have space battles) and only serve as a numeric check during the final mission to determine if 1-2 of your companion die during an initial cut-scene. The game never explains that this could be a possibility and the loss of certain characters could completely screw up your ME3 run. So if you look up the selection algorithm for the sacrificial companions and it turns out that one of them is critical to the story going forward (don't know how you'd find that out without spoliers), you'd be forced to grind resources to prevent the game from locking you out of critical story paths in the [i]next[/i] game.

[b]- Brainded AI:[/b] As much as the game likes to talk about the threat that AI poses to organic beings, it does a piss-poor job implementing it in its NPCs. The enemies have a tendency to leave cover and charge at you back-first (at least in ME1). Sometimes, during scripted events, it's possible to rush past the enemy line and cause them to lose track of you. So you can single handedly mow them down from behind and they won't even acknowledge your existence.

[b]- Bugs:[/b] Not that many, but there are a few game breaking ones. For example, a cut-scene fails to load during a scene transition. You retain control of the character but the screen goes black. The only option is reloading the game from the main menu (not for the in-game menu screen). So it may help saving from time to time, at least in between missions.

An excellent collection of a trilogy that still remains one of the best game experiences ever, where your characters and choices you built from the first game continue throughout the entire trilogy. A true role playing experience where you get to decide how major events in this galaxy panned out from beginning to end. The first Mass Effect in this edition is the most remastered of  the 3, which is quite welcomed as the evolution from 1 to 2 was quite significant when these were first released, now the first game keeps up a bit more with its sequels. However, the essence of the first game still remains intact, so some of the leveling and combat still isn't as refined, just a lot more polished but still retains its style for those that still prefer and love that first game's gameplay design. The graphics have also been significantly upgraded to keep up with the 2nd and 3rd game, the same applies to the 2nd and 3rd game, who also got a visual upgrade, more significantly the 2nd game as overall the 3rd game was quite ahead for its time. The other big and important feature from this collection is that it features all the essential DLCs for the story, so now you can truly experience the game (specially the 3rd game) the way it was always meant to be without having to figure out how to get previous DLCs. 

But if you own the previous versions of these games on PC with all DLCs, is it worth playing this version? I think overall it does make significant improvements to justify upgrading, not to mention the modding scene for this version is the active one now, with a lot of great mods coming left and right to amplify the experience on these games. However, in terms of old bugs and such, the game hasn't changed much, so the modding community has done unofficial community patches to each game on the trilogy to tackle most of these bugs that were carried from the first 3 games, so I recommend checking those out. However, the current major issue and reason for downvoted reviews is EA Play. To play this game, you need to launch the EA app, now that's not terrible in principle, the problem is that the game will encounter significant issues because of this, including no longer being able to obtain trophies for the game. Ever since I changed from Origin to EA App (as forced by EA), I can longer get any trophies/achievements unfortunately. However, I still upvote this game as this experience is still too good that everyone should experience at least once.

Really enjoying this one, especially when you consider it's a remaster of a much older game series.  Interesting and engaging characters and story, very good space exploration, fun combat, beautiful visuals.  Lots of nods to classic scfi from people like Ridley Scott, Jim Cameron, John Carpenter, and Robert A. Heinlein.  

It maybe can't touch the great CDPR games in terms of writing and characters, but who can these days?  All I know is that it's keeping my interest in a way that more recent RPG's like Hogwarts Legacy and Horizon Zero Dawn could not.  It's maybe lacking in some quality of life features that we've come to expect in modern RPG's, but for me this has been nothing too distracting or annoying.  It's curious though how way back in the day Bioware created a perfectly viable and fun military space opera, yet fast forward to today and we have Chris Roberts' Star Citizen nowhere near beta release after nearly a decade and half billion in crowdfunding dollars.  

I would also add that this series made Jennifer Hale one of gaming's first voice acting superstars, and deservedly so.  She does an amazing job breathing life into Commander Shepard.  On a related note, one of my pet peeves from the MSM journos and fan community is the trite and cheesy term 'FemShep' (but please don't take me too, too seriously here ;)

Anyway, I may update this review as I advance into MA2 and 3, but for now I would close by saying that this game has greatly exceeded my expectations.  Thank you to my Steam friends who recommended this series to me, and as always thanks everyone for taking the time to read this.

I think your enjoyment of the Legendary Edition package on Steam will be directly proportional to your ability to weather and fight against it's not insignificant bugs. I'm writing this in mid-2023. The game released May 2021 and there are STILL problems with it.

Graphical issues I can endure and there aren't a ton here. I get t-poses from characters here and there. Occasionally you'll kill an enemy and rather than the game playing their death animation they will just freeze in mid air. Or their death animation from gunfire will cause them to randomly rag doll 100 feet in the air. VERY infrequently but still there. But overall the new coat-of-paint on the Legendary Edition looks pretty good. I'm playing the game on a 21:9 ultrawide which is supported (though I wish companies would come up with a more seamless transition between 16:9 cut scenes to "ready-to-play" ultrawide sequences other than black pillar bars just popping out.)

One annoying aspect of the LE package (ignoring for a moment the EA/Origin app fiasco) is launching the game requires you to go into a trilogy launcher (with an unskippable opening animation) from which you then pick the game you want to play which THEN starts THAT games unskippable opening animations before dropping you in your save. This seems like a concession built for consoles that is clunky and maddening on PC (especially adding the Origin/EA boot layer ON TOP of THAT.)

But there are a handful of actually painful bugs. For superfans who have played through the series multiple times, one of the carrots in the package is achievement chasing (the achievements have been retooled from the original releases (in the case of ME 1, thank God,)) and I have run into a bug that, past a certain point, causes me to be unable to open new achievements EVEN ON A BRAND NEW SAVE. Steam shows my achievements unlocked to a particular point but the menu screen of any specific game shows that I have unlocked every single achievement for every game, including the Insanity run. I've done some Googling and this STILL unfixed bug happens to people randomly during their play-through of the trilogy. Mine happened in the opening of the third game. 

The problem (apparently) was introduced when EA switched from the Origin app to the EA app. And because there is a User profile file independent of your saves, starting a new save carries the problem over. Worse, the issue gets sync'd to the cloud through the launcher so deleting your local saves doesn't fix the issue. At one point you could manually download the old Origin app as a workaround but EA has since pulled that installer from it's site.

A couple months ago, a new workaround became possible. If you're experiencing the issue, you can blow away your user profile file (google for the location,) boot the EA app, switch it to offline mode (an ability they added this year,) and then boot the game. Since then I've been able to pickup ME 3 again and keep achievement chasing. However, I boot the EA app and switch it to offline mode before every play session, even though I'm not certain that's necessary.

As I got into 3 though, I found that the imported save somehow didn't reflect all of the decisions I had carefully made in my play-through of Mass Effect 2. Avoiding spoilers, so far no Jack, no Legion (which makes a tough Rannoch story-beat then impossible.)

The sad part is that I know the real problem here is me: I paid for this, knowing better. I have put nearly 100 hours in at this point and know that I will put in more. Because Mass Effect is still Mass Effect, one of my favorite game series of all time - even if the package it's wrapped in is depressingly beneath it's legacy. If PC is your only option, this is the one you want to buy. The individual originals on Steam don't support controller and STILL require you to use EA's launcher. But if you have the option of picking up the package on Xbox or PS, I would grab it there instead. They won't be perfect either but I'd be shocked if they were in as sorry a state as this one.

I never played the trilogy when it was first released. Last year, I had a month of down time and was strongly recommended this game. Now, after 3 playthroughs I can say without a doubt that Mass Effect (the trilogy as a whole, not just the first game) is my favourite game of all time.

The story is gripping, thought-provoking and action packed, the characters are (90-95% of the time) well fleshed out and felt like old friends after you've done some missions with them and finally the story lines and quest structures hold up well. Even the first game (which can be a bit fetch-questy and most side quests are the same rotation of interiors slightly redesigned for each quest) still convinced me to explore every single quest in my second and third playthroughs!

I could spend hours talking about all the things that I love about this game (and have with friends) but I'll sum it up like this. I am so happy that I got to experience this game, but at the same time, I am also incredibly sad that I'll never get that "first playthrough" experience again. Now if any of this sounds up your alley, go buy the game, you have a galaxy to save!

P.S. I recommend designing your characters face yourself rather than using the default Maleshep or Femshep options. Yes, they are classics, don't get me wrong, but it will truly make it feel like the Shepard you're playing is unique to YOU.
