Mass Effect.  What, really, can I say about Mass Effect that thousands of others haven't said already?  It's an icon of Bioware before they went on to make Andromeda and Anthem.  It's a trilogy encompassing many different sci-fi aesthetics, from the shiny, Star Trek-like utopias, to the dirty, grungy underbellies that works like Deus Ex and Star Wars revel in, to the 'eldritch space' that things like the Lovecraft Mythos, Kirby, and Florida all excel in.

Here's my hat in this overcrowded hat-rack of a ring, then.

Mass Effect: LE is the original trilogy, given a major coat of visual polish, and bundled with almost all the single-player DLC.  Almost, because Pinnacle Station's source code was corrupted.  Whoops.

In gameplay terms, Mass Effect is half role-playing game, half cover-based third-person shooter.  Between talking with your crew, tackling sidequests, or going from point of interest A to point of interest B, you're taking cover behind benevolently placed chest-high walls and shooting at people.  Or using powers (this series' take on spells, buffs, debuffs, crowd-control, etc.) on said people.  Or both.  Often both.

This formula does get tweaks between games; ME1 had all weapons have unlimited ammo, but limited time to fire before they overheated, and Powers ran on individual cooldowns.  Weapon modifications were plentiful, weapons themselves were quite common and often came in duplicates, but most of them were the same basic archetype with a few numbers tweaked between them, with how you modified them causing the performance differences.  Armor was the same; Visual differences and different numbers, but a lot of survivability came from modding it.

ME2 gave all weapons thermal sinks, limiting their ammo but letting you fire away, and you could only use one Power at a time; Cooldowns were still case-by-case, but you could no longer just play your hotbar like an accordian to win fights.  Armor and weapons were much rarer, and almost always performed differently or 'upgraded' off your older weapons.  Modifications were excised or made class-wide and researched in the lab instead of found by the dozen in the field.

ME3 struck something of a middle ground.  Your weapon load affects your cooldowns, so a lightly-armed Shepard can sling Powers around like alcohol at a college party, while one bogged down with guns aplenty will find their cooldowns rather lengthy indeed.  Modifications are back to being found in the field and back to being applied to weapons on a case-by-case basis, but now you only need one copy to modify every weapon in that mod's class; Spares merely upgrade the mod itself.

And now, I'm going to break from my usual routine and discuss each game as it's own entity.


[h1]MASS EFFECT 1[/h1]
[i][b]"YOU EXIST BECAUSE WE ALLOW IT.  AND YOU WILL END BECAUSE WE DEMAND IT."[/b][/i]

The original game was arguably the most in need of gameplay fixes; While the rest of the trilogy could, and did, receive a major graphical touch-up, the first game had a lot of oddities and problems that, I'm happy to say, LE took the time to fix up, especially regarding the Mako.  It's a much smoother game on the actual 'game'-y bits, as opposed to a very solid story backing up a game with some very rough edges.

Visually, this is the game that most represents 'Shiny Sci-Fi'; A dream of a better tomorrow, a clean future where curves are the new edges, where humanity isn't alone and most of the aliens are friends, or at worst, political foes rather then military ones, and where the confrontations involve mostly robots, or hostile aliens on the fringes of galactic society.

It's story is not quite light-hearted, Virmire and the introduction of [b]Sovereign[/b] spring to mind as counter-points, but of the trilogy, it does have that sort of 'Sci-fi movie'-like feel.  What begins as 'stop a rogue state-sanctioned black-ops agent' soon spirals into the eldritch territory, but proves that, yes, the spooky eldritch abomination can be punched out if everyone works together.  Mass Effect 1's overall storyline was a bit basic, a bit bare-bones in spots; It almost feels like it wasn't going to be a trilogy at first, and 2 and 3 were greenlit after this launch.

Regardless, Mass Effect 1 is a good game on it's own two feet, standing as a primer and introduction to the trilogy, and introducing and setting up the stakes for the rest of the series to follow.

What followed it up was even better.


[h1]MASS EFFECT 2[/h1]
[i]"We will fight for the lost!"[/i] 
[spoiler]It's a damn shame that line was advertising-only, huh...[/spoiler]

If Mass Effect 1 was Star Trek, Mass Effect 2 was Mirror-Universe Star Trek.  Whereas ME1 had you traipsing about the well-lit and smooth Citadel, ME2 has you gallivanting around the gritty, grungy nightclub-slash-crime den of Omega and the beautiful, but completely amoral, Illium.

If ME1 was about listening to dialogue and making choices, ME2 had that, but added quick-time reactions called Interrupts, which allowed you to potentially influence events by making direct choices mid-dialog, be it hugging someone in distress or politely encouraging someone to take a break via a helpful 20,000-volt two-step nap.  Where ME1's story was reactionary, reacting to new threats or potential problems, ME2's story is pre-emptive, with Shepard and co. moving on leads ASAP and never staying in port for long.

If ME1's HUD was a soothing blue, ME2's was a slightly louder orange.  If ME1 politely asked you to use your Powers but gave gunslingers nigh-unlimited room to operate, ME2 forced you to use them as ammo was depleted and weapon after weapon greeted your request to fire with a loud 'click' and nothing to replace it.

If Mass Effect 1 was A New Hope, Mass Effect 2 was The Empire Strikes Back; A game about overwhelming odds, where the heroes don't quite succeed despite their best efforts, and where the threat is still out there, emboldened, and bigger then ever.

What followed it up was better still, after some time.


[h1]MASS EFFECT 3[/h1]
[i]Take.  Earth.  Back.[/i]

Mass Effect 1 was shiny.  Mass Effect 2 was gritty.  Mass Effect 3 is scarred.

The game deals with war, the weight of a galaxy resting on your shoulders, what that [i]means[/i] for those so weighed down, and death.  It deals with the end of days, the desperation of those still alive, the death of the old ways and the fight to survive and thrive.  It deals with fighting the eldritch, the unknown, at it's peak.

The game reminds you of the bleak tone, time and time again.  Nothing is safe or sacred.  Allies who you've known the entire trilogy, or even since ME2, can and will die, sometimes unavoidably, but often due to your choices not working out.  Races you've come to learn about die, or perhaps experience a resurgence, from the consequences of choices made all throughout the trilogy.  ME1 and ME2 were setup, and ME3 is the payoff.

If the prior games gave you lots of resources, and limited-but-fair resources, ME3's are finite and painfully so.  Heavy weapons are now a rarity, a beloved sight for sore eyes, rather then an impressive mainstay of your arsenal.  Powers retain ME2's system of 'use one, all cool down', but that cooldown can be modified by weapon load; Do you take less, or lighter weapons to cast faster, at the expense of potentially running dry and having to rely only on powers mid-firefight, or do you take the heaviest guns you can and relegate your powers to one-offs or quick-use panic buttons for when things get especially bad?

ME3 asks the player to make tough choices, all the time.  And you, the player?  You can only hope you made the right ones.

[b]Get ME: LE.  It's the best way to experience the trilogy.[/b]

Every time hope springs up that EA has finally learned its lesson, it trips some kind of switch and resets to its factory default setting of malicious incompetence. ME:LE is a game-containing product that you have to fight for the right to enjoy it.

Let's start with the undeniable pros: ME1 gameplay is greatly improved. That's about it. That's the only major, immediately noticeable improvement across all three games. Admittedly, it's a *vast* improvement. Gunplay is far better, elevator rides can be skipped, you don't have to play the damn thing thrice to 100% it, there is a marginally better way to sort through all the junk, etc.

Everything else is some monkey paw nonsense. Graphics are shored up, textures are noticeably higher-resolution, some ME3 assets have been backported into earlier games and there's the rare treat of real-time reflections. Yay. Dynamic lighting in ME1 is outright broken. The default FOV is an unusable atrocity. NPC appearances range from weird to jarring. Newly broken textures and animations would take an entire page to list. Boo.

Audio: the store page boasts, quote-unquote, "full-resolution audio". I don't know how full is it or where that resolution is supposed to be, but sound is consistently bad across all three games. Volume levels are wildly inconsistent. Dialogue gets randomly cut off. Lip sync occasionally fails. An entire subset of enemies in ME2 is missing *all* of their audio - it's not just a missed reference, the audio files themselves are outright gone. Hammerhead's objective pickup buzzer is changed to what can be charitably described as screams of the damned.

Technical: to begin with, the game breaks achievements if you don't jump through the hoops to launch it through an outdated version of Origin. Even if it didn't do that, the "new" and "improved" EA Play launcher can refuse to work for months at a time due to circumstances likely related to the movement of stars. The game's own launcher, as if it needed another one, is inexplicably DX12-only despite the games themselves requiring nothing of the sort. FPS drops and momentary freezes are annoyingly common despite running on hardware ahead of the game's requirements by several generations.

The ME2 bug with slotting abilities into the quickbar that annoyed me back in 2010 is *still* in the game and occasionally crashes it just like the original. Camera randomly breaks in ME1 and locks you into one direction. Pinnacle Station is gone - not that anyone would miss it, but the fact that modders brought it back without access to the source code calls Bioware's competence into question. No such luck for ME3's multiplayer, which was once considered the major draw of the game.

Thankfully, a lot of these can be fixed with unofficial patches and mods. A lot more exist in the base game that I haven't noticed thanks to said patches and mods. When all the hoops have been jumped through, it's still a Mass Effect experience, but given its persistent attempts to resist providing that experience, I too recommend resisting buying it unless it's at least -75% off on a sale.

The Mass Effect Trilogy, is simply put, one of the greatest experiences I've ever had the pleasure to, well, experience. It's one of the most captivating, detailed and passionately created worlds and stories I've ever seen, with the closest comparison I can make being Sci-Fi Game of Thrones. Perhaps not as realistically explicit, but similar themes, of morality vs reality, honor and dishonor, and leadership and camaraderie and choices, and the paths they lead down, and so much more. The writing is phenomenal, and there are so many lines permanently branded into my memory. I wish my English literature degree I am currently working through could help me become as eloquent as I would want to be, to be able to reach inside myself and pull out all the emotions and feelings and thoughts that went through my head as I was playing these games, and mold them into language I can give form to, into words that give justice to them. Sadly, I'm about as eloquent as a woodsquirrel, so you will have to forgive me. All I can really tell you is, if you care even in the slightest about storytelling, about the worlds that can be created, and the characters that can jump to life in our imaginations, you owe it to yourself to play these games, like with The Witcher 3, or Red Dead 2, or the Souls games, or Fallout New Vegas. 

I genuinely can't think of the words I want to use to describe what it felt like playing through Mass Effect, what it felt like exploring these vividly textured worlds, these multi-faceted, complex characters I got to know and genuinely love as if they were real people. The choices I made, unaware of the myriad of tiny, and gigantic repercussions that would ripple out from those choices, often came back to haunt me, sometimes immediately, sometimes whole games later, tearing up at more than a few occasions. People tend to criticize Mass Effect 3, and specifically its endings, and while I agree to some extent, and having my own gripes with some of the plot points, the overall experience remained unforgettable. 

I'm probably going to add to these thoughts as they come to me, and come back to this review to add them in, but right now, I'm going to have to leave it at that. The Citadel DLC was absolutely phenomenal too, I just have to add, hellbent on making me either grin, or tear up, or both at every moment, a poignant, heartfelt farewell to one of the greatest series of games I have ever played. Garrus, Tali, Liara, Joker, Thane, Legion, EDI, Mordin, Wrex, Grunt, Jack, and all the others, I will forever remember and cherish these characters and their stories, as cringe as that may sound. I don't give a sh*t.

The Mass Effect Trilogy is still one of my favourite series of games. Though the series has its flaws, as any piece of creative media does, the love and the dedication of those men and women at Bioware who created it shines through.

I was most interested in replaying Mass Effect 3, after I purchased the Legendary Edition, as I'd not played it since it was originally released. With the addition of the DLC content, the game is a lot better than I'd remembered. Still, from a narrative perspective, it is probably still the weakest entry in the series. 

The final book, game, or film in any trilogy is always the hardest to get right. You have to somehow tie up all the loose ends in a satisfactory manner, while also bringing the main story to an end in a way that doesn't feel contrived. There are many great moments in Mass Effect 3, and its still a good game, with or without the narrative issues. I'll be interested to see what Mass Effect 4 will bring, though I'll wait till we know what direction Bioware want to take it in.

The Legendary Edition is without a doubt the best way to play these games. The graphical upgrades are nice, though the main draw for me is all the DLC and extra content are bundled in directly, so I got to experience a lot of the cool missions, and many of them are more interesting than the main story content.

Most folks will have likely purchased this long ago, though for anyone who hasn't played Mass Effect, I can thoroughly recommend it. It is true that Mass Effect 1, in terms of the game play, is quite crude when comparing it to Mass Effect 2 & 3, though it is still my personal favourite.

I know a few people complained about the fact you need to download the EA launcher to play this, and I'll admit it did put me off for a long time, though after picking this up on sale, its not much of an issue. If you're really against it, you could always uninstall the EA launcher once you're done with your play throughs.

All in all, to some up these games would require me to write an essay on each game, and it makes more sense to simply play them and make up your own mind as to each games strengths and weaknesses.

The only downside to a series like Mass Effect is that it'll reduce the chances that another games company will create something similar with a new IP, which I would personally love, at some point in the future. 

Mass Effect is up there with Star Wars, Star Trek, Babylon 5, Dune, and many other Sci-Fi classics of our time, and I can't think of any higher praise than that.

~~SPOILER FREE REVIEW~~
I wasn't one that played Mass Effect when it originally released.  I played a bit of ME2, not very far in, but I didn't have any context for the game.  I bought the Legendary Edition when it released because I knew I was missing out on a great trilogy, I just didn't know how great.  ME1 is the perfect entry point for the series.  The gameplay mechanics are a little dated, but it still holds up well.  The main story isn't overly complicated, but the lore is fascinating and draws you in completely from the first mission.  There's so much to learn about this universe, I found myself reliving when I fell in love with Star Wars and learning all about the extended universe when I was a kid.

I'm incredibly drawn to the Quarian species.  For example, in between mission when you go to speak with Tali, she complains about how she can't sleep because it's too quiet.  Her kind living on the Flotilla among the stars, basically starships patched together for centuries.  She complains that it's too quiet, because when it's quiet on the Flotilla that means an engine went out, or the environmental scrubbers malfunctioned.  Too quiet means potentially fatal problems for the entire crew.  It's a short exchange but it's small details like that, that reveal the care the original Bioware team put in to developing these different species cultures and making them feel "real." They really put themselves into the perspective of what it would be like to live on the Flotilla, what kind of problems would arise, how would they feel in a different setting outside their comfort zone.  Like a living part of the universe you're traveling.  That's just one of many examples like that.

ME2 is without question the greatest of the trilogy.  After playing through ME1 and going straight into ME2, the quality of life changes to the combat systems and game mechanics feel incredible. They simplified the skill system in a very meaningful way that doesn't take away from the game. The story is absolutely epic, the roleplay elements feel significant, the romance options (Tali's my girl) feel vulnerable, and every story told has so much more depth to it.  Like Miranda telling you early on she's genetically modified but then later discovering what that really means to her.  The paragon and renegade system feels much more substantial in ME2 with different species reacting differently to them based on their culture, their individual personalities, and context in which they apply.  Yes in my humble opinion, Mass Effect 2 is without question one of the greatest games I've ever played.

Finally to sum it up with ME3.  Bioware really learned from their experience with ME2 and improved upon the gameplay mechanics once again. There's not much to say about how it changed except the overall feel and pacing of the action.  I do think the gameplay and combat reached it's peak in ME3, while the story peaked in ME2.  That's not to say the story isn't good in ME3 as well, but how do you follow up a nearly perfect entry?  There was almost no way in which the story of ME3 could exceed ME2.  Because of that, I did feel slightly disappointed in the ending of ME3, but I enjoyed my time with it nonetheless.

Overall, these games are an amazing piece of storytelling in which the player crafts the outcome.  There are many games since that have used this style where the ending is decided by the player's actions and decisions I.e. role playing, but I don't think any of them truly come close to recreating the grandeur of the Mass Effect trilogy.  Yes, I do see myself coming back to replay them many times for many years to come.

TL;DR:  STEAM ACHIEVEMENTS IN THIS GAME ARE BUGGY AND DON'T UNLOCK IN ME 2 or 3. There are stability issues in ME 1, but this was one of the best gaming experience I've had this year. If you don't mind the lack of achievements unlocking, play it! I loved the experience, but can't recommend because achievements are broken.

The meat of my issues:

While playing the first game I had one of the best experiences playing a video game in recent months, I had previously played mass effect two when it originally came out, but hadn't play ME 1 or 3 so this edition was a perfect re-introduction to the series for me HOWEVER. 

The EA launcher, that this game requires to play has made the experience DRASTICALLY worse. Aside from significant stability issues that caused me to be near constantly saving throughout the first game, the launcher has made launching the game a hassle and only seems to have added downsides with no upside.

My biggest grip with the game -- and I want to note my only real gripe with this game as aside from stability it was one of the best experiences I've had in a long time -- is that Achievements are completely bugged out for ME 2 and 3, with no way to acquire them at this time. The kicker to this is that there's no way to know this UNTIL you finish the first game and start ME 2 only to realize that the achievements should be unlocking and aren't. Which for me started a lengthy dive down a google and forum rabbit hole only to find that after the sunsetting of origin, there's no way to unlock achievements in 2/3 of this game reliably. But, once you find that, most of us will be outside of the return window having played the entirety of the first game to get to this point.

Thus, I just can't recommend this game while this bug persists, as it means that a major, advertised feature of this game is fundamentally broken for 2/3 of the video game. And, from various forum posts and comments made by EA it appears there's no interest in fixing this problem. It's really irritating that a game that came out just over 2 years ago has this fundamental of a flaw. I think that steam should remove the achievements as advertised from the game's listing unless this bug is fixed.

It's really unfortunate that a game I was truly enjoying had such a fundamental flow in it. Sure, I got my "money's worth" and I can't return the game, but it's not the point. My experience is marred because EA refuses to play ball and fix the game. I'm irritated because I bought the game thinking it had achievements and it didn't so one of the fundamental ways that I relate to playing video games recently is broken in this game.

This trilogy skyrocketed to the upper tier of gaming experiences I have had in the last 5 years.

Even if its a bit dated, the first game was fantastic. So many meaningful choices and decisions put you right in the drivers seat of handling every tense moment. The story was a fun ride of a race against time to stop the evil from accomplishing their goals. The companions were great and really felt like actual characters instead of cardboard cutouts. I was on the edge of my seat from start to finish and loved the 30 or so hours I put in to do every side quest and task. 

Mass Effect 2 felt like a step up in nearly every way from the first. The gameplay felt smoother, the character moments felt better and while I felt the main story of 1 was a little more engaging, the climax of 2 was off the charts in terms of stress, decision making and edge of your seat action. I don't think I have been as glued to the screen, so afraid to make the wrong decision as I did at the end of the game with how much decisions mattered. It was really cool to see a game really push the envelope of making the player feel the consequences and rewards of every decision they made. 

Despite all the issues with 3s ending, the journey of Mass Effect 3 might be my favorite of the 3. Packed full of emotions and heavy decisions, it really felt like the series was wrapping up with a perfect bow. It felt like it was going to be the best way of ending an 80 hour long journey through the franchise, but unfortunately it fell flat in doing so. Despite that, I still absolutely loved it. The gameplay was fun, the characters were still great as always and the Citadel DLC was a great moment before finishing that really made me look back and say "man what a fun ride its been". 

All 3 games had their flaws at various points, but I can say without a doubt this franchise was one of my favorite gaming experiences I have had in some time. I went in not knowing much about them and I really recommend anyone who hasn't played them to give them a go because the first time seeing everything the series had to offer was an absolute joy.

The Mass Effect series is one of the best RPG series in gaming.  None of the games are perfect, but all are easily worth your time and money.  However, EA is a horrible company who can't support even their best franchises.  At the time of writing, the achievements in 2 out of 3 of the games don't work because EA forced everyone to migrate to the EA app.  I have to give a negative overall rating because of that.  However, the games themselves are very good, and if you don't mind giving money to an incompetent and arguably evil company, read on.

Mass Effect 1 is an unfocused and overly ambitious game.  The inventory system is somewhat tedious, and the Uncharted Planets gameplay is fairly uninspired.  However, everything else about the game is amazing.  The story and dialog are some of the best in any RPG, as long as you understand that unlike many western RPGs, you're more inhabiting a set character than trying to totally build your own in Commander Shepard.  The Legendary edition has completely transformed the gunplay from rather poor in the original to above average.  The RPG mechanics as you level up your character and unlock and upgrade new powers is a little overly detailed, but quite understandable once you've had some time to learn it. Overall its an immensely fun game to get lost in the worldbuilding of.  

Mass Effect 2 is an improvement in almost every way on Mass Effect's strengths.  The shooting is tighter, and the story is more personal.  The interrupt system makes dialog go from very good to cinematic and probably the most fun I've had in an action RPG.  There are only two missteps in my opinion.  The RPG mechanics are extremely stripped down, especially on your squad-mates. And it seems like they were unable to come up with any way of making planet exploration enjoyable, so they just replaced it with a scanning minigame.  A DLC included in this bundle does add Vehicle combat, but its very stripped down and only usable in a very small amount of content.  It's not really an improvement on ME1 due to that.  But, what you're left with is a sequel to Mass Effect that was arguably even better than the original when it came out.  The massive improvements to ME1's shooting makes the gap a good deal smaller in this bundle, but ME2 is still one of the best action RPGs of all time.  Also you can romance more aliens in this one so that also scores it more points. 

Mass Effect 3 is the hardest to rate objectively in my opinion.  In most ways it is clearly the best game.  The shooting mechanics and RPG mechanics find their best form here.  For 90% of the game the story is as strong as its ever been, and many of the characters and story ideas get excellent endings that tie everything up greatly.  But on the other hand, this game has the worst flaws.  Turret sections.  Most Dialog gives few branching options, generally just 2 choices.  There's really no exploration mechanic at all.  And the Act 3 ending to the whole story is just a massive flop.  90% of the game is amazing.  10% is the worst of the whole series.  It makes it very hard to give a definite rating.  The obvious struggle the devs had to actually give the series a strong ending is clear.  They obviously worked very hard, but they did not stick the landing.  Sucks, but it is what it is.  Still well worth playing, and honestly the ending, as bad as it is, is rather iconic and worth experiencing so you can understand an important moment in the history of RPGs.  If you played ME1 and 2 I'd recommend it.

The Mass Effect trilogy is a game series close to my heart. Since the day ME1 premiered to the day the trilogy ended, I found myself absolutely enthralled by its majesty and scale. If you seek a science fiction ballad full of action, suspense, intrigue, and romance you have no further to look than here. This cornerstone series of games shows just what storytelling in the medium of video games can be. Though time has not been the kindest on the first installment, the series as a whole holds up incredibly well and will continue to entertain people for generations.

This trilogy holds a very secure and special place in my heart. It's one of the best experiences I've ever had playing something. The creativity behind the building of this galaxy places, stories, races and people (and even the technical background for every practical aspect of these advanced-technology based relations) cannot be overmeasured at any rate. 

The Mass Effect main trilogy (let's leave Andromeda sided for now) presents not only a remarkable sci-fi story, but it is also an learning experience about friendship, relationships, understanding new cultures and different points of views. It's a game about making choices that could affect everyone around you, and the consequences will be felt throughout the three games, whether good or not.

I really advise you to play the three games very slowly, following its pace. Enjoy the dialogues, the adventures, and dive into this rich universe. Try yourself to explore every conversation, every mission available and everything that the three games offer, you'll not regret it. 

I must say, however, that EA support on this game is really poor and unoptmized. The main issue as of today (04/22/2023) is the blocked achievement unlocking on steam, caused by a bug stemmed from EA App bad programming. This bug prevents you from unlocking ME2 and ME3 achievements, as they're already unlocked in-game, tricking Steam to consider that if they're already obtained in the game, the player already has the achievement. It kinda sucks, but that are fixes available on the internet, you'll just have to search for yourself.

[b]My review is no spoiler! Read on without fear![/b]

[b]TL;DR: [/b] Everyone should play this trilogy and the legendary edition is a perfect bundle for these games. It is not without flaw, but far and away one of the most fun, engaging, and fulfilling gaming experiences of my entire life (as a life long avid enjoyer of games of all genres).

[b]Full Review[/b]
To dive into more details The Legendary edition is essentially just a wrapper around all three Mass Effect games and their DLCs all included in one purchase. It took me nearly 150 hours to play through the whole thing. Most of that 150 hours is without any grinding or useless filler. It's all story and missions all the time. I meant it when I said this is a very engaging game. It's massive, gorgeous, and the amount of work and effort put into it is unrivaled in it's genre. While you do have the ability to go off and grind extra money and resources, and there are ample side missions throughout all the games they are mostly optional even for a perfect ending. And not much of my time was spent on side missions or grinding.

The best part of this game is the story. It connects through all three games and all DLCs. But not just loosely, if you're here you may have heard that the decisions made change the next game and everything is connected. But the extent to which this is true was beyond what I thought anyone would attempt. A character in the first game dying will change the story in the next two games. Decisions made long ago will come back to help or haunt you. Every person you save or kill, it all matters. 

Beyond being connected, these games do something I didn't expect. They refused to let that connection limit the story. A character you let die could have been a main character in the final game, and you'd never know because the story is that extensive. It's a very well written story with some of the best characters and lore I've ever seen. I will, for quite some time, remember not just this game and story, but the personalities of my crewmates and the jokes they made and the people we lost along the way. Most movies and books don't have the level of characters development and motivation the Mass Effect series has. 

Now, up until now I've done nothing but praise the game, and it deserves every second of that praise. But there are two "Negatives" I want to discuss. The first being one I personally found, and the second being the one everyone talks about.

[b]Negative #1[/b] - Mass Effect 1 is the oldest and most flawed of the games. It still has the amazing story, world, and characters, but it falls flat in two areas, the combat is a bit clunky, and the only real grind in this entire series is in the first game. The number of side missions and their lack or importance can hit a bit hard here. I found a solution though. Follow a guide for mission order and importance. You can skip most of the useless side stuff and only do the side missions that effect future games. Those side missions still are my least favorite part, and please, please, please, don't give up here. I did for a month before I tried again. I'm so glad I pushed through it. I won't post links, but I used the "SUGGESTED MISSION ORDER GUIDE" on gamespot. Highly recommend that guide.

[b]Negative #2[/b] Mass Effect 3's ending is not nearly as bad as I think people make it out to be. It is definitely not perfect, but this game is not all sunshine and rainbows (I cried multiple times) and you will simply not get through the games without loss. Accept that now, and know that the Universe is a harsh place and there is no 100% happy ending and sometimes there are just not as many choices as you want there to be. If you take that to heart you will finish the game if not happy but content with the ending.

[b]Final Words of Advice:[/b]
Enjoy ME1's story and world building, use a guide to cut out the unnecessary side stuff. Enjoy ME2 as it is a masterpiece all the way through, fixing and improving on every part of the first game. Finally, Enjoy ME3, (controversial opinion perhaps) I liked this game even more than the second one. The arcs conclude in epic fashion and you will have the highlights of the story. Don't skip out on getting to know your crew, Mass Effect is driven by it's characters, and nearly all of them are worth knowing.

I've been really enjoying this so far, I'm about halfway through ME1 and I only have a few minor complaints, otherwise I am really happy with this remaster.

First of all, I think too many people expected this to be a full on remake where all three games are completely different, the ending for ME3 is entirely re-written, and they get a free life sized android of Miranda to come suck them off while they play. This is not the case. The legendary edition is [i]just a remaster, it was meant to touch up the graphics and gameplay and modernize the overall experience of the trilogy for current audiences to enjoy, and neither Bioware nor EA ever advertised this to be anything but that.[/i]

The things that I really like so far about it is the gameplay, especially. Gunplay feels so much smoother and less clunky, things like the shaky sniper rifle is fixed, the UI looks a lot nicer and cleaner, and you can now sprint at any time, not just in combat, which is a godsend for going around the Citadel for side quests. The new graphics also look great in my opinion, so many textures were touched up and look so much nicer than in the original version, I don't like some of the lighting changes but it doesn't take away from the experience at all and is really a negligible complaint on my part.

Is it perfect? No, there's a few issues that me and other people are annoyed by. The negative mouse acceleration is absolutely atrocious, I started playing with a controller because it annoyed me that much, and there is no way to fix it. There's also no way to change the nauseatingly low FOV, although there is already a few mods that let you change it so I recommend people who hate low FOV to go find that ASAP. I know people are also complaining about the lackluster ultrawide support, but I'm pretty sure something like <1% of people on Steam have an ultrawide monitor so odds are it wouldn't be an issue for most of you.

Overall, I am really enjoying this remaster for one of my all time favorite game series. I think if you're willing to put up with the minor issues I mentioned, you'd absolutely love these games, whether you're a new fan or old. Gameplay aside, the story and characters of this trilogy are phenomenal, those things along with the atmosphere and world building will easily draw you in, even if the gameplay and other issues don't.

Legendary Edition is hard to rate. Wish there was a neutral rating.

On the one hand, a lot has been done to improve the experience in some areas. The Legendary version of ME1 is like playing a new game. The graphics, audio and gameplay has been almost completely reworked, resulting in a much more engaging game from the 2007 version. It might be worth buying this package just for the work done on that game alone.

The same cannot be said for ME2 and 3. Its not zero, but little has been done to improve the gameplay, graphics etc. of the Mass Effect sequels. So you're pretty much buying a more expensive 2nd and 3rd game without any significant changes.

Its also 96gbs. The Legendary edition does include all the DLC, so that might make it worth it for some. But for me, that file size just felt insane and little to nothing can be deleted to reduce it without breaking the game. 

EA play is also required. I don't share the hate for EA play that others have, but its still an extra 520mb of bloatware on your computer, has corrupted code that prevents you from getting achievements in ME2 or 3 and forces you to always be online to play the game. So its not great.

Still, I can't bring myself to flip this review negative. I was having fun a lot of the time and that's what matters in the end. If you're a fan or never played before, the Legendary edition is worth it. But wait for the game to drop to $30 or below. Its not worth $60.

I loved these games growing up. But after playing ME1 again and then going into ME2, only having 2 weapons (unless soldier class), losing 90% of weapon customization, forced global cool-down instead of individual ability cool-downs makes it so that I have to AFK behind cover and fight things in waves, it also means that the AI followers will be less useful, and then to top that off the enemy AI almost always target you instead of any companions, they prefire, they shoot before they are fully out of cover and aiming their weapons, can even shoot homing rockets from some enemies through the cover they are hiding behind (fun), forced installation of AI on my ship, changed the star map so you physically move the ship between planets but just adds 2x the amount of time and effort for the same outcome, the cover system now requires 2 buttons to be pressed to enter cover, your followers use their abilities from your perspective and will hit random objects next to where you are aiming with their powers, all weapons use ammo (scarce resource) instead of heat (what? how? why?) when the 2nd game takes place 2 years after the first one...

TLDR: The second game feels like it was the first game, and the first game feels like it was the second game, I don't know why they would add all these terrible changes. Glad I didn't play these games back to back as a child because I definitely wouldn't have enjoyed them in the same way.

Going to revise and compare when I finish ME3 again, feel free to comment anything constructive on ME2's gameplay/changes/etc

ME2 becomes playable about half way through the game when you get enough talent points to have useful skills. Even with a nearly max level character from ME1 transferred the game felt so off in comparison to how the first game felt. ME3 adds a bunch of elements back in from ME1... Except in ME3 you still get forced down to peon level after getting kicked in the shins in ME2. ME1 gave you all of the power to play the game how you wanted. Makes no sense how backwards these games are. Some areas of these newer games look worse than ME1. Running animation, dodging is useless and causes more problems than it fixes (especially when it happens constantly trying to maneuver your character like normal but because you for some reason cant strafe it dodge rolls instead?) Ashley in ME3 makes me regret saving her instead of Kaidan, and arguably looks worse in ME3. 

They added the ability to use more than 2 weapons again, but selecting a weapon in an empty weapon slot uses skill recharge time, up to nearly 100% addition in cooldown by equipping one weapon. You still have global cooldown which means you have to wait about 2 seconds to cast your secondary skill that you would use for detonation, causing the gameplay to feel turn based and waiting on skills instead of in ME1 where you use your skills so they go on cooldown then you use your selection of weapons and mods to play the fight out from there how you want. Now it's just sit and wait constantly. AI auto lock on you way harder, have less shielded enemies or armored enemies to start so you have no real damage type advantage over the just high HP enemies instead. Makes abilities and gameplay way more bland. They also added shield enemies that are somehow planted in the ground and are unmovable objects. You can hit them with a singularity and they don't care, you can hit them with a 1000 force Throw and they just act like they were hit with a ball of cotton candy. Terrible. Awful. Sad.

It's really sad to realize how poorly influenced such a well known game series actually is if you analyze it a second time. I can't imagine what these players were saying to the devs in between games to influence such terrible changes.

Also just the cherry on top, you can't run the game (ME3) higher than 60 FPS locked because your shield on your character wont recharge (fun!). 

"Legendary Edition" seems to only really mean ME1 is Legendary. This kind of reminds me of CoD getting worse and worse as they go, Diablo getting worse after 2, Battlefield series falling apart at Battlefield 2, FarCry goes from FarCry 2 (legendary), FarCry 3 (arguably the most favorite amongst others), (FarCry Blood Dragon was released in between these games but nobody acknowledges its existence as it isn't worth the $3 it is sold for), FarCry 4 (God-Like), FarCry Primal (feels like an entire different series and ties for second place), then they start falling down a very steep tall hill into FarCry 5, New Dawn, and 6 where it's not even remotely the same and is sad to see as a fan. 

I think I would rather have companies release the same game with new content and graphics, maybe some extra options to change to your liking, stuff that could really be a DLC, or simply just do it how Dying Light did it with the Following. Don't jump ahead like they did in Dying Light 2 and ruin everything.

I have to admit, that technobabble isn't half-bad! Tying mass & structure of space-time into magic'esque powers makes certain sense, given this whole Higgs biz. The writing style is classical fantasy, I don't mind though. It's a [url=store.steampowered.com/app/208580]space opera[/url] after all, not [url=www.imdb.com/title/tt3230854]hard SciFi[/url]. Speaking of which, a spacious orchestral score goes well with exploring a spacious, stunningly designed space station. The strong visual style very much works in its favor.

I don't really care about the powers anyway, a bunch of cooldown-based hotkeys doesn't cut it from a gameplay perspective so I ended up treating it as a tacltical'ish third-person shooter (with my team throwing in abilities on their own volition, always love self-reliant squadmates). [url=steamcommunity.com/id/reboot/recommended]If you know me[/url], you know I like dem shotguns chonky and this one is dang good by TPS standards!

The prologue, I gotta say, was a let-down. A really linear romp without [strike]lots[/strike] any [url=store.steampowered.com/app/606880]alternative solutions[/url]. [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1041720]Some dialog options here and there[/url], leading to the same result albeit giving you a different kind of serial episode to watch. Please don't take the last one as a complaint, the dialogs are really well-written, well-acted, well-watchable! Too bad they nuked speech skills in ME2.

What it does good, are consequences. RPGs win a lot if [url=store.steampowered.com/app/367500]something you did a couple hours (and maybe years in-universe) comes back to remind you[/url] and that's what this one really going for. Does it good too, make no mistake, I just wish there was a wider in-quest decision tree. The stories themselves, on the other hand, are certainly worth it! Rich writing all around, going someplace and then getting lost in a lil' side-story is what I play RPGs for! Another RPG quality it has is to remind you every now and then what you did a couple hours (or years, in-universe) before, to remind you that this is a cohesive world with a cohesive narrative.

I don't mind the Mako sequences either. Humping around some distant backwater hellhole makes perfect sense within the in-game universe and I really dig connections between gameplay & lore. I also dig finding some side-quest-relevant tidbit in a hidden place in some remote hellhole. I don't dig Mercury though, meaning I don't dig "quests" of the brand "do menial A X times" and "do menial B Y times" and... Not an open-world game in a classical sense, it does commit yer olde classical open-world sin of filling the quest log with surrogate daily jobs (I'd quit on the spot though if my real job was so menial).

To its credit, optional parts are optional. I still fault it for leaning heavily on the cinematic side of things. On the flipside, this one's a good fit for GUI. I still wish they didn't ramp up the cinematic parts throghout the series, neither can I get over picking an evil line in ME3 and then getting something, I would have with IRL friends and we'll feel close. ME1 had way more substance to its dialogs.

A Series That Lost Its Way and Succumbed to Ideological Agendas

Rating: 2/5 Stars

While the Mass Effect Trilogy initially showed great promise, it ultimately became a massive disappointment, particularly with the release of Mass Effect 3. The game's narrative took a backseat to the developers' apparent desire to push a strong emphasis on LGBTQ+ representation and the "strong woman" trope.

Shepard, once a powerful and respected protagonist, is reduced to a shell of his former self, taking orders from everyone and losing his edge. The storyline involving Jack's transformation from a psychopath in Mass Effect 2 to a reformed teacher in the third installment feels forced and unrealistic.

The writing quality in Mass Effect 3 pales in comparison to the first two games, making it seem as though it was penned by an inexperienced intern with a power fantasy. The original developers' departure from BioWare and the subsequent push for diversity and inclusion have significantly impacted the game's overall quality.

Additionally, the first game has technical issues with sound, including missing surround sound and imbalanced audio levels. A workaround is available, but it results in further complications.

As for Mass Effect Andromeda, it's best to steer clear of that title, as it only adds to the disappointment of the series.

In conclusion, the Mass Effect Trilogy has become a frustrating and ideologically-driven experience that fails to deliver the captivating storytelling and engaging gameplay that fans once loved. It's best to avoid this series and seek out games that prioritize the player's experience over political agendas.

This is a no-spoiler review. I may make grand general statements about the game, and I may even refer to some events in the game, but not enough to spoil any major stuff.

This is the best story-game I have ever played, by MILES. The story is so good, I've played through the whole trilogy multiple times as both male and female Shepard, and I'm about to do it again. It's just incredibly immersive and deep. 

Your choices don't matter as much as they hype it, but they DO matter, and have some affect on the story. But even though the choices don't have a huge impact, it still feels very much like the NPCs in the game are referring to your character and their choices. There are thousands of tiny little lines of dialogue that are done in multiple ways depending on what you did in the past. 

And the epic scale of the story, and the lore you discover along the way, all pays off tremendously. The Ending.... let's talk about the ending. A lot of people hated it. But I loved it. It was every bit as grand and amazing and dramatic and majestic in scale as it needed to be. Some found it bittersweet. But it's the ending the game needed. The game tells you how it has to end. From the very beginning. You complainers all just didn't listen. :)

The only other game that comes close to this in terms of story and emotion is Red Dead Redemption 2. It's great, but it's 1/3 of the length. I hope RDR3 is coming soon. I tried RDR1 but just couldn't get into it.

Sorry for the ramble, that's how I do some of my reviews, and not others.
